story:
Hold These Truths

by Jeanne Sakata

     World War II has begun and a young student, Gordon Hirabayashi, agonizes over the US government's orders to forcibly remove and mass incarcerate all people of Japanese ancestry on the West Coast. As he fights to reconcile his country’s betrayal with his passionate belief in the U.S. Constitution, Hirabayashi journeys toward a greater understanding of America’s triumphs — and a confrontation with its failures.

     "Jeanne Sakata’s eloquent one-man drama about civil rights giant, Gordon Hirabayashi provides a concise examination of a fascinating chapter in American history..." 

HUFFINGTON POST-ASSOCIATED PRESS


     "This well-crafted and beautifully acted piece offers not just a glimpse of the past but an extraordinarily relevant message for today..." 

MINNEAPOLIS STAR TRIBUNE

 

Hang a Tale

www.hangatale.org

     We are a 501(c)3, non-profit, New York City-based, theatre company creating works for the Off-Broadway stage. We seek tales of universality, old and new, that transcend the limitations of time. We search for stories that inspire us and start conversations about our lives and the world around us. And Jeanne Sakata's Hold These Truths is such a piece.  

In 1942, approximately 120,000 Japanese-Americans were targeted for internment by the United States government. One of these people, Gordon Hirabayashi, dared to take a stand and fight against his government's unjustified attack upon his civil rights. Now, in 2017, his story is more relevant than ever. Under our current U.S. government, constitutional rights are, again, in peril, and specific groups of people are being subjected to harsh scrutiny based solely upon their religion and ethnicity. We believe every American should  bear witness to Gordon Hirabayashi's incredible story: a journey of courage that can serve as a model to anyone wishing to raise their voice in protest to injustice.

 

We Need You!

Funding for the arts is also in danger. Budgets are being cut, if not eliminated all together. We are passionate about this project and desire to give it the exposure it deserves. We cannot do it without you. We need the help of our community of friends to sustain our work. Give now. Every, single penny counts toward the rising costs of production. Whether it's theatre rental, insurance, costumes, lights or paying artists a fair wage, all donations go toward these expenses. Thank you! 

 

Spread the Word!

Help us reach others. Please, send this campaign to anyone who might be interested in our story. Perhaps, it will inspire them to pitch in and make a difference.

Find out more about Hold These Truths and Hang a Tale.

www.hangatale.org

Again, thank you! We appreciate it!

story:
DESCRIPTION DU PROJET

Avec la montée de la droite politique, l’espoir en l’humanité peut être ébranlée par des discours parfois haineux et empreints de lâcheté volontaire. Le besoin de reprendre ce texte de création est né du désir d’exposer quelques-uns de ces discours pour montrer l’absurdité des propos tenus par les personnages qui sont souvent contraires à la morale et aux normes sociales, mais qui, malheureusement, reflètent la pensée de plusieurs. L'ironie, bien ancrée dans l'écriture et qui sous-tend ce joyeux carnage, est manifeste.

À mesure que les tableaux se succèdent, le rationnel fait place à une animalité et une agressivité grandissantes pour finalement se terminer en une joyeuse chasse à l’homme effrénée, où parfois un groupe poursuit une personne, parfois une personne poursuit un groupe. Le discours disparaît pour laisser place au mouvement, aux pulsions. C’est tranchant comme un couteau bien effilé. Précis comme la pointe d’une flèche empoisonnée qui nous atteint en plein cœur. C'est la pièce Tranche-cul de Jean-Philippe Baril Guérard.

Êtes-vous prêts ? 

C'est au second étage du Quartier de Lune à Limoilou que ça se passe. Du 6 au 16 novembre (relâche les vendredi 10 et samedi 11 novembre). https://lepointdevente.com/billets/tranche-cul-ql

Pour que notre projet soit aussi éblouissant en réalité qu'il l'est dans nos têtes et dans nos cœurs depuis plusieurs semaines déjà, on a besoin de vous. De votre soutien. Qui est si précieux.  Que ce soit pour des éléments de décor évocateurs, des accessoires ou des costumes qui aideront à donner vie aux personnages, chaque contribution sera rentabilisée à son plein potentiel !

*** Nous avons pensé à vous ! En échange de vos dons, vous trouverez, à droite de l'écran, des surprises amusantes en lien avec la pièce gracieusement offertes par nos partenaires et commanditaires.***

 

TRANCHE-CUL

ÉQUIPE DE PRODUCTION

Un texte de Jean-Philippe Baril Guérard

Mise en scène : Angélique Patterson (œil extérieur : Jonathan Gagnon)

Interprétation : Ann-Sophie Archer, Vincent Champoux, Charles Fournier, Nadia Girard Eddahia, Stéphanie Jolicoeur, Marianne Marceau, Jean-Nicolas Marquis, Angélique Patterson, Annabelle Pelletier Legros 

Conception : Mélanie Robinson (décor et costumes), Mathieu C. Bernard (éclairages), Jonathan Sonier (conception sonore), Valérie Pitre (collaboration au mouvement), Guillaume Lévesque (graphisme)

 

SYNOPSIS

Il s’agit de nous. Il s’agit de vous. Il s’agit de ce que certains, vous et nous, peuvent penser tout bas de ces autres qui sont « différents » de soi. Certains le pensent sans le dire. D’autres le disent sans le penser.

Eux, ce sont 14 personnages qui montent aux barricades pour clamer haut et fort dans une succession de monologues adressés au public ce qu’ils pensent de cet "autre" à qui ils sont confrontés. Tel un miroir réfléchissant, voire même déformant, les personnages confrontent leur vision du monde et leur système de valeurs aux préjugés et autres idées préconçues des spectateurs. 9 comédiens (qui interprètent les 14 personnages) sont d’abord assis parmi les spectateurs et se fondent dans la foule : ce sont des gens comme nous, comme vous, assis tout autour et parmi nous ; ce sont nos amis, nos proches, vos personnes-ressources, vos voisins. Puis, se sentant interpellés par l’urgence de dire, les personnages se révèlent un à un et se commettent devant le public, règlent leurs comptes. Cruauté, capitalisme, misogynie, racisme, mondialisation, sont autant de thèmes abordés sans filtre où chacun tente d’assainir l’espèce humaine selon une vision bien personnelle en se basant sur un certain darwinisme social pour justifier sa prise de position. Des discours où la liberté d’opinion et d’expression se confondent à un droit à la persécution.

Publiée chez Dramaturges Éditeurs, la pièce a d’abord été créée dans le cadre d’un laboratoire présenté à la Zone Homa en 2013 par le Théâtre en petites coupures, puis a été reprise à L’Espace libre en décembre 2014. Les textes de ce jeune auteur au talent indéniable n’ont jamais été montés à Québec dans un contexte professionnel.  

Le Collectif de feu

Nous sommes des comédiennes et comédiens professionnels de la relève et d'expérience, d'âges et de sexes différents, issus de familles théâtrales diverses de Québec. Cette multiplicité d'identités et de parcours artistiques fait écho à la pluralité des opinions qui sont livrées dans la pièce et donc, par extension, aux différents points de vue défendus par les spectateurs assistant au spectacle, à la manière d'un échantillon de population.

REMERCIEMENTS

Le Quartier de Lune, Hôtel C3 Art de vivre, Chez Alfred-Pellan Galerie d'art, Cinéma Le Clap, le Théâtre du Trident, Monsieur T., Fluolido, Manu Lemire, Première Ovation

story:
Ninja Ballet 

 

 

Shoko Tamai – Artistic Director / Choreographer / Producer

 

 

Shoko is a ballerina based in New York City. She grew up in the foothills along the base of Mount Fuji, in Japan. And she wants to share her passion for dance with as many people as she can. Shoko’s performing arts background, choreography, and professional dance experience are strongly interdisciplinary. Although her career has allowed her to perform on stages across the world dancing contemporary, modern, silk, & jazz she often finds herself back where it all started, in pointe shoes.

 

At age two, Shoko began dancing and training classical ballet in Japan. Since then dance has been her life’s work and passion. Dance is, and always has been her way of life.

 
Over the next chapter of her professional career she wants to explore the blending of cultural idioms through movement and dance. Shoko has taken her years of classical ballet training along with her cultural heritage from Japan, and combined them into a new dance discipline; a decoupage of east meets west with a twist. Martial Arts and classical ballet; it’s The Matrix meets Swan Lake. This new form of dance challenges the audience to question what they were anticipating to see.
We call this project Ninja Ballet Dance Project, as it contains equal parts classical ballet and martial arts influences.
 

The Plan

Our goal is to raise enough capital to rent a theatre, pay our performers, afford a marketing budget, and produce our first opening Ninja Ballet production.

Because we truly believe the more people who are able to experience our production, the more people will be able to identify with its message of unity & the human experience.

 

 

Budget Breakdown

This is a production with a message that we think is important to be told, every dollar counts!

Below you will be able to see a breakdown of our $25,000 goal.

  • Casting - 1%
  • Advertising/marketing - 3%
  • Props - 3%
  • Location Rental - 40%
  • Production Personnel - 40%
  • Special Effects - 4%
  • Craft Services - 3%.
  • Wardrobe Services - 6%

 

The Impact

Every dollar matters with respect to our Ninja Ballet opening production being successful and our ability to realize it’s artistic and performance art potential, for you the audience.

It’s important to support the performing arts, especially new and developing disciplines that don’t already have an established sponsorship in a community for younger generations to gain access to it. With your help, we hope to build beyond this first opening production and into a genre of dance and performance art that can be accessible by many peoples.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Every dollar counts and helps us reach our goal. We understand that not everyone is always able to donate even just five dollars sometimes. But maybe you know someone who can. Someone who loves supporting the performing arts and local theatre.

Please use the Indiegogo share tools and let your friends on your social media network know about our important goal, thank you.

story:
Who We Are & What We're Doing

Hello!

 

  • We are David Albert-Toth and Emily Gualtieri, co-artistic directors and choreographers of PARTS+LABOUR_DANSE, a Montreal contemporary dance company. We've created and toured several award-winning works throughout Quebec and Canada. We've just finished presenting our newest work and are gearing up to take the World by storm!
  • This campaign will allow us to present an excerpt of our work during PARCOURS DANSE, an annual networking event that would enable us to tour our new work LA VIE ATTEND.
  • By helping us fund this endeavour, you are helping to secure a future for the production, as well as for the dancers, composer, lighting designer, costume designer, and technical staff. 

 

 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's a breakdown of what we need, and what you'll get:

  • We need to raise $2,500 to cover all of our costs. This includes dancers' salaries, studio rentals, costume care and cleaning, set transportation, performance fees, and royalties.
  • Our perks include some breathtaking visuals taken during our performances by photographer Guzzo Desforges. They will look smashing on your wall or in your office!

 

 

The Impact

Your contribution makes a difference!

  • This project is immensely valuable to us. It is a key way for artists in our position to move forward in our careers by securing tour dates so that our pieces can live longer than their premiere run, and helps us reach greater audiences outside of our hometown. As with any artist - dance, music, theatre, even visual artists - touring is an integral part of career development.
  • Our last two pieces toured Quebec and Canada. In Mixed Company won the Coup de pouce prize and the Vue sur la relève festival here in Montreal, and La chute won the Audience Choice Award at Toronto's Dance: Made in Canada Festival. It was also named one of the year's top ten moments in dance in the national publication The Dance Current. These projects were made possible thanks in part to our Indiegogo campaign at the time.

 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't contribute directly to our campaign, we get it! Any help would be appreciated:

  • Get the word out! Anyone you know who might be interested in supporting emerging artists such as ourselves reach the next level - let 'em know!
  • Indiegogo has embedded sharing tools that can be of huge help to get word out to your friends or networks.

 

 

*** All performance photos © Guzzo Desforges // Headshots © Claudia Chan Tak

story:
Lights Up!

We are the brand new Do No Harm Theatre Company and we are preparing to present our first production in 2017.   Led by Co-Artistic Directors Cheryl Horne and Nomi Tichman, we believe in collaboration, in providing a safe space for the pursuit of art.  We believe that such a pursuit is accomplished when all involved are working toward a shared goal:  to tell a story, to illuminate a text, in short – to create art.  We strongly believe that a community of like-minded artists can change the world.  We aim to provide a safe haven for such activities.

These days seem to get darker and darker; let us gather together to create a well-lit space in which art and artists may flourish.

We are introducing Do No Harm with a new adaptation of A Child’s Christmas In Wales by Dylan Thomas at Pearl Studios on Sunday, December 10th for an invited audience.

In order to launch The Do No Harm Company's debut, we need to raise $1,600 to cover the rental of the hall and other related expenses for the presentation (stipends for actors, musical director and stage manager as well as rental of rehearsal space).

Any amount is welcome, but the first 5 contributors who pledge $100 or more will receive 2 reserved seats each to the presentation, along with a "vintage" copy of the poem, A Child's Christmas in Wales.

All contributors will receive Special Thanks program credit in any and all Do No Harm productions throughout 2018.

We believe that all artists deserve a safe environment in which to work, away from controversy and adverse criticism.  Art will flourish in this environment and will be sent out to enrich the world.

If you are unable to contribute to this project, please share this message with your friends.  Helping us get the word out is every bit as valuable as money.  Well, we like money too.

Thank you.

story:
Who is FWD

FWD Theatre Project (Festival of Works in Development) launched in 2014 with a vision to Discover, Develop, and Deliver the world's best original musicals for Chicago's audiences, actors, directors, and producers. With an amazing Season 1, including a powerful industry concert (headlined by Tony Award winner Jessie Mueller) and five beautiful sold out staged readings, FWD quickly became one of Chicago's boldest and most-watched new arts organizations. As excitement builds for our second year, promising more great original musical theatre for our city, we have one thing to say: Join us in this exciting, passionate new initiative!


Bring the World's Best New Musicals to Chicago

FWD has received over 400 submission of the world's best new musicals in development. Each season we welcome 5 winners to Chicago, engaging the entire arts community along with the city's best actors, directors, and creatives, all collaborating to turn our home into one of the country's favorite destinations for musical theatre development.

For example, on September 28th FWD will collaborate with American Music Theatre Project to present the World-Premiere concert reading of La Révolution Française by Alain Boublil and Claude-Michel Schönberg, the writers of Miss Saigon and Les Miserables who'll join us in Chicago for two weeks in preparation for this one-night only spectacular event. Great opportunities like this take funding!

What We Need and What You Get

FWD produces the country's best staged readings on well-managed, streamlined, impressive budgets. Production costs average $2500-$4000 per presentation and feature the city's best venues, star-quality Equity casts, top studio musicians, award-winning directors and musical directors, lighting, sound, writer support and housing, making each event special and memorable. Your money is well invested, and 100% of your support goes to readings you'll enjoy throughout the year.

                  

What's it worth to grow Chicago's influence in great original theatre? What's the benefit of supporting new musicals for ourselves and future generations? What about education and community outreach programs like audition master classes with casting legend Jay Binder? How valuable is it to secure star talents like Jessie Mueller, leading directors like Goodman's Henry Godinez, Broadway conductors like Todd Ellison, or to bring Boublil & Schönberg to our community?

Make your contribution today and help make it all happen. Our donors enjoy fantastic perks including full season and show producer credits, inside access to artists and writers, private industry events, VIP show tickets, signed posters, FWD logo merchandise, and a ground floor role in our exciting new musicals in process.

  

Your Impact

Chicago is recognized as a leading center for new plays, but rarely for original musical development. Patrons and artists want and need an organization like FWD, and the city's taken notice.

Chris Jones of the Chicago Tribune says, "It’s fair to say that no prior effort has been launched with the star power and oomph of (FWD.) Here, finally, (is) a group that might just have the savvy and chutzpah to give it a real Chicago-style go.”

Hedy Weiss writes in the Sun Times, "(FWD’s) venture is sure to imprint itself on the consciousness of anyone who loves new musicals and believes that Chicago, with its extraordinary talent pool of musical theater artists, should become a major force in their discovery, development and delivery."

Did you join us for a sold-out staged reading in FWD's inaugural season? Did it make you proud, engaged, eager for more? Did it deepen your connection to our theatre community and build love for this city? That's the impact your donations create.

  


Every Dollar & Every Person Counts

If you can't join us as a Season Producer or Show Producer, consider becoming a FWD Thinker for inside access and special involvement with the creative teams. Enjoy show and event tickets and special gifts from FWD. No level of support is too small to help build this vital initiative for all of us. Make your gift now!

Don't forget to tell your friends! Like us on Facebook, follow us on Twitter, tell your family, your fans, co-workers, the gal on the train, the barista at your corner Starbucks. FWD is connecting the community, the arts, and everyone in between - you're our best and most important storyteller. Welcome to FWD, and THANK YOU!

story:
Dance Week is coming!

In celebration of International Dance Day, DanceNL is bringing a series of dance initiatives to the people of Newfoundland and Labrador, and we need your help to make it the best it can be!

International Dance Day is a UNESCO-created event celebrated on April 29th each year. Its goals are to increase the awareness of the importance of dance among the general public, as well as to persuade governments all over the world to provide a proper place for dance in all systems of education, from primary to higher. This is DanceNL’s fifth Dance Week, and we are proud to be continuing some young traditions, and beginning a few new ones.

This year, we've got:

Dance Ambassadors: A face you know will tell you why dance matters to them. Uploaded daily to our YouTube and social media.

Most Danceable Song: Nominate and vote for the NL song that most makes you want to dance!

Province-wide Boogie: Dance for your webcam to the Most Danceable Song, and we'll cut it into a digital dance from St. John's to Nain!

Municipal Dance Off: St. John's Mayor Dennis O'Keefe and DanceNL are challenging municipal leaders and councils to dance for video, and then you get to vote for the best dance! Winner gets an awesome prize!

Random Acts of Dance: Watch out, NL - someone near you may start dancing at any moment!

Traditional Folk Dance Night at the Ship: The Folk Arts Society is letting us invade their Folk Night at the Ship on Wednesday, April 22nd with traditional Newfoundland set dancing and step dancing. 9pm, $5 admission.

Dance Unconference: We'll get dancers of all disciplines together with musicians, funders, and other partners to talk shop. Saturday, April 25th from 10am-4pm at the St. John's Arts & Culture Centre. Free to attend.

NL Moves: Body as Storytelling for Male Movers with Lynn Panting: DanceNL invites any fella who's ever been interested in dance to come along for this awesome, text-based dance workshop. Monday, April 27th at MAX, 6 St. Clare Ave., from 8-10pm. $10, or $5 if you're a DanceNL member.

Dare to Dance: We're challenging schools and other educational institutions across the province to dedicate a little time on April 29th to dance. We want the students of this province moving!

Dance for Discounts: Some of our pals in the NL business community will be offering one-day promotions on April 29th. The only catch: you have to dance for your discount!

You can help!

DanceNL has support from the City of St. John's, the Canada Council for the Arts, the Province of Newfoundland and Labrador and the Wellness Coaltion of Avalon-East, not to mention partner organizations like the Folk Arts Society, MusicNL, CBC Radio One, Business & Arts NL, Newman Sound Men's Choir, Lawnya Vawnya, and Veitch Physiotherapy and Wellness Centre…. so far! We're super lucky to have all these awesome, enthusiastic folks on board.

What we need now is just a little extra to make Dance Week 2015 the very best it can be: 

  • Hiring video and photo professionals as we need them throughout the week to keep everyone up to date on the goings-on, and to make our online content shine;
  • Getting snacks for participants at Folk Night, NL Moves and the Unconference (everyone loves snacks!);
  • Paying for a bit of extra admin time so that everything runs smoothly and everyone has a great time!
It would be great if we could do all of these things - but even if we don't raise our entire goal, we'll use your contributions to do as many of them as we can!
We have some awesome perks available for anyone who's able to pitch in as little as $5 - check them out!

No dollars? No problem!

If you want to support Dance Week 2015 but can't pitch in cash, don't worry about it! There are lots of ways to contribute that don't cost a cent!

  • Share this campaign, or Dance Week 2015 events, with your friends through social media;
  • Talk about Dance Week 2015 with people you like IRL;
  • Visit our website at www.dancenl.ca to learn more about us and this project;
  • Tune in to On The Go on CBC Radio One and nominate a tune for Most Danceable Song;
  • Vote for Most Danceable Song on our website from April 13-21;
  • Dance for a camera and send it in to be part of the Province-wide Boogie;
  • Encourage your local politicians to participate in the Municipal Dance Off;
  • Vote for the best Municipal Dance on our website from April 22-28;
  • Do a Random Act of Dance during the week - bonus points if you get photos or video and let us know!
  • Encourage the school in your neighbourhood to Dare to Dance;
  • Check out promotions available on April 29th and Dance for Discounts;
  • Come out to Traditional Folk Dance Night at the Ship, the Dance Unconference, or NL Moves (disclaimer: two of these things actually do cost some cents… but you will love them!)
  • Follow us on social media! Facebook: DanceNLOnline and Twitter: @danceNLonline

Happy Dancing!

story:
ARIM Dance is a new company founded in 2015 preparing for it's debut/premiere season in 2016 (no set date yet). At this present time, ARIM Dance has a repertoire of 16 ballets which are in the process of being choreographed solely by Ari Mayzick, and a total of 15 dancers, including Ari himself. The company will present more than half of the works in 2 programs in its first NYC season.

ARIM Dance's objectives are to bridge the gap between  "Old School" with today's "Current" giving "Dance" that "Museum Archaic" yet "New", "Modern" feel to it. The works/ballets range from dramatic to lighthearted, from abstract to life's situations and more, while maintaining its movement and artistic integrity. ARIM Dance is setting out to create something that will touch everyone whether it be mentally, emotionally, physically, and/or spiritually.

With the asking amount raised, ARIM Dance will be able to pay for theater rental (for the NYC season), studio rentals (to prepare for the season), costumes, photo shoots for website and marketing purposes, and of course, to pay the dancers for rehearsals and performances.

With the company being so new, all expenses are being paid through the company's Artistic Director teacher/dancer salary which of course, limits the horizons of what the company can create since there are also the costs of everyday life that must be handled with the same salary. Therefore, any and all donations are not only much appreciated but also a necessity to help get ARIM Dance of the ground and take flight to its highest potential. With your help, not only are you supporting the company, you are also becoming apart of the family and with a strong family, just about anything is possible.

We thank you in advance and look forward to sharing our experiences with you through dance and through art.

ARIM Dance

Ari Mayzick - Associate Artistic Director

story:
HELLO FROM DAVID AND ANDREW!

We're DAVID HANBURY and ANDREW RASMUSSEN, the creators behind MRS. SMITH'S BROADWAY CAT-TACULAR!

We're taking the "biggest little Broadway show" OFF BROADWAY this summer for a 10-week run at the famous 47th STREET THEATER, in the heart of Times Square, New York City.

FIRST PREVIEW: JULY 10, OPENING NIGHT: JULY 20

  • MRS. SMITH is the brainchild of DAVID HANBURY, who has performed the character across the country (from Ars Nova, Berkeley Rep, A.R.T., Dixon Place, 54 BELOW and many more), channeling the "rage and grief" she feels over her missing cat, Carlyle. ANDREW RASMUSSEN is co-writer and the Director of the production. Together...we make a dynamic producing duo.
  • Our show takes a razzle-dazzle backstage show biz story and turns it on end. Featuring hit showtunes ("Cabaret", "One Night in Bangkok", and "Don't Rain on My Parade"), live tap dancing, cat puppets, video flashbacks and virtuosic electric guitar shredding. A loving "valentine" to Broadway past and present, the show has had audiences laughing through tears while experiencing comic improv, drama and heartfelt storytelling.
  • Some of our previous critical acclaim includes: 
  • "A DEMENTED CABARET ON ACID! EXPERTLY MERGES COMEDY AND SONG! -CITY PAGES
  •  "OFF IT'S MEDS!"  -BOSTON GLOBE
  • "A SENSATION!"  -LAVENDER MAGAZINE
  • "LARGER THAN LIFE! SHOW STOPPING BALLADS AND SOME SERIOUS SHREDDING ON ELECTRIC GUITAR!"  -PIONEER PRESS

WHAT WE NEED

HOLY PRODUCING, CARLYLE! 
In order for our show to have lights, sound, equipment, scenery, costumes, makeup, wigs, professional actors (under an official Actors Equity Association contract), Broadway Boys, cat puppets and that ever increasing advertising budget...not to mention a publicist, marketing agency and paying for the theater rent, deposits, insurance and kitty litter. 
Thanks to an adventurous team of investors (who are either brilliant or lunatic), we have reached our minimum capitalization to get the production ball rolling. But now WE NEED YOU: our FRIENDS, our FAMILY and LOYAL FANS to help us raise additional capital in order to get the show off the ground! Producing live theater in New York City is extremely expensive and comes with a rollercoaster of ups and downs.
In short: WE NEED YOUR HELP!

THE IMPACT

We've worked our tails off for 3.5 years in productions from Minneapolis, Boston, and New York making ends meet on our little show - and now we're scaling upwards to take MRS. SMITH to a new level. 

  • MRS. SMITH has been performing on the road for over 6+ years, including cabarets, nightclubs, theaters and lower East Side dive bars -- often ranging from full-length plays, music videos and a space rock musical (written by us) for children and hip-minded adults (developed at Berkeley Rep).
  • Taking MRS. SMITH Off-Broadway will help us to bring Smith to a larger audience, develop industry outreach and bring a little bit of indie ingenuity (and guitar shredding) to audiences of all backgrounds. This production is just the tip of the iceberg in the canon of MRS. SMITH projects, platforms and an array of stories and legend.
  • By appearing Off-Broadway, MRS. SMITH will finally be seen by legitimate reviewers, including major New York media (NY Times, Time Out NY, Daily News, Playbill, etc) - and we will be reviewed by the major players.

WHAT YOU GET

We've got some really nice and unique "Thank You" perks to give to you in return for your generous financial support: personally autographed photos, cat mascots, voicemails, show tickets, party invites, private performances and so much more! 

EVERY amount we raise will go directly to the costs of getting MRS. SMITH to OFF-BROADWAY.  You can contribute as much or as little as you're able, and you'll still get your thank you gift.

RISKS & CHALLENGES

We realize the risks involved with any online crowd funding campaign like this. But rest assured, we have also scheduled fund raising events outside of Indiegogo, that will be held live and in person.  Added to these event donations, ANY amount you contribute here will help us with our goal.  Your financial gift WILL NOT go to waste, and you will be a part of musical theater history.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

We understand that some people just can't contribute, but that doesn't mean they can't help!

  • You can SHARE THIS CAMPAIGN with everyone you know on Social Media and more! (Facebook, Twitter, etc.) INDIEGOGO has some VERY easy "share tools" for you to do just that.
  • HELP US PROMOTE our show in a couple of weeks by sharing our show website, viral videos and "liking" Tweets, FB Posts and Ticket links.
  • BUY TICKETS (bring a group, send grandma, a bus load of grandmas) to our show! Tickets on sale June 11th. First performance is July 10.
We'll be THRILLED to see you this summer, no matter what. We've got our team in place and ready to take New York by storm, but we can't do it without you!

story:
Overview

Mission Fusion is an acclaimed after-school dance program based at Jefferson High School in Daly City, California. For four months each year, some 150 middle- and high-school students participate in dance, percussion, and acting workshops led by guest teachers and choreographers. Their efforts culminate in public performances attended by upwards of 1,500 students, parents, and community members. The Mission Fusion program is operated by the Jefferson Union High School District, with partial support from Children’s Empowerment, Inc.

Project Need

Jefferson High School (JHS) in Daly City is rated only 3 (out of 10) on California’s Academic Performance Index (API). The student body is 98% minority (primarily Hispanic and Filipino), and 62% economically disadvantaged. Yet with the help of CEI’s academic programs, the school’s scores on state tests have improved significantly: JHS is now one of the top schools in San Mateo County for qualifying Latino students for university admission, as measured by the percentage of Latino students with four-year graduation and eligibility for admission to the University of California or California State University.

The younger members of Mission Fusion come from Pollicita Middle School, also in Daly City. Its demographics are similar to those of JHS, and the school itself is rated as a Performance Improvement (PI) 5 school, the federal designation for schools with five years of unacceptable progress. In this environment, the Mission Fusion dance program offers students from both schools valuable opportunities for educational enrichment and achievement.

Project Description

Mission Fusion is a gathering of arts and cultures designed to build bridges in the community. Each year’s production has some 25 segments featuring the dances, rhythms, songs, oral histories, and traditions of the cultures represented along Mission Street in Daly City. The main shows at the Jefferson High School Theater have sold out for the last 10 years. The group has also performed at Skyline College in San Bruno, City College of San Francisco, and neighboring high schools and middle schools. The tentative dates for the next show are February 4, 5, and 6, 2016.

Founded in 2000, Mission Fusion is a quality program in an underperforming school, yielding many benefits for its participants. For students from poor families who are interested in the performing arts, Mission Fusion offers the only local option for practicing dance. Students pay nothing to participate; even their costumes are provided free. Mission Fusion offers a positive school experience for underperforming students who may be struggling with their academic subjects because they are visual, aural, or experiential learners. It also builds character as students learn self-discipline, perseverance, time management, and collaboration skills.

Mission Fusion also develops students’ social skills, bridging gaps among young people of different ages, races, and ethnicities. Students break out of their ethnic communities to form friendships with those from other communities and to learn about their traditions and values. This benefit extends to their families. More than half of Daly City’s population was born outside the U.S., and parents working long hours to support their families and speaking limited or no English have few opportunities to learn about the cultures and traditions of their neighbors. Their children’s involvement with Mission Fusion opens a new world for these new U.S. residents.

Please visit www.missionfusion.org for more information about this vibrant program, including videos of past performances.

About CEI

Children’s Empowerment, Inc. (CEI), a 501(c)(3) non-profit corporation, was originally founded in 1999 to support students at Jefferson High School in Daly City who face economic, cultural, and linguistic barriers to their educational success. CEI now offers in-school and after-school programs in four Bay Area counties. An estimated 2,950 unduplicated youth benefit annually from one or more of CEI’s programs.

Our academic programs are still centered at Jefferson High and include California High School Exit Examination (CAHSEE) and Scholastic Aptitude Test (SAT) preparation, plus a multifaceted College Prep program. Our Food Service Program feeds hungry children at more than 100 after-school and summer-recess sites in San Francisco, San Mateo, Alameda, and Contra Costa Counties. We also help support two programs operated by the Jefferson Union High School District: the Mission Fusion dance program for middle-school and high-school students, and the Jefferson Robotics STEM program.

story:
The Story

This show, based on actual interviews with Harriet Tubman in 1868 by local schoolteacher Sarah Bradford, was written specifically for actress-singer Christine Dixon by playwright Morna Murphy, with original songs by Ralph Martell, through a grant from the Staten Island Arts Council in 2008.

In this unique show, Christine, as Harriet, draws the audience right into the action with her. She brings children on stage and “leads” them to freedom; she gets a man and a woman to be her father and mother, then boldly “rescues” them from slavery. In a funny scene, after Harriet escapes to freedom, she returns to the South months later and “scolds” her husband, John Tubman (“played” by an audience member) who has married another woman while she was away.

Many people, after seeing this show, say that Christine made them feel they were actually meeting Harriet Tubman herself.

What We Need

Christine has been performing this show and the production costs for each show range from $350 (at community centers) to $800 (at universities). However, there are many youth centers, schools or churches, located in lower-income areas, that have no budgets to pay for theatrical productions. These are the very places where young people – especially African-American young people – need to be inspired by Harriet Tubman’s story.

We are asking for $7,000 to enable us to donate 10 performances at 10 of these significant venues. The money is needed for expenses that include performance fees to Christine, expenses for traveling, costumes & props, dry cleaning, meetings with venue managers, publicity, printing, flyers, mailings, perks, etc.

List of the Performance Venues

MANHATTAN: Hartley House

BROOKLYN:  P.S. 287 Bailey K Ashford

STATEN ISLAND:  The Goodhue Childrens Aid Society & Faber Park Center

BRONX:  Mt. Hope Green Community Center & PS 55 Benjamin Franklin 

QUEENS:  PS 80 Thurgood Marshall & P.S. 23 Queens Children Center

NEW JERSEY:  Hawthorne Avenue School, Newark & Cedarbrook Elementary School, Plainfield


Why 'HARRIET TUBMAN HERSELF' is Important
Today, in the news, movies, TV, magazines and the internet, African-Americans are too often presented in a very negative light. Many are admired in sports and entertainment, but there is a long line of courageous forerunners that African-American youth should know about. Harriet Tubman is one of them and a wonderful role model. She was a young woman who, in spite of terrible circumstances, accomplished so much that helped better the lives of so many people. She herself said: "I never considered myself a downtrodden slave!"

In HARRIET TUBMAN HERSELF young people of color meet a down-to-earth Harriet who shows that with a true feeling of self-esteem, and self-worth, they can also have the confidence to better their own lives and help make the world around them a better place.

About Christine Dixon

This actress-singer was born and raised in Brooklyn, New York and graduated as a Performing Arts major at Kingsborough Community College. In Film and TV she has worked on Law & Order, The Sopranos, The Manchurian Candidate, School of Rock, Spinning Into Butter, Flight 93, Inside Man and independent films including Descent starring Rosaria Dawson. In Theater, prior to the challenge of portraying the great Harriet Tubman, her favorite roles included Aldonza in The Man of La Mancha, and Titania in Shakespeare’s A Midsummer Night's Dream. She played a police officer in Staten Island Outloud’s production of Rashomon and varied roles in Lawrence Schwabacher’s series of monologues Larry’s Women Speak Out at the Dramatist Guild on Broadway. Christine has performed HARRIET TUBMAN HERSELF throughout the New York area, at schools and colleges. See The Huffington Post article: http://www.huffingtonpost.com/christopher-taylor-/the-woman-who-has-played-_b_6769538.html

About Morna Murphy & Ralph Martell

We are the creative and producing team of HARRIET TUBMAN HERSELF and have long resumes, Morna in the theater as a playwright/director, Ralph in the music business.  When we began writing musicals together, the first was ONLY A WOMAN, about how the Women’s Right’s and Anti-Slavery movements coincided  in America. We lived in Staten Island for 10 years, where we received a grant to write HARRIET TUBMAN HERSELF as well as 5 musicals for children, including SANTA CLAUS IS MISSING, a Christmas show that ran at the Staten Island Children’s Museum for 6 consecutive years. We currently live in Hollywood, California.See our website: https://sites.google.com/site/dramatune

Please Help Us Bring This Inspiring Message to Everybody

We have seen how young people - and adults too - respond to HARRIET TUBMAN HERSELF. We see how they cheer and believe in Harriet Tubman’s dream that everyone can find the courage to stand proud and be free.

At one performance a timid little boy of 8 years old asked Christine, as Harriet, "Were you brave in your dreams?" She reached down and hugged him. "Yes, I always was," she said, "and so can you be! " - a message this young man will carry with him throughout his life.

So, please help us bring this inspiring message to everybody, especially the youth who need to hear it.


What You Get

All Donors will have their Name and Thank You on the HARRIET TUBMAN HERSELF Facebook Page.They will also receive personal items including a postcard, tickets to the show, flyers, a signed photo of Christine and, really large donors will get a personal call from Christine no matter where they are in the world and even a CD with her singing songs from the show. All those who give to our project will also know they have contributed to the continuation of this inspiring work that is bringing an important message to the world.

If we receive more money than our stated goal of $7,000, we will happily use the extra money for presenting the show at many more venues where we know Harriet's life will be an inspiration.

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute, that doesn't mean you can't help:
  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And you will be part of our team.

story:
theNEIGHBORHOOD. is a Hartford based performing & visual arts collective, founded in August 2015. We, theNEIGHBORHOOD., are a group of artists creating, sharing, giving, and presenting collaborative realness. Our mission is to explore new facets of artistic collaboration while inspiring and entertaining audiences of all backgrounds.


theNEIGHBORHOOD. presents: sideshow

A group of Hartford's most brilliant performers and artists, going above and beyond their exceptional talent and technique to create and present art with a twist. Shocking, alluring, and peculiar; sideshow will expose the community to a mix of incredible dancing, music, theater, and visual art – raw talent, performed live. Because we are up-and-coming, we need your help to make it happen! Even a dollar can make a difference. We have a goal to reach of $3,728:

  • Paying artists: $2,550
  • Space: $500
  • Costumes and Props: $500
  • Indiegogo 5% Fee: $178
For news, updates, and more information, you can follow us on Instagram (@theNEIGHBORHOOD.collective) or check out our Facebook page TheNEIGHBORHOOD.

story:
Short Summary

 

                                                                                                     

The National Ballet Institute for the Arts

with the Creative and Performing Arts of South County have been offered a great opportunity to establish a new home in Edgewater, Maryland on MD. Rt. 2 close to MD. Rt. 214.  The NBIA has been providing education in the  art of ballet for over 66 years, training and developing professional dancers and teachers now working in major companies throughout the world.  Many of the ballet teachers in the Washington area are graduates of the National Ballet Institute as are many performing artists seen in our theaters. 

The Creative and Performing Arts of South County (CPASC) is a young non profit that began in March of 2014 to provide opportunities to local artists, musicians and theater groups in the community.  During its first year CPASC has been awarded grants, provided classes in the arts at a variety of venues and performances with NBIA at Catholic University and Historic  London Town Gardens as well as being an active participant at festivals and local events. 

The space in Edgewater will allow NBIA and CPASC to establish a full schedule of classes in all of the arts for children, adults and senior citizens. 

What We Need & What You Get

                                                                                                  

                                       

The National Ballet Institute for the Arts has committed their efforts to raising funds to build the ballet studios, storage for scenery and costumes and to help with the overhead costs of establishing their presence in the community.  Our goal is $40,000 of a $200,000 estimated cost. This is the first step in building a facility which will eventually have a 1000 seat theater for professional and local performing groups, an art gallery, ballet, modern dance and tap studios, art studios and music and drama rehearsal spaces.  NBIA will begin by offering a fully professional ballet program to students ages 5 and up and the National Ballet Company will be in residence providing performances and special events for the community, 
The CPASC has already engaged Art teachers to teach classes in painting, photography, music for children, acting classes with the Annapolis Shakespeare and much more. The Honey Hive, Wimsey Cove Framing & Art, Londontown Symphony Orchestra, Parlor Room Theater and Move and Grove are actively working to make this arts center a reality in the community.
 

The Impact

With your support it can be open by September 1st! With your help in talking to friends, business associates, and local businesses in the community it can be done quickly to provide the tremendous need to the people who love and appreciate the work of our great artists. The Arts Center will raise the cultural impact in South County and make study and work in the arts available to a far reaching area including Calvert County and Prince George's County.

Risks & Challenges

  To be an artist in any of the arts is a challenge in the United States as we are a country that believes business is about making money. Unfortunately artists are not often thought of as a business but as hobbyists by the average individual.  Far too often artists are not appreciated unless they have been able to break through the cracks of business and receive a great deal of publicity from the media.  Money is difficult to acquire but not impossible with the assistance of a great community. 

To be an artist one must take risks everyday to be creative.  This is the life of an artist.  It is the life of all who move forward and upward in the world.  The National Ballet has taken many risks and had numerous challenges in their 66 years.  Leading the way for many to follow in being creative in production and business.   

Other Ways You Can Help

There are many ways to make it happen and you, the art lover, ballet enthusiast and theater goer have the power to do it.  Let everyone you know in the community know about the campaign and encourage them to contribute whatever they can to secure arts education, performance entertainment in our lives for the present and the future generations to enjoy. 

Use the Indiegogo share tools!  Makes it simple to let your friends know how they can help.

story:
LOVE, LOCS & LIBERATION

A Solo Play Written and Performed by Ella Turenne
Produced by Africa Miranda

“To be beautiful does not refer alone to the arrangements of the hair, the perfection of the complexion or to the beauty of form....to be beautiful, one must combine these qualities with a beautiful mind and soul.” - Madam CJ Walker

What is Love, Locs & Liberation?

Using my own journey through storytelling, poetry and song, this solo show will unlock Black women’s hair history, rituals, struggles and triumphs. I play over 10 characters, from Madame CJ Walker to a 5th grade bully to a West Indian hair stylist - all to expose how hair is tied to politics, identity and culture and illustrate why hair is an intimate and essential part of Black life. I ask the question: Is my worth inevitably tied to my hair? This roller coaster ride will have you laughing and crying but most importantly, having a conversation about our identity as women and how we own it. We’re looking to bring this show to LA and NY late this summer.

Who am I?

I’m an actor, writer, poet and producer who has been doing this work for close to two decades. The arts is my passion and I’m bringing it to the stage big time with this show! Some of my acting credits include plays such as Love Child at the Harlem Theatre Company, Working Things Out which premiered at the Downtown Urban Theatre Festival, the short film Big, Dark, Scary Girl and the newly completed feature film Forever Yours. I’ve performed my poetry all over the country including the Black Family Channel show Spoken which was hosted by Jessica Care Moore. Visit my website at www.ellaturenne.com!

Why Love, Locs & Liberation?

In college I wrote a poem called Wooly Metal Hair, my ode to Black hair, it’s trials, tribulations...and celebrations! It was published in 2008. Then in 2009 I was chosen to be part of a HBO’s documentary, The Black List. 


It was the first time I spoke publicly about my hair journey and how it had affected me. Until then, I hadn’t really put all the pieces together, but being on the Black List helped me realized that I had a story to tell. I started talking to other Black women about it and realized it was a story that needed to be shared. This is not just a play. This is a conversation I hope to take worldwide!

My Track Record

Although this is my first solo show, I have produced theatre and film before. My play Gray premiered in the Harlem Heritage Fringe Festival in 2009. I also co-wrote and co-starred in the critically acclaimed webisode series Kindred, which garnered much media attention and was an official selection of the LA Web Fest. My first short film, woodshed, which I directed and produced, had its world premiere at the Hollywood Film Festival. woodshed was also nominated for Best Short in the Montreal International Black Film Festival. I also co-wrote and co-starred in the critically acclaimed webisode series Kindred, which garnered much media attention and was an official selection of the LA Web Fest. Most recently my short film Freedom premiered at the Black Starr Film Fest in Philadelphia and the Haiti Film Fest in NY.

What We Need & What You Get

A portion of the budget for this project is $10,000. I’ve already been on the grind and have raised money from other sources! 100% of the money raised from the Indiegogo Campaign will go towards:

1.  Crew: The director, lighting, set and sounds designers.
2. Venue: A theatrical space to rehearse in and have the show.
3. Design: Set, props, tech., costumes.
4. Multimedia: Videos and music.
5. Photography and Videography.
6. Marketing: How we make sure to get people to come see the show!!

By contributing, you are not only giving financially, you are investing in a vision and a movement! But we also have some nice rewards lined up too...

$25 - Signed DVD copy of my short film Freedom which just premiered at the Haitian Film Fest in April 2015

$50 - Exclusive Digital Download mp3 a poem from the play...performed by me!

$75 - Chapbook of poems of the show which includes a bonus poem by the prolific poet Jessica Care Moore.

$100 - You get to name a character in the show! You can name the character after YOU or pick another name that’s pleasing to your ears.

$250 - One on one consultation with genius Social Impact Strategist JLove Calderon. Are you ready to start your own venture? Have an idea or passion you’ve been wanting to bring to life? JLove can help you make it happen!

$500 - An exclusive Hairnista Session with the one and only Producer extraordinaire of Love, Locs & Liberation Africa Miranda! Chat with Africa about her new ventures, get beauty and fashion tips, and get to know this amazing brand ambassador and TV personality!

$500 - A mounted and signed poster of the art work made by Ella Turenne from the play. I will be creating an original piece of work JUST for this show. And you will get a signed poster of it!

...and more!

The Team

We’ve assembled an amazing team of people to help bring this project to life! They’ve got years of experience and most important - they are all passionate about the project.

Ella Turenne: Writer and Performer
Producer: Africa Miranda
Director: Kathryn Ervin
Stage Manager: Tamiyka White
Production Manager: Maya Morales
Lighting Designer: David Wendell Boykins
Makeup: Koni Guichon
Publicity: Synovia Youngblood

So let’s get it! After you make your pledge, get 10 friends to join the movement by pledging. Let's make history together. Here’s how:

  • Update your Facebook status to tell your friends that you’ve contributed to Love, Locs & Liberation! You’ll have the option of sharing that once you contribute.

  • Inbox your friends directly to get them to contribute. You can send them this link to contribute:

  • Tweet about the project! Use the hashtag #lovelocsliberation.

  • Send your friends a personal email with the direct link to the campaign:

  • Repeat!


Much love,

Ella


Special thanks to Maya Morales and Kyle Scoble for co-producing the campaign! Music courtesy Brown Medius Productions.
story_txt:
LOVE, LOCS & LIBERATION

A Solo Play Written and Performed by Ella TurenneProduced by Africa Miranda
“To be beautiful does not refer alone to the arrangements of the hair, the perfection of the complexion or to the beauty of form....to be beautiful, one must combine these qualities with a beautiful mind and soul.” - Madam CJ Walker
What is Love, Locs & Liberation?
Using my own journey through storytelling, poetry and song, this solo show will unlock Black women’s hair history, rituals, struggles and triumphs. I play over 10 characters, from Madame CJ Walker to a 5th grade bully to a West Indian hair stylist - all to expose how hair is tied to politics, identity and culture and illustrate why hair is an intimate and essential part of Black life. I ask the question: Is my worth inevitably tied to my hair? This roller coaster ride will have you laughing and crying but most importantly, having a conversation about our identity as women and how we own it. We’re looking to bring this show to LA and NY late this summer.



Who am I?I’m an actor, writer, poet and producer who has been doing this work for close to two decades. The arts is my passion and I’m bringing it to the stage big time with this show! Some of my acting credits include plays such as Love Child at the Harlem Theatre Company, Working Things Out which premiered at the Downtown Urban Theatre Festival, the short film Big, Dark, Scary Girl and the newly completed feature film Forever Yours. I’ve performed my poetry all over the country including the Black Family Channel show Spoken which was hosted by Jessica Care Moore. Visit my website at www.ellaturenne.com!   
Why Love, Locs & Liberation?In college I wrote a poem called Wooly Metal Hair, my ode to Black hair, it’s trials, tribulations...and celebrations! It was published in 2008. Then in 2009 I was chosen to be part of a HBO’s documentary, The Black List. It was the first time I spoke publicly about my hair journey and how it had affected me. Until then, I hadn’t really put all the pieces together, but being on the Black List helped me realized that I had a story to tell. I started talking to other Black women about it and realized it was a story that needed to be shared. This is not just a play. This is a conversation I hope to take worldwide!My Track RecordAlthough this is my first solo show, I have produced theatre and film before. My play Gray premiered in the Harlem Heritage Fringe Festival in 2009. I also co-wrote and co-starred in the critically acclaimed webisode series Kindred, which garnered much media attention and was an official selection of the LA Web Fest. My first short film, woodshed, which I directed and produced, had its world premiere at the Hollywood Film Festival. woodshed was also nominated for Best Short in the Montreal International Black Film Festival. I also co-wrote and co-starred in the critically acclaimed webisode series Kindred, which garnered much media attention and was an official selection of the LA Web Fest. Most recently my short film Freedom premiered at the Black Starr Film Fest in Philadelphia and the Haiti Film Fest in NY.What We Need & What You GetA portion of the budget for this project is $10,000. I’ve already been on the grind and have raised money from other sources! 100% of the money raised from the Indiegogo Campaign will go towards:1.  Crew: The director, lighting, set and sounds designers.2. Venue: A theatrical space to rehearse in and have the show.3. Design: Set, props, tech., costumes.4. Multimedia: Videos and music.5. Photography and Videography.6. Marketing: How we make sure to get people to come see the show!!By contributing, you are not only giving financially, you are investing in a vision and a movement! But we also have some nice rewards lined up too...$25 - Signed DVD copy of my short film Freedom which just premiered at the Haitian Film Fest in April 2015$50 - Exclusive Digital Download mp3 a poem from the play...performed by me!$75 - Chapbook of poems of the show which includes a bonus poem by the prolific poet Jessica Care Moore.$100 - You get to name a character in the show! You can name the character after YOU or pick another name that’s pleasing to your ears.$250 - One on one consultation with genius Social Impact Strategist JLove Calderon. Are you ready to start your own venture? Have an idea or passion you’ve been wanting to bring to life? JLove can help you make it happen!$500 - An exclusive Hairnista Session with the one and only Producer extraordinaire of Love, Locs & Liberation Africa Miranda! Chat with Africa about her new ventures, get beauty and fashion tips, and get to know this amazing brand ambassador and TV personality!$500 - A mounted and signed poster of the art work made by Ella Turenne from the play. I will be creating an original piece of work JUST for this show. And you will get a signed poster of it!...and more!The TeamWe’ve assembled an amazing team of people to help bring this project to life! They’ve got years of experience and most important - they are all passionate about the project.Ella Turenne: Writer and PerformerProducer: Africa MirandaDirector: Kathryn ErvinStage Manager: Tamiyka WhiteProduction Manager: Maya MoralesLighting Designer: David Wendell BoykinsMakeup: Koni GuichonPublicity: Synovia YoungbloodSo let’s get it! story:
COME PUOI CONTRIBUIRE:

  1. IN GENERALE:
    SELEZIONANDO (NELLA COLONNA CHE VISUALIZZI A DX) UNA DELLE OPZIONI  A PARTIRE DA 5 EURO - 10 - 25 ECC.

OPPURE:

   2.   SE SEI UN ORGANIZZATORE DI SPETTACOLI RASSEGNE E/O FESTIVAL,(per avviare percorsi di collaborazione /coproduzione/scambio nazionale e  internazionale)
         PUOI INSERIRE LA PRODUZIONE ALL'INTERNO DEL TUO CIRCUITO . 

(for english version scroll down)

  • IL PROGETTO
Il progetto  "La zattera di pietra - La balsa de piedra- Le radeau de pierre", mira a far incontrare le generazioni e a favorire lo scambio e la cooperazione artistica attraverso residenze artistiche, incontri, workshop multidisciplinari e rappresentazione delle opere artistiche prodotte. 

  • sostiene  i giovani artisti indipendenti;
  • crea l'opportunità di residenza creativa, sperimentazione e ricerca nel territorio della Sardegna;
  • incentiva la mobilità e la circuitazione in una vetrina particolare che metta in luce il lavoro coreografico di danzatori, compagnie e coreografi attivi sul territorio regionale nazionale/internazionale ed extra europeo.

  •  "La zattera di pietra - La balsa de piedra- Le radeau de pierre" nasce come  Co- produzione tra tre nazioni: Italia Spagna Francia ed è inserito all'interno del programma di ricerca triennale (2015/2017) dal titolo: "Sulle orme" - Il Mediterraneo, il corpo, il viaggio. Un progetto interdisciplinare di danza musica, teatro e poesia con la direzione artistica di Simonetta Pusceddu e Anthony Mathieu, esso coinvolge artisti, coreografi, danzatori e i rappresentanti dei diversi linguaggi dell'arte performativa.

                                       

  • INFORMAZIONI SU LA COMPAGNIA TERSICOREAT.OFF 
  • la pagina teatro officina delle arti sceniche
    La Tersicorea  garantisce il sostegno alla produzione e mobilitazione di opere coreografiche , premiando l’originalità delle proposte culturali che esprimono una forte testimonianza dell’arte contemporanea nel mondo. L’approccio antropologico, fa sì che gli artisti attraverso un programma condiviso, possano rendere visibile il loro percorso artistico che così “rivive” in un contesto di comparazione e dialogo intergenerazionale.
  • LA RETE NETWORK MED'ARTE
    Dal 2008 si è creata una rete di interscambio internazionale, finalizzata al sostegno  degli artisti contemporanei e indipendenti provenienti  da tutto il mondo, con particolare attenzione agli artisti emergenti  da paesi a  rischio di pace o in cui sono in corso conflitti civili.   Una rete di dialogo tra artisti denominati messaggeri dell'arte nel mondo. Dal 2008 al 2015,  è stata in grado di identificare 80 opere corali provenienti da: Italia, Portogallo, Francia, Spagna, Repubblica Ceca, Costa d'Avorio, Kazan, Scozia, Danimarca, Germania, Egitto, Brasile, Tunisia, Nord Africa e Africa Occidentale, Giappone.
            



  • PERCHÉ È IMPORTANTE LA NOSTRA CAMPAGNA: SOSTENIAMO I GIOVANI  - UN PONTE TRA IL MEDITERRANEO E SPAGNA E FRANCIA

L'OBIETTIVO di raccolta fondi è quello di essere in grado di garantire la realizzazione della 2 ° fase del progetto da ottobre a novembre 2015. Questo periodo di tempo è necessario per l'attuazione di una residenza artistica utile alla realizzazione di un'opera teatrale itinerante. 

  • Il "collettivolabalsa" - ON THE ROAD SPAGNA/FRANCIA/SARDEGNA Il gruppo è composto da danzatori acrobati provenienti da Italia, Spagna e Francia, formatosi alla CAU - Accademia di Circo e Teatro Contemporanea di Granada - Spagna. Viaggiano via terra a bordo di due furgoni con un equipaggio di sei artisti e durante il loro lungo viaggio, rappresentano diversi spettacoli di strada in varie parti del loro itinerario, per finanziare parte del progetto:  "La zattera di pietra - La balsa de piedra- Le radeau de pierre" 

Tersicorea è nella sua prima azione di crowdfunding, attraverso la quale vi chiediamo una quota di € 10.000 per completare il nostro budget. Con il vostro contributo che possiamo coprire una parte dei costi di produzione e di organizzazione relativi per l'ospitalità. Tutti i contributi ricevuti attraverso Indiegogo andranno direttamente alle spese di residenza artistica, parte dei costi relativi ali viaggi e alla permanenza per un mese in Sardegna (vitto e alloggio).

  • L'IMPATTO
    Il vostro contributo costituisce un esempio di grande impegno per la valorizzazione dei processi  trasnazionali culturali di produzione artistica. L'impatto quello di creare nuovi mecenati che garantiscano la mobilità artistica, la collaborazione tra nazioni, l'unione delle culture, Promuovere e salvaguardare la diversità lingusitica e culturale europea; Estendere la promozione e l’identità del paesi coinvolti; Implementare l’ingresso di nuovi percorsi culturali  

  • Grazie per il vostro tempo, la considerazione e il sostegno ai giovani artisti indipendenti.
Fare arte è un rischio e soprattutto i giovani  nel mondo del lavoro artistico. Noi crediamo nel potere di un movimento indipendente composto di persone che collaborano alla divulgazione di processi creativi per l'arte contemporanea nel mondo .


  • Ogni contributo farà la differenza più grande! Se non è possibile donare, potete anche aiutarci raggiungendo un nuovo pubblico condividendo la nostra campagna con qualcuno che sarebbe interessato alla nostra missione attraverso Facebook, Indiegogo e altri social media.


(english version)


  • ABOUT PROJECT

La zattera di pietra - La balsa de piedra- Le radeau de pierre", bring together the generations. It encourage the exchange and cooperation through artistic residencies, meetings, workshops and multidisciplinary  of choreutic artworks.

  • supports the young independent artists;
  • encourages the opportunity to creative residency, experimentation and research in the territory of Sardinia;
  • promotes mobility and circulation in a particular showcase that highlights the choreography of dancers, choreographers and companies active in the region national / international and extra / European.


  • The project  "La zattera di pietra - La balsa de piedra- Le radeau de pierre" began as a Co -production among three countries: Italy /Spain/France and is included within the three-year research program (2015/2017) entitled: "Sulle orme" - the Mediterranean, the body, the journey. An interdisciplinary project of of dance, music, theater and poetry  with the artistic direction of Simonetta Pusceddu and Anthony Mathieu, it involves artists, choreographers, dancers and representatives of the different languages of the performing arts.    




  • ABOUT C.ia TERSICOREAT.OFF
  • officina performing art T.off page
Tersicorea through its projects ,from 2008 to 2015,  has guaranteed support for the production and mobility of different companies  rewarding the originality of cultural proposals that express a strong testimony of contemporary art in the world. The anthropological approach, makes the artists through a shared program, can make visible their artistic path so that "lives" in a context of intergenerational dialogue. 

  • NETWORK MED'ARTE
Since 2008 has generated a network of International interchange supporting contemporary artists from around the world with particular attention to emerging artists from risk of peace countries or in which they are going civil conflict. It takes the form of a network of dialogue among artists, denominated the messengers of art in the world, to implement the territorial extension of the trends and dynamics of artistic creation, within the great cultural fabric of contemporary art - in which young people are the authors / proponents / interpreters. In only eight years it has been able to identify 80 choral works from: Italy, Portugal, France, Spain, Czech Republic, Ivory Coast, Kazan, Scotland, Denmark, Germany, Egypt, Brazil, Tunisia, North Africa and West Africa, Japan.

             



  •   WHY  OUR CAMPAIGN IS IMPORTANT: SUPPORT YOUTH -  A BRIDGE AMONG THE MEDITERRANEAN AND SPAIN AND FRANCE

THE FUNDRAISING goal is to be able to guarantee the realization of the 2nd phase of the project  for  October to November 2015. This period of time is necessary for implementing an artistic residence useful to the realization a traveling theater opera.


  • The "collettivolabalsa":  ON THE ROAD SPAIN /FRANCE/SARDINIA
The group consists of dancers acrobats from Italy, Spain and France, trained at the CAU - Academy of Circus and Contemporary Theater in Granada - Spain. They travel by land aboard two vans with a crew of six artists and during their long journey, representing different street performances in various parts of their itinerary, in order to finance part of the project La balsa de piedra.

          

Tersicorea is in his first action of crowdfunding, through which we aim to collect a share of € 10.000 to supplement our budget. With your contribution we can cover part of the costs of production and organization related for hospitality. All contributions received through Indiegogo will go directly to the costs of rehearsing, part of the costs related  to travel and accommodation and meals for a month in Sardinia.

  • The impact
    Your contribution is an example of hard work for the promotion of transnational cultural processes of artistic production. The impact to create new patrons to ensure artistic mobility, collaboration between nations, the union of cultures, promote and safeguard the European cultural diversity; Extend the promotion and the identity of the countries involved; Implement the entry of new cultural itineraries.

  • Thank you for your time, consideration and support to the youth independent artists.
    Making art is a risk. Young people are at risk in the world of artistic work, but we believe in the power of an independent movement made up of people who cooperate on disclosure of creative processes for contemporary art in the world.

Each contribution will make the biggest difference! If you can not donate, you can still help us reach a new audience, Spread the word by sharing our campaign with someone who would be interested in our mission through Facebook, Indiegogo and other social media.

The impact to create new patrons to ensure artistic mobility, collaboration between nations, the union of cultures, promote and safeguard the European cultural diversity; Extend the promotion and the identity of the countries involved; Implement the entry of new cultural itineraries.



Thank you for your time, consideration and support to the youth independent artists.
Making art is a risk. Young people are at risk in the world of artistic work, but we believe in the power of an independent movement made up of people who cooperate on disclosure of creative processes for contemporary art in the world.



Each contribution will make the biggest difference! If you can not donate, you can still help us reach a new audience, Spread the word by sharing our campaign with someone who would be interested in our mission through Facebook, Indiegogo and other social media.

story:
Shrapnel is an edgy new theatre company created by an ambitious group of North Louisiana-based film/stage veterans and up-and-coming actors. Our motto is: "good art is like shrapnel, it stays with you!"

Our project consists of seven (7) performances of Sharr White's award-winning play “The Other Place” to be staged in the Engine Room Theatre of The Shreveport Regional Arts Council . Performances are still being decided upon but will be taking place in spring of 2016.

The plot is as follows: lead character Dr. Juliana Smithton is a successful neurologist whose life seems to be coming unhinged. Her husband has filed for divorce, her daughter has eloped with a much older man and her own health is in jeopardy. But, of course, nothing is as it seems. Piece by piece, a mystery unfolds as fact blurs with fiction, past collides with present, and the elusive truth about Juliana boils to the surface with a surprising ending that forces her to confront her greatest fear.

"The Other Place" premiered Off-Broadway, and was an Outer Critics Circle Award nominee for Outstanding New Off-Broadway Play. This will be its Louisiana premiere.


Like other thought-provoking plays Shrapnel will produce, “The Other Place” addresses serious - and sometimes uncomfortable - issues. Our company's mission is to use theatre as a medium to acknowledge societal issues, and work within our community to address them.  This inaugural production will pave the way for Shrapnel Stage Company to bring other thought-provoking, nontraditional performances to Shreveport/Bossier. 

Our cast is comprised of some of this area's finest actors: Jennifer Bush, Mat Latz, Gordon Christy, and Christi Saunders Fortson. Other Shrapnel members will work backstage, in the box office, and on our media campaign.


In addition, Shrapnel is one of the few local theatre companies that will compensate its actors!  By paying local artists for their hard work, we hope to raise the bar for all regional performance arts groups, and contribute to Northwest Louisiana's cultural and economic well-being.


100% of your contribution will be invested in:

  • purchasing performance rights to the play
  • compensating our technical director
  • buying supplies for set construction
  • printing and advertising costs.

    All ticket sales will be dedicated to paying our actors, and securing and presenting our next ground-breaking production. 

We cannot stage this important play without your help! 

Support local theatre by becoming a proud sponsor of Shrapnel Stage Company today!
