story:
UN MEDECIN. Arrive un soir... je suis sorti enfin... je suis sorti pour souffler un peu. J’étais aux Urgences donc... et je vois arriver une dame âgée. Elle arrive sous le hall des Urgences... au 1er sous- sol, et je lui dis : « Je peux quelque chose pour vous ? ». Je sais pas quelle heure il était... 23h... quelque chose comme ça... : « Vous êtes... vous êtes malade ? Vous avez mal quelque part ? », « Ah non... », bah je lui dis : « Alors... mais pourquoi vous venez à l’hôpital ? », « Parce que c’est le seul endroit où y a de la chaleur et de la lumière ».

Le projet est né avant tout de la rencontre de différentes personnes, côtoyant l’hôpital chacune à leur manière (patients, aides-soignants, infirmiers, médecins, agents de ménage, diététiciens, psychologues, étudiants, aumônière, prêtre, familles, proches et associations de patients, techniciens, personnel administratif... ). Nous avons eu la chance de pouvoir passer du temps dans différents services du CHU de Limoges, et d'y entendre des récits très variés. La pièce a été écrite à partir de ces témoignages. Un certain nombre de réflexions en sont sorties, autour de cette relation à la fois étrange et caractéristique, de dépendance, qui peut exister entre le patient et le soignant. Réflexions sur la question de la réduction du personnel, sur le travail en équipe et ses problèmes hiérarchiques, administratifs, relationnels, sur le sens profond du métier de soin et les raisons multiples qui poussent à vouloir faire ce choix, sur la coexistence au sein de l’hôpital de populations très variées mais confrontées ici à un même besoin, sur la formation que suivent aujourd’hui les futurs soignants et et la façon dont ils sont parfois « conditionnés » à exercer leur métier d’une manière pas toujours adéquate aux attentes et aux besoins ressentis par les patients, enfin, sur la machine institutionnelle française dont l’hôpital lui-même a parfois du mal à s’extirper.

UNE DIETETICIENNE DE L’HOPITAL - « C’est qu’on se heurte à pleins de problèmes hein. C’est un mastodonte ici, quand vous voulez quelque chose, il faut plusieurs mois, avant de l’obtenir. Parce qu’on vous répond pas, on vous dit : « peut-être », on vous dit : « ah bah non... », alors le temps que vous ayez passé toutes les strates, parce qu’y a 50 personnes, et puis alors je vous dis pas, si vous en oubliez une alors là, c’est la catastrophe hein ! »

Au fil de notre recherche, l’hôpital s’est avéré être une sorte de microcosme de notre société, où les individus qui le composent sont confrontés aux mêmes problématiques qu’on peut retrouver ailleurs, même lorsqu’il s’agit des métiers du soin – où la priorité est mise à la rentabilité et où les directeurs d’hôpitaux sont de plus en plus souvent dans la culture de l’économie financière... Dans un monde où l’on a plutôt tendance aujourd’hui à développer des robots pour combler l’ennui des patients atteints de la maladie d’Alzheimer, plutôt que d’ajouter du personnel soignant, quelle place reste-t-il encore pour l’humain, quand on sait pourtant aujourd’hui l’importante part du psychisme dans le processus de guérison d’une maladie ? Comment concilier le respect de d’objectifs ministériels et de consignes budgétaires, avec la prise en compte du bien-être des patients ?

 

Qui sommes-nous ?

La compagnie Hors Jeu :

« Le jeu suppose certes la volonté de gagner, en utilisant au mieux ses ressources et en s'interdisant les coups prohibés. Mais il exige davantage : il faut enchérir de courtoisie sur l'adversaire, lui faire confiance par principe et le combattre sans animosité. Il faut encore accepter d'avance l'échec éventuel, la malchance ou la fatalité, consentir à la défaite sans colère ni désespoir. Qui se fâche ou se plaint se discrédite. En effet, là où toute nouvelle partie apparaît comme un commencement absolu, rien n'est perdu et le joueur, plutôt que de récriminer ou de se découvrir, a lieu de redoubler son effort. »

Roger Caillois, Des jeux et des hommes

Nous sommes 5 comédiens récemment sortis de l'Académie Théâtrale du Limousin, et une comédienne québécoise rencontrée sur la route. 

Relevé de la parole : Sophie Lewisch et Antoine Guyomarc'h 

Mise en texte : Sophie Lewisch  

Dramaturgie : Guillaume Hasson  

Mise en scène : Sophie Lewisch et Antoine Guyomarc'h  

Avec : Hélène Bertrand, Antoine Guyomarc’h, Sophie Lewisch, Raphaël Ména, Charles Pommel, Julie Lalande  

Création sonore : Nourel Boucherk

Création lumière : Jérôme Léger

Régie son : Thierry Bossot

Régie lumière : Mary Corcuff

Scénographie : Alain Pinochet, Tristan Gros et Didier Chipan

Captation vidéo : Frédéric Coiffe

Création vidéo : Jean-Michel Périllier

 

Durée du spectacle : 1h30

 

A quoi nous servira la collecte ?

La collecte nous servira à jouer 2 représentations du spectacle, le 29 mai 2017, à l'Anis Gras à Arcueil, à 14h30 et 19h30, et grâce à cela organiser ensuite la tournée dans les hôpitaux et théâtres de France.

Pour cela, nous avons besoin d'acheter le décor du spectacle, les costumes, le matériel vidéo et à payer les frais de déplacement et d’hébergement de l’équipe, dont les artistes ne vivent pas tous dans la même ville.

- Achats du décor : 900 euros

- Achats des costumes : 380 euros

- Matériel vidéo : 1450 euros

- Défraiement et hébergement de l'équipe : 1000 euros

- Commission Indiegogo : 227 euros

 

Total : 3957 euros

 

Si la somme dépassait le montant de la collecte, cela nous permettrait de travailler également sur une version plus souple de la pièce, qui serait plus facilement jouée dans les hôpitaux.
story_txt: UN MEDECIN. Arrive un soir... je suis sorti enfin... je suis sorti pour souffler un peu. J’étais aux Urgences donc... et je vois arriver une dame âgée. Elle arrive sous le hall des Urgences... au 1er sous- sol, et je lui dis : « Je peux quelque chose pour vous ? ». Je sais pas quelle heure il était... 23h... quelque chose comme ça... : « Vous êtes... vous êtes malade ? Vous avez mal quelque part ? », « Ah non... », bah je lui dis : « Alors... mais pourquoi vous venez à l’hôpital ? », « Parce que c’est le seul endroit où y a de la chaleur et de la lumière ». Le projet est né avant tout de la rencontre de différentes personnes, côtoyant l’hôpital chacune à leur manière (patients, aides-soignants, infirmiers, médecins, agents de ménage, diététiciens, psychologues, étudiants, aumônière, prêtre, familles, proches et associations de patients, techniciens, personnel administratif... ). Nous avons eu la chance de pouvoir passer du temps dans différents services du CHU de Limoges, et d'y entendre des récits très variés. La pièce a été écrite à partir de ces témoignages. Un certain nombre de réflexions en sont sorties, autour de cette relation à la fois étrange et caractéristique, de dépendance, qui peut exister entre le patient et le soignant. Réflexions sur la question de la réduction du personnel, sur le travail en équipe et ses problèmes hiérarchiques, administratifs, relationnels, sur le sens profond du métier de soin et les raisons multiples qui poussent à vouloir faire ce choix, sur la coexistence au sein de l’hôpital de populations très variées mais confrontées ici à un même besoin, sur la formation que suivent aujourd’hui les futurs soignants et et la façon dont ils sont parfois « conditionnés » à exercer leur métier d’une manière pas toujours adéquate aux attentes et aux besoins ressentis par les patients, enfin, sur la machine institutionnelle française dont l’hôpital lui-même a parfois du mal à s’extirper.UNE DIETETICIENNE DE L’HOPITAL - « C’est qu’on se heurte à pleins de problèmes hein. C’est un mastodonte ici, quand vous voulez quelque chose, il faut plusieurs mois, avant de l’obtenir. Parce qu’on vous répond pas, on vous dit : « peut-être », on vous dit : « ah bah non... », alors le temps que vous ayez passé toutes les strates, parce qu’y a 50 personnes, et puis alors je vous dis pas, si vous en oubliez une alors là, c’est la catastrophe hein ! »Au fil de notre recherche, l’hôpital s’est avéré être une sorte de microcosme de notre société, où les individus qui le composent sont confrontés aux mêmes problématiques qu’on peut retrouver ailleurs, même lorsqu’il s’agit des métiers du soin – où la priorité est mise à la rentabilité et où les directeurs d’hôpitaux sont de plus en plus souvent dans la culture de l’économie financière... Dans un monde où l’on a plutôt tendance aujourd’hui à développer des robots pour combler l’ennui des patients atteints de la maladie d’Alzheimer, plutôt que d’ajouter du personnel soignant, quelle place reste-t-il encore pour l’humain, quand on sait pourtant aujourd’hui l’importante part du psychisme dans le processus de guérison d’une maladie ? Comment concilier le respect de d’objectifs ministériels et de consignes budgétaires, avec la prise en compte du bien-être des patients ? Qui sommes-nous ?La compagnie Hors Jeu :« Le jeu suppose certes la volonté de gagner, en utilisant au mieux ses ressources et en s'interdisant les coups prohibés. Mais il exige davantage : il faut enchérir de courtoisie sur l'adversaire, lui faire confiance par principe et le combattre sans animosité. Il faut encore accepter d'avance l'échec éventuel, la malchance ou la fatalité, consentir à la défaite sans colère ni désespoir. Qui se fâche ou se plaint se discrédite. En effet, là où toute nouvelle partie apparaît comme un commencement absolu, rien n'est perdu et le joueur, plutôt que de récriminer ou de se découvrir, a lieu de redoubler son effort. » Roger Caillois, Des jeux et des hommesNous sommes 5 comédiens récemment sortis de l'Académie Théâtrale du Limousin, et une comédienne québécoise rencontrée sur la route. Relevé de la parole : Sophie Lewisch et Antoine Guyomarc'h Mise en texte : Sophie Lewisch  Dramaturgie : Guillaume Hasson  Mise en scène : Sophie Lewisch et Antoine Guyomarc'h  Avec : Hélène Bertrand, Antoine Guyomarc’h, Sophie Lewisch, Raphaël Ména, Charles Pommel, Julie Lalande  Création sonore : Nourel BoucherkCréation lumière : Jérôme LégerRégie son : Thierry BossotRégie lumière : Mary CorcuffScénographie : Alain Pinochet, Tristan Gros et Didier ChipanCaptation vidéo : Frédéric CoiffeCréation vidéo : Jean-Michel Périllier Durée du spectacle : 1h30 A quoi nous servira la collecte ?La collecte nous servira à jouer 2 représentations du spectacle, le 29 mai 2017, à l'Anis Gras à Arcueil, à 14h30 et 19h30, et grâce à cela organiser ensuite la tournée dans les hôpitaux et théâtres de France.Pour cela, nous avons besoin d'acheter le décor du spectacle, les costumes, le matériel vidéo et à payer les frais de déplacement et d’hébergement de l’équipe, dont les artistes ne vivent pas tous dans la même ville.- Achats du décor : 900 euros- Achats des costumes : 380 euros- Matériel vidéo : 1450 euros- Défraiement et hébergement de l'équipe : 1000 euros- Commission Indiegogo : 227 euros Total : 3957 euros Si la somme dépassait le montant de la collecte, cela nous permettrait de travailler également sur une version plus souple de la pièce, qui serait plus facilement jouée dans les hôpitaux.

story:
At many points during the past 12 months, we have watched families dissolve into senseless arguments; we have watched our country dissolve into fear, frenzied finger-pointing, and blame. We have seen walls go up where before there was the terrain of shared history.  Regardless of affiliation, we have seen some of the ugliest aspects of America emerge into the daylight from their dormant resting place.

At its core, Shadow Tender is our response to the growing trend of dehumanization and demonization across many spheres - political, social, and environmental. This profound desire to create an “other” - to create an enemy on which to project all of one’s hatred - extends beyond the containers of culture, language, or geography. On a macro level, this turns into radical nationalism...on a much more intimate, individual level, it is an ongoing battle with personal shame, fear, anger, and vulnerability.

News networks swamped with pitched arguments rather than factual reporting, self-congratulatory unfriendings on social media, and tense facades of normalcy at family gatherings all reveal the limitations of verbal dialogue in relation to these topics.  Shadow Tender has grown from a desire to see how our skills as artists, movers, performers, and designers can offer alternative ways to enter the conversation. The Shadow Tender project is so much more than a single performance - it is also an ongoing dialogue with ourselves and our communities that seeks to broaden our notions of what it means to be human; what it means to bridge the gap between “us” and “them.” Our goal is to create both a performance and a teaching methodology that uses mask-making, conversation, and movement to provide our communities with tools for communicating with and learning from their own Shadows, ultimately allowing us to confront things that have been abandoned and pushed away on both personal and societal levels.

Your contribution to the Shadow Tender project on any level helps us encourage much-needed dialogue around topics of conflict, trauma, shame, identity, anger, and bias that bypass regular ego-defenses around power/lessness, fragility, and privilege and allow people to see each other as mutually human.

 

Shadow Tender is a performance project that combines physical theatre and wearable sculpture to externalize the parts of ourselves we fear and repress in order to engage a dialogue and promote individual and social healing.

Carl Jung described the Shadow as the aspect of the psyche in which we store those parts of ourselves that we do not wish to acknowledge - things that make us feel ashamed, frightened, weak, or powerless. In rejecting our own Shadows, we unconsciously project them onto others, creating monsters and enemies that are more revealing of our own darkness than anything else.

Shadow Tender is both a performance and a teaching methodology focusing on how we construct, project, and can compassionately confront and transmute the monstrous within ourselves and society. Jung identified Shadow projection as one of the roots of discrimination against marginalized communities. The political and socio-ecological events of the past year in the US and abroad have made it evident that there is a profound need for dialogue with the personal and collective Shadow self, inciting a sense of urgency for the creation of Shadow Tender.

Shadow Tender features a team of talented performers/artists from diverse cultural and movement backgrounds, ranging from ballet, butoh, and modern dance to circus and martial arts.  We’ll be utilizing awesome tools such as biofeedback technology, masks, and prosthetics to create a sense of wonder and transformation. 

Using our personal stories as conduits and reflections of a larger experience, Shadow Tender looks beyond our egos' defenses to ask these questions: Who is the monster, here? How do we create the monstrous? How does it create us? What lies beyond the fear?

 


We have been invited to perform Shadow Tender and teach a workshop at the 2017 World Stage Design festival to be held at Taipei National University of the Arts this coming July.

World Stage Design is one of the largest international performance design festivals in the world and provides an exciting cross-section of work from the realms of theater, dance, installation, site-specific events, and entertainment. 

Due to the highly international nature of WSD - over 36 countries will be represented - there is also a strong emphasis on building global community, cultural exchange, and fostering dialogue that expands and challenges existing definitions of the performing arts.

Your contributions go directly towards allowing us to finalize our costumes and choreography for Shadow Tender and getting us to Taiwan to represent the US at this incredible event.

 

We are asking for a total sum of $11,000. This money will go towards covering round-trip travel costs to Taiwan, materials for costumes, wearable biofeedback technology, marketing/video production, and of course, compensating the artists for their time. So far, we have covered most of the expenses out-of-pocket, but our vision for the project exceeds our current resources.

Here is the exact breakdown of our projected costs (with a graph - who doesn’t love graphs?)

Round-trip airfare to Taiwan for three performers: $ 3,600
Costumes & biofeedback technology: $1,500
Video production: $1,500
Marketing: $450
Compensation for artists: $ 3,000
Studio space rental: $950
 

We are offering tons of exciting perks to our contributors - digital, physical, and other. Many of them will allow you to join us as we move forward with this project. From sneak-peeks into our process and research archives, to original concept art, to custom-made masks and adornments, we have a plethora of amazing awards for you to choose from, with some surprises lined up for after the launch of the campaign!


We understand that flex-funding is always a risk - what if we aren’t able to meet our budget goals? Each and every member of our creative team has made major changes in our lives to take on this project and to see it through. Very simply put, we believe in this work, and we believe that it is necessary now. Thus, regardless of how much money we are able to raise, we will continue moving forward with Shadow Tender in whatever way we can. Below is a breakdown of what will happen based on the amount we are able to raise through this campaign.

$3,000: We will premiere a bare-bones version of Shadow Tender in Portland, Oregon in July 2017 and hold a Q & A session afterwards for our audience.

$5,000: We will premiere a fully robust version Shadow Tender in Portland, Oregon in July 2017 as well as hold a workshop for our local community.

$7,000: We will be able to present a simplified version of Shadow Tender and teach a workshop at WSD 2017!

$11,000: We will be able to present the full version of Shadow Tender and teach a workshop at WSD 2017!

 

We are a bi-coastal creative team of artists, movers, and educators. We each have a strong track-record of leadership, responsibility, and professional success in our areas of expertise. 

Natalya, Aurelia, and Maria have collaborated in the past as the Anatomia Dance Collective - an internationally award-winning performance project whose designs have been featured in multiple exhibitions and venues throughout the world, including the A. A. Bakhrushin Theatre Museum in Moscow, the Chinese Institute of Stage Design in Beijing, and the Royal Welsh College of Music & Drama, Cardiff.

We are thrilled to be joined by Magda, Sophia, and Adam for Shadow Tender - come meet our full team below!


Natalya's online portfolio can be found here. Please follow her current projects on Instagram!

Maria's online portfolio can be found here. Please follow her current projects on Instagram!

Please visit Magda's website here. Follow her current projects on Instagram!

Visit Intuitive Compass -- Aurelia's musical project -- here. 

Please see Sophia's online portfolio here. Follow along on Instagram for more!

Please see Adam's portfolio here, and check out his Soundcloud here.

 

Please help us spread the word about this project and continue to check in with us over the course of campaign. We cannot wait to share Shadow Tender with our audiences!

We firmly believe in the power of this work, and in the relevance of the Shadow to the events unfolding all around us on a daily basis. We are deeply grateful to everyone who has taken time to learn about the concepts behind this project - our ultimate goal is to inspire a deeper understanding of internal and interpersonal conflict and to prompt dialogue around difficult topics that will provide new tools for conflict resolution. Just your willingness to read this far is already making this project a success - thank you.

If you aren’t able to contribute financially, there are still a ton of other ways you can be involved:

SHARE this project with your friends on social media and beyond - feel free to tag us as #shadowtender as you share! 

START A CONVERSATION about what the “monstrous” means to you/your community - and why.

GET IN TOUCH with us! We would love to hear your feedback, ideas, and reflections on this work.

 

We are open to various forms of support and potential collaboration in this work. If you would like to be involved or contribute to the project outside of the scope of this campaign, please email natalya[dot]kolosowsky[at]gmail[dot]com.

--------

The Shadow Tender team would like to extend an enormous thank you to Headwaters Theatre and Potoo Media in Portland, Oregon for their generous support of our work, especially in preparation for this campaign! Photography featured in this campaign is by Richard McConochie and Shane Phillips.

story:
Help Stop High School Bullying! 

"Lines in the Sand" a new play written by Jim Dalglish and directed by Jim Dalglish and Ian Ryan has been chosen as an official selection for this year's International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival. The play, which will have its world premiere at Cotuit Center for the Arts from March 9 - 26, 2017, is hard-hitting contemporary drama about an important topic - high school bullying of LGBT teens.  

Here are some disturbing facts:

  • 9 out of 10 LGBT teens report being bullied at school because of their sexual orientation or gender
  • 1/3 of the schools did nothing to help them 
  • More than a 1/4 of those student end up dropping out of school 
  • Gay, lesbian, and transgender teens are 3x more likely to commit suicide than other youths

"Lines in the Sand" is an important play that gives voice to the issue of violence and intimidation directed at our LGBT youth. 

We Need Your Help

We hope to send the play to Dublin and perform it in the festival May 8 - 14, 2017. But first we have to raise the money.  In order to spread the word about this important topic and share the play with the people of Ireland, we need your help.
Our projected expenses:

  • We need to raise $12,000.00 to get the cast and crew to Ireland and back 
  • Airfare will cost about $4,000.00 
  • We anticipate lodging for 12 days will cost at least $5,000.00
  • We are projecting incidental costs - shipping, rentals, stipends, daily expenses - to run about $3,000.00

About Cotuit Center for the Arts 

CCftA is the leading non-profit performing arts venue on Cape Cod. A vital part of the Massachusetts community for decades, the center sees art as an essential aspect of life. CCftA's mission is to be a welcoming hub for Cape Cod’s artists, performers, students, and audiences, working together to make the creation and experience of art accessible, nurturing, and thrilling to all.

About the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival 

Founded in 2004, the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival creates new opportunities for visibility and affirmation for existing and emerging gay artists and theatrical works. The Festival’s criteria for inclusion into the programme are broadly interpreted to include works by gay writers, works that have a gay relevance or theme, or works that include either performance or another artistic contribution by gay people.

It's a Long Road to Dublin - But We Know the Way

Getting everyone and everything we need to launch this production in Dublin may look a little daunting. Thank heavens people on the team have already had experiences sending prior productions to this wonderful festival. We know the ins and outs of the festival and we have experience with booking flights and securing lodging. In fact a play co-written by Lynda Sturner and Jim Dalglish (the author of "Lines in the Sand") won an award at last year's festival. Lynda won an "Oscar" for her performance in the play.

Other Ways You Can Help

We will accept any contribution you can make, of course.  But we know that it may be challenging for some people to donate money.
Here are some other ways you can help:

  • Share this campaign on social media - Indiegogo has the tools you will need to share it 
  • Come and see the CCftA production - March 9 - 26, 2017

Thanks!

Thanks so much for your time and attention. We hope that with our play we will be able to spread the word about the important topic.

About the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival 
Founded in 2004, the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival creates new opportunities for visibility and affirmation for existing and emerging gay artists and theatrical works. The Festival’s criteria for inclusion into the programme are broadly interpreted to include works by gay writers, works that have a gay relevance or theme, or works that include either performance or another artistic contribution by gay people.

It's a Long Road to Dublin - But We Know the Way
Getting everyone and everything we need to launch this production in Dublin may look a little daunting. Thank heavens people on the team have already had experiences sending prior productions to this wonderful festival. We know the ins and outs of the festival and we have experience with booking flights and securing lodging. In fact a play co-written by Lynda Sturner and Jim Dalglish (the author of "Lines in the Sand") won an award at last year's festival. Lynda won an "Oscar" for her performance in the play.

Other Ways You Can Help
We will accept any contribution you can make, of course.  But we know that it may be challenging for some people to donate money.Here are some other ways you can help:

Share this campaign on social media - Indiegogo has the tools you will need to share it 
Come and see the CCftA production - March 9 - 26, 2017

Thanks!
Thanks so much for your time and attention. We hope that with our play we will be able to spread the word about the important topic.
campaign_city: Cotuit Center for the Arts, United States

story:
At its core, Maligrad Contemporary Dance Company is about community, collaboration, artistic research, and investigation. The company began in 2014 in Croatia and has since established roots in San Francisco. While we cherish the community we call home and find constant inspiration from the artists we share space with, we find it essential to broaden our knowledge, experience, and sensitivity to the world through cross-cultural exchange. 

With dance as our medium and an educational mindset at the forefront, Maligrad will be embarking on a European tour in May and June of 2017 to perform our most recent works, teach, and reconnect with our roots as a contemporary dance company founded in the EU.

Maligrad has been invited to perform and lead workshops with the students at the Accademia dell'Arte in Arezzo Italy. We will spend a week at the University and within the town engaging with the students and faculty and performing our most recent evening-length work, “Archival”. In addition, we will be performing a new site-specific work, “Ping-Pong State of Mind”, intended to bring interactions and cross-cultural exchanges to the viewer. This same site-specific work will be performed in Amsterdam with the potential of other tour stops, all with video documentation allowing for reflection and engagement post-tour. Lastly, Artistic Director Molly Fletcher Lynch-Seaver will be traveling to Villennes Sur Seine, France, where she will be performing, teaching and setting new work on students there. 

We feel that this tour is both culturally timely and necessary for us as educators and artists to continue to impact the community we engage with as performing artists. Maligrad is continuing to grow and develop, but financial support enables us to go further than we are otherwise able. Individual funding to this tour will not only make it a reality, it will enable the mission to grow and expand to other locations.

All funds will directly support and enable the following:

-Travel costs

-Artist fees

-Documentation (photography, videography)

-Marketing 

-Technical support 

-Administrative support

Maligrad, Croatian for "small town",  stands for a living, breathing entity. An artistic entity that is influenced by the environment, each other and has an acute sensitivity to the cause and effect potential we have as people, and as artists. We are grateful for this opportunity to share our work, and look forward to sharing what we absorb through artistic research and cross-cultural exchange. Thank you for your time and consideration. We are so grateful for your support.

-Maligrad Contemporary Dance Company 

http://maligrad.org/

story:
UPDATE- NOW PART OF THE CAMDEN FRINGE FESTIVAL
MACBETH 360 will be exhibited at The Cockpit on August 1st. 

 

MACBETH 360 is all about generating an experience influenced by early video games, with the audience member sitting in place of Macbeth himself. In this way we create a first person connection and involvement with the context of the play.

More than just the violence and intensity of Shakespeare’s words, MACBETH 360 is going to be an intense immersive Sci-Fi experience, mostly influenced by Cyberpunk and BDSM fashion. The choice to adapt Macbeth’s witches’ ritual scenes within a 360 format comes from an interest in the current issues with an aggressive flux of information, and how this damages our capacity to be empathetic.What is empathy? How can one provoke it through immersive performance? And with this in mind, how can one use new technologies to support and explore the previous question?

We have already constructed and filmed the performative elements of the piece, now we just need to animate it and bring it to life!

Once animation has been completed we will then be exhibiting MACBETH 360 as an installation along side the 360 experience, placing the audience member in a real life setting which is an extension of the virtual one.

What we need:

We are aiming for a sum of £1400 in order to continue on with our project and cover the costs already spent. We have been working with the amazing BoxHead VR who have donated their time and equipment, so our overhead costs have been minimised hugely.
 

What the money is going towards:

Animator - £300
We are looking to hire an animation student from the university who will be working on the piece for approximately one week. Keeping the project predominantly between students is something that we are very interested in, and obviously helps massively cost wise, but we are tired of artists being expected to work for free!

Materials- £600
The set up for what has already been filmed came to £300 for set build and costume (metal, green screen materials, costume materials etc), in order to create the installation for the performance we will need a further £300 (to be spent on yes, more metal)

Transport- £200
To keep costs low we have been sourcing metal and other materials from scrap yards which has been great, but then we've had to get them back to our studio, and bus drivers aren't very happy to let on huge pieces of scrap, so we've had to hire transit vans, and will continue to need to do so.

Books- £300
With the installation we are designing a book to be viewed with it which describes the experience and its process of creation. As this project is also for our degree show, we are aiming to manufacture copies for most of our team members to be able to present at our final review (which then decides on our overall grade) to concisely represent the experience.

 

Some people are unable to donate, and we understand that, if you have an interest in the project but are unable to contribute financially, you can still help! Please share the campaign with others that you think may be interested and help us continue our project!

story:
Chloe here- the writer and co-producer of The Woman Who Shed Her Skin, a hybrid theatrical production. This project started life as a poem, a cathartic expression of personal growth and a message to women; a dialogue between a woman’s relish in her exterior beauty and her interior desire to be heard as an individual.  Named Corinne, the central character was a woman in dire flux.  Over time, with the addition of  Noel MacDuffie as director and co-producer,  the piece evolved into a stylized theatrical exploration fusing mixed media with live performance, a projected version of her character that comes with its own infomercial and pop song, a live dancer, a live Voice over and a live Cellist!  

 

We premiered the show at Dixon place on February 25th this year. After an over sold opening show and exceedingly positive feedback we were invited to present the piece the following week at HERE Arts Center. So far the next part of the journey is to take the project across the pond to the UK where we have been accepted to participate in the Brighton Fringe festival.

 

WHAT WE NEED! Our goal is to raise $10k in the next two months to cover the costs of this trip. We need to provide travel, accommodation, rehearsal space, food/living costs for five performers, the director, and the technical/projection master. As well as covering production costs including maintaining costumes, props and set, storage, transportation, publicity and insurance. Over half of our total projected budget will go towards travel (flights and ground transport) for the team. We will use roughly $2000 for production costs. $1750 will be divided up into a small per diem per individual. $1000 will also be used to house the company for the week.

WHAT YOU GET! We are excited to partner with some talented artists who are creating original artwork based on the motif of Shedding Skin. Each person who donates to our campaign no matter the amount will receive a postcard with original artwork designed by one of our chosen artists. As the donation amount goes up, so do the gifts you receive

story:
John Kahara as the Cardinal.


Webster was much possessed by death

And saw the skull beneath the skin;

And breastless creatures under ground

Leaned backward with a lipless grin.


Daffodil bulbs instead of balls

Stared from sockets of the eyes!

He knew that thought clings round dead limbs

Tightening its lusts and luxuries


                                           T.S. Eliot- Whispers of Immortality

 

 HISTORY

I have wanted to direct this play since I fist encountered it 15 years ago.  It is a very special project for me, one that is a culmination of everything that I want in theatre; an excellent cast, wonderful collaborators, and a bold, award winning, theatre company.  I have been searching for the right group for John Webster's play, and this is it.   So if you have followed my work, and have liked my previous shows, this production is the result of years of work and planning.  I want this show to be a celebration of theatricality and Webster's brilliant writing.

We are ready; and by investing in us, you are supporting a truly special theatre piece and group of people.

WHY FUND US

I want to be able to give my designers the funds necessary to let their imagination run wild.  The original music will need time in the studio, and time for development in rehearsal.  It is a show steeped in blood, and we need resources to create an approach to the violence that is both visceral in impact and innovative in approach.  In the end I want something involved can be proud of; we need your support to make this happen.

THE AWARD WINNING TEAM

This group of collaborators represent multi award winning artists, from Jeff awards  to international film awards. 

This group of artists have already been referred to by those in the Chicago Theatre community as a "dream team".

                                                                      CAST

Bosola- Kevin Cox   2015 Jeff award  "Best Actor" for "La Bete" at Trapdoor Theatre.

Duchess- Lyndsay Kane 

Ferdinand- Casey Chapman 

Cardinal- John Kahara

Cariola- Emily Lotspeich

Julia- Simina Contras

Antonio- Mike Steele

Delio- Keegan Siebken 

Grisolan, Murderer, Fighter- Jon Beal

Silvio, Officer, Madman- Mike Mazzocca

Castrucchio, Madman- Kevn Webb

Roderigo, Madman, Doctor, Fighter- Pavi Proczko


                                         THE DESIGN AND ARTISTIC TEAM

Christopher Marino -Director  http://union93.wix.com/coreshakespeare

Megan Lewis -Assistant Director and Managing Director Trapdoor Theatre http://trapdoortheatre.com/

Rachel Sypniewski -Costume Designer 2015 Jeff award winner "Best Costume Design" For "La Bete" at Trapdoor.  http://www.rachelsyp.com/

Mike Mroch -Set Designer http://www.abouttheartists.com/artists/326407-mike-mroch

Rachel Levy -Lighting Designer  http://www.rachelklevy.com/

Zsofia Otvos -Make up design  http://www.zsofiaotvos.com/

Michal Janicki -Indiegogo graphics designer http://www.studiobema.com/

R&D Choreography -Violence design      http://www.fightshop.org

Mark Winston -Composer  http://www.thedeadsuperheroes.com/

Dr.Charles Grimes - Dramaturge



Lyndsay Kane as the Duchess.


THE MISSION

This is a play of extremes, and this production will restore the world of this play back to its lustful, grotesque, and excessively theatrical core.  With a visceral hyper-theatrical take, audiences will see a version of this play not seen on stages before. 

The blood will be plentiful, the environment dangerous, and the horror tangible.


THE PROCESS

To bring this masterpiece of Jacobean theatre to life, we will take our cues from the play itself; it is a world of excess and obsession, violence and darkness.  To love Webster is to love horror, and the dark macabre facets that are a part of human nature.  It is to look at oneself through a very dark mirror indeed.  We want to tell an excellent, complex, horror story through a play that has a beautiful (cutting) edge.  This is extreme, muscular language, and as Elliot so aptly said it,  to expose “the skull beneath the skin”. 

We seek to immerse ourselves in Webster’s dark theatrical imagination in order to be true to his vision. 


Casey Chapman as Ferdinand.


THE WORLD OF THE PLAY

This production will exist in a place of excess; where sex, power, death, and violence are commonplace.  The feel will beautifully grotesque with a true sense of danger reflected in all the elements of the physical environment. 

 I do account this world but a dog-kennel-

                                                                  Ferdinand -Act V Scene V

story:
Hey There!

Thank you for taking a look at my IndieGogo! My name is Shayla Tharp and I am in need of a helping hand, as I am trying to raise money for the Kennedy Center Festival that is happening this February. 

I am an actress in my last year of college at California State University, and just recently performed in my last production called Idiots Delight. Because of my performance, I was nominated for an award called the Irene Ryan. I was offered an opportunity to travel to Hawaii and compete with the other nominee's for scholarship money. 

This is such a rare and a once in a lifetime opportunity and I would love the chance to be able to compete. I can't express how much this trip would mean to me. I would not only learn more about my craft, but I would get to experience a whole new part of the world that I have never seen before. 

Let Me Break This Down

I am a struggling actress, and If anyone is willing to lend a helping hand, I would be more than grateful to you. If you donate, I'll be sending you a personal thank you, letting you know how much your contribution means to me. 

I have jumped so many hurdles to make it to this moment in my life. And I am just hoping I get the chance to compete and show the world what I've got!

Thank you again for taking the time to read this. Spread the word to all your friends and family :). 

Again, I am eternally grateful to all my friends and family, even if you just send positive vibes and prayers my way. 

Love from Shay <3

story:
Short Summary

  • TNT has become the premiere student theatre organization at NYU.  It has established itself as an avenue for students to work in all facets of the theatre: performance, management, direction, production, and other technical and design aspects. Tisch New Theatre is committed to developing ambitious work intended to entertain, inspire, and unite the artistic efforts of the Tisch Community with the entire student body.
  • NEXT TO NORMAL tells the story of suburban mother Diana, who struggles to cope with her worsening mental health affecting her whole family. After she is diagnosed with bipolar disorder, she searches for a healthy family life with her depressed husband, her perfect son, and her teenage daughter who just wants to be seen.

What We Need & What You Get

  • A donation to Tisch New Theatre would not only help guarantee the success of TNT this season and future seasons, but also give us the financial freedom for design, marketing, and most importantly, stay in our off-Broadway venue: The Soho Playhouse.
  • Our unique perks range from giving you a special mention in our program to getting multiple complimentary tickets to our show!

The Impact

  • NEXT TO NORMAL addresses mental health issues such as bipolar disorder, depression, suicide, grief, and drug abuse. The show shines a light on the effects and treatments of mental illness. It gives a musical and artistic voice to those whose stories have not yet been represented on a stage. We want to be able to reach our entire NYU community as well as the general public with the beautiful, honest message this show emits.

  • TNT Alumni have gone onto work in various areas (producing, management, design, and performing) on or with HAMILTON, HELLO, DOLLY!, AVENUE Q, HARRY POTTER AND THE CURSED CHILD, MEAN GIRLS, SUNDAY IN THE PARK WITH GEORGE, DEAR EVAN HANSEN, THE BOOK OR MORMAN, The Muny, City Center, Berkshire Theatre Festival, Manhattan Theatre Club, Broadway.com, Telsey & Co., and many more!

  • No matter the size, your financial contribution can help launch many careers in all facets of the theatre.

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to make a financial contribution, there are other ways you can help:

  • Please get the word out about our theatre company and let your friends know what a difference they can make by supporting our shows.
  • Share this campaign on social media!

If you are unable to make a financial contribution, there are other ways you can help:

Please get the word out about our theatre company and let your friends know what a difference they can make by supporting our shows.
Share this campaign on social media!

story:
Four Clowns presents: Welcome to Illyria! Or An Exceedingly Silly Retelling of Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night! Written and Directed by Joe DeSoto 

Four Clowns is a Los Angeles-based, nationally and internationally touring clown troupe founded in 2010, dedicated to entertaining audiences and shining light on humanity. This unique group implements a beautiful blend of elements in their highly physical productions. Music, dance, song, stunts, gags, and audience interaction create a super fun, engaging experience for all!

Illyria is the creation of our highly talented director, Joe DeSoto. (No, he didn't make us say that:) His vision for this production has evolved over several marvelous years of performing and directing comedy shows in a variety of venues across the nation. Illyria is a quirky, modern take on Shakespeare's classic tale, Twelfth Night. On the small island of Illyria, a cast of hilariously flawed characters can't avoid encroaching on each other's lives. When new guests arrive, a flood of mystery and desire leaves them more enmeshed than ever! 

Not a huge fan of Shakespeare? We promise you'll love this version!

Die hard Shakespeare fan? Don't worry, we kept the characters and the integrity of the story alive!

Our contributors are the lifeblood of this show; we appreciate you immensely! We also hope to see you at the show! 

Nov 30. - Dec. 16 Fridays, Saturdays & Sundays at 8 p.m. As well as a Sunday show at 2 p.m. at The Shakespeare Center of Los Angeles.

Buy tickets here: https://welcometoillyria.bpt.me/

www.fourclowns.org

Don't feel you can contribute right now? We understand! Please consider sharing this project with your friends and family. It's easy, just hit the Share button. :)

story:
About Emerge

 

Emerge Theatre Company, founded by Torez Mosley, Abi Ariza, and Shaun Leisher, was birthed out of a strong desire to see more POC creatives represented on stages, on screens, and in classrooms. Our mission is to uplift our community, embrace diversity, and encourage social change through creating high quality art and providing artistic opportunities.The work we produce is multisensory, ensemble driven, and designed to stimulate growth and new thought. We focus on sharing fresh perspectives, facilitating mindful healing, and constantly challenging the limits of live performance.

Our first major production will be Marisol, by Jose Rivera. We will host our production at Touchstone Theatre, August 24,25, and 26th. Space rentals, along with building our set, paying our talent, and designing the super intricate props add up quickly, and we are looking to our community for help.

We are looking to raise $1000

This will cover actor's fees, costume and hair design, and a little bit of our space rental. (Wooohooo, thank you so much for helping us!)
 

Other Ways You Can Help

  • We are offering ad space in our programs for very low cost! Pleas email Emergetheatreco@gmail.com to reserve your space!
  • Come see the show, leave a good review, and like us on Facebook!

story:
ABOUT US:

KKP Atlanta Productions was created by Kelley Young and Kelly Dawkins. We are a producing and directing duo of film and theatre. We came together, and found common ground, and not just with our names. We both share an insatiable joy for telling stories that uplift small voices, and that reach to the small voice within all of us and reminds us: we are human and we are not alone. 

  • WHO ARE WE: Producers and directors of theatre and film.
  • WHAT ARE WE CREATING: A Theatrical Production of ALMOST, MAINE 
  • WHY DO WE NEED YOU: Real Magic takes time and funding. Your funds will bring this magical story to life. See it, and feel it. 

ABOUT THE SHOW:

Written by John Cariani,

ALMOST, MAINE: It’s love. But not quite.

Welcome to Almost, Maine, a town that’s so far north, it’s almost not in the United States—it’s almost in Canada. And it almost doesn't exist. Because its residents never got around to getting organized. So it’s just…Almost.

One cold, clear Friday night in the middle of winter, while the northern lights hover in the sky above, Almost’s residents find themselves falling in and out of love in the strangest ways. Knees are bruised. Hearts are broken. Love is lost, found, and confounded. And life for the people of Almost, Maine will never be the same. It’s love. But not quite. 

SHOW DATES: November 16th, 17th, and 18th

HOW TO MAKE THE MAGIC:

Your funding  = Magic. Here's how you can bring the play, ALMOST, MAINE to life:

  • PLAY RIGHTS aka "Permission to make the magic" = $300 
  • SET COSTS aka "Establishing the world of the ALMOST, MAINE" = $967
  • COSTUMES COSTS aka "Bringing characters to life" = $288
  • LIGHTING COSTS aka "Seeing Life on stage" = $212
  • MUSIC COSTS aka "Hearing pleasant noises" = $300
  • PROP COSTS aka "Enhancing the performance" = $159
  • PROMO COSTS aka "Getting the word out" = $456
  • PROGRAM COSTS aka "Printing the Magic" = $589
  • CONCESSIONS + EVENT COSTS = $300
  • CAST + CREW COSTS aka "Honoring the people that make the magic really happen" = $1375 
  • We believe in honoring our cast and crew. Our dream is to thank them for contributing their magic by compensating them for their time and talents. 

WHAT MAGIC DOES:

Our definition of magic is: Something so wonderfully beautiful and heartbreaking that it can't be explained, only felt.

Imagine being apart of this project and knowing your contribution will be gathering a community under one roof, to feel, to laugh, to love, and experience the magic. There are moments in this play that changed our hearts for the better, that reminded us how amazing love is and how powerful it can be. This beautiful show is something that must be shared, and with your help we'll be able to share this magic. 

Other Ways You Can Help:

Our biggest hurdle will be FUNDING, but with your contribution, this hurdle will be easily overcome. Some people just can't contribute (no worries, we get that!), here's other ways you can support us.

We are hosting a few COOL EVENTS to help get the word out about Almost, Maine and KKP Atlanta Productions. Follow us on Instagram and Facebook to stay up to date on our upcoming events (click on event for link to sign ups) :

  • Follow us on Facebook + Instagram (@kkpatlanta)
  • SHARE and ATTEND  our OPEN MIC night on Friday, September 21 at 7pm. 
  • SHARE and ATTEND our FAMILY PORTRAIT SESSION on Sunday, October 14th. 
  • SHARE and ATTEND our SECOND OPEN MIC (Family addition) Thursday, October 11th at 7pm. 
  • SHARE and ATTEND our SECOND HEADSHOT promotion October, 26th. 
  • SHARE and ATTEND our SHORT FILM SCREENING on Friday, October 26th at 6pm. 
  • Ask fellow theatre folks and creatives to get the word out and make some noise about your campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!
  • COME SEE THE SHOW! :) November 16th, 17th, 18th

Support small voices, support magical stories, support women in production, support young dreams, and watch them become a reality. 

You're the best. 

MORE FROM KKP PRODUCTIONS:

Behind the scenes of KKP Productions First Movie, "Kill Jill"

Behind the scenes of KKP Productions First Movie, "Kill Jill"

Behind the scenes of KKP Productions First Movie, "Kill Jill"

story:
Mr. Crow, an interactive performance

"You showed me how to die. Now it’s my turn to show you how to live.

I will never forget you. But I chose to bury you in my memory."

"We were only 19 back then. He told me about his failed suicide attempt. And I thought I understood him. But I didn’t. After he died from suicide two years later, I kept going back to that cafe conversation. Again and again, I tried to dig out every clue that may tell me why he took his own life. Again and Again, I failed. From what I experienced, Mr.Crow, was born. He flies freely like a crow, dances at his own funeral, and laughs at those who tried to cover up his suicide with a simple reason."  ---Changting Lu, Creative Producing MFA Candidate at CalArts,

Written and directed by Changting Lu, Mr. Crow is a multimedia interactive performance that explores the complexity and controversy of suicide through the lens of personal memory. It is a story of the living trying vainly to reconnect with the dead, facing the guiltiness of his not being able to prevent his friend’s suicide, and defending the dignity of the deceased in a society that views suicide as a crime. 

We are asking our audience to put down all the judgements on suicide, and try to understand: How does it actually feel to stand on the edge of suicide? How does it actually feel to lose someone to suicide? How are the way we talks about suicide (or, the way we avoid talking about suicide), influencing those who’re suffering from suicidal thoughts? And why are these questions related to EVERYONE of us?

With voice recording devices, DV camera, live-feed projection, the performance digs into the aftermath of suicide by revisiting and recreating fragmented memories stored in multiple media. 

It will open on January 26th at 2019's Company Creation Festival @ Son of Semele Theatre, Los Angeles. We have a long way to go in order to bring Mr. Crow to life. Our team, aided by your support, hopes to resurrect this lost memory in the City of Angles.

Mr. Crow is brought to you by Flyingfire Collective, a group of LA-based theater-makers from CalArts, UCLA and USC who create new forms of storytelling to explore controversial issues. With diverse cultural backgrounds and different specialties, we're proud to create space for inter-cultural and interdisciplinary collaborations in our artistic practice. Like fireflies, we cast every hint of light inside of our body into the vast world around us.

Highlights of the experience

  • Open workshop for everyone during the rehearsal: our rehearsals will be held in form of workshops in which designers, directors and performs work as an ensemble. Our devising process will employ techniques from drama therapy. Feel free to join us and have fun! 

  • You’re invite to join a funeral…… but something will go wrong.

  • You can freely explore the space and interact with performers and multimedia devices! 

  • From our performer Lydia: “I wish to investigate and present atypical, non-human characters with opened imagination.”

  • The cast can speak 6 languages!

  • Someone is going to eat 10 BANANAs in the play

 

What We Need & What You Get

You can be an active and proud part of the birth and realization of this project and an exciting way to be directly involved with FlyingFire collective. 

Your support will go directly towards renting rehearsal and performance space, costumes, props, design elements, and marketing efforts (playbills, flyers, video and photo campaigns). And most importantly for paying our amazing actors, directors, stage managers and designers! 

When you contribute you will be able to come and see us perform at Son of Semele Theatre on Jan 26/27, Feb 6/7/8 (WOW!!!)

In addition you'll get awesome rewards, depending on your giving level, from social media shout-out, T-shirts, posters, shopping bags, to opportunities attending our open rehearsals and free performance tickets! See giving levels on the right.

Every bit of your help will make this project into reality! We really really appreciate your donations and support! 

The Impact

The creative team of Mr.Crow believes that theater is a process rather than a product, and to achieve our goal of “opening up conversations about a taboo issue”, we need to take the challenge to make to process as open as possible. With your support, we can really delve into a project that excites and challenges us at the same time. And we are committed to create a more diverse and creative greater theatrical community. Together, we can facilitate an experience for audience members, create opportunities for underrepresented artists to devise work, and share that voice with those most in need of diverse perspective.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Come see the show at Son of Semele Theatre! 
  • Like us on and share this campaign Facebook, Instagram, and Twitter
  • If you are interested in large scale donations or sponsorships, please reach out to us directly at zhutianyi1995@gmail.com

Links

Ticket: https://www.artful.ly/son-of-semele-ensemble

Facebook:  https://www.facebook.com/FlyingFire-Collective-...

Instagram: @flyingfire_collective

You can also find more information here: 

SoSE’s Facebook Page: https://www.facebook.com/sonofsemele

SoSE’s Twitter: @sonofsemele

SoSE's Instagram:  @sonofsemele

story:
Short summary

We’re looking for support to stage the Morecambe Goth Passion Play. We’re independent, unfunded and, because of Morecambe's location on the North West coast, we’re unlikely to get funding of any sort. Which is where you come in!

We want The Goth Passion Play to be a play with a difference, a mini-festival open to all. We’ll have support from the amazing community in the West End of Morecambe and the Bay Area. We also hope for the support of the goth community no matter where you are, and everyone else who believes in supporting indie projects.

The play, the place 

Performed by a cast of professional and community actors, the Morecambe Goth Passion Play is a promenade drama and spectacular that takes its inspiration from the narrow streets, cobbled back alleys and sweeping seafront of the Victorian West End of Morecambe with its amazing views of the Lake District on the other side of the bay.

As Jesus carries his cross barefoot and scourged through the streets, he begs for help from a bystander who scornfully refuses. Jesus’s supporters try to hold the bystander to account. Instead he escapes but puts the blame on an innocent goth who had actually wanted to help the future Messiah.

Now cursed in the eyes of the world, the wrongly accused goth finds himself doomed across time to roam the earth in search of salvation. Rejected by his community and those he encounters in his wanderings, he comes to understand the reasons why people fear the Other even when it comes from within us. Ultimately he finds kindness in the most unlikely quarters as we all discover the inner goth inside us. Meanwhile, special 'playlets' based on social themes dot the West End, ready for discovery by the audience.

Fanfare for the Uncommon Man

Taking inspiration from the great gothic novels of the 19th century, the Jarrow Crusade, Pilgrim’s Progress, and the social iniquities of the UK today, The Morecambe Goth Passion Play lays to rest the incipient hatred in organised religion and places the Otherness of the Goth – of us all – into an eternal passion that seeks redemption in resurrection that might not be what you expect.

The Goth Passion Play is therefore a powerful drama that rips through the human condition, a community play that speaks for those in need, a global celebration of a unique culture and values. And most of all it gives a voice to the Oppressed and the Other, something given particular resonance in our Disunited Kingdom of Austerity today.

The experience will be followed the same evening by Corrosion, Morecambe's very own goth club night that will take place at the Alhambra Theatre, of a shape and form still to come. Many will remember the Alhambra Theatre in its Carleton Club incarnation, when it held sway as one of the truly great Northern club venues.

Our creators & partners

The Morecambe Goth Passion Play is being brought to life by a creative alliance guided by producers Nick Awde and The Other National Theatre: Corrosion, DIY West End Theatre, Desert Hearts, Second Skin Theatre, the Alhambra Theatre, Morecambe Arts so far – and many more to follow. We also hope the Sophie Lancaster Foundation will have a presence at the event.

What we need

We’re raising £4,300 in this Indiegogo campaign to go towards making it all work – because The Morecambe Goth Passion Play will be an experience played out in public spaces and is free to all, we won’t be ticketing it.

We won't get Arts Council funding, but we would like to pay our creatives and there’s also a long list of administrative things to pay that come with any public event like this. £4,300 won’t cover it all, but the more we get the more we can spend on COSTUMES!, ambulatory scenery, music and musicians... and a truly darkly epic finish!

We’re independent and so we need YOUR help to bring the Morecambe Goth Passion Play to life! Like we said, you don’t have to be a goth to support our event, so if you love live events, if you love supporting artists & communities, if you love Art that unashamedly has a Soul, YOU can have a direct influence in making The Morecambe Goth Passion Play 2019 an amazing event for one and all and the seed for something BIGGER to grow.

PLEASE PLEDGE NOW!

Risks & challenges

We know this is difficult thing to do, but we know we have the vision to create and stage an amazing event thanks to all the talented people who are helping us make this happen on the smallest of budgets. It's just that your money will make us more awesome. We shall overcome!

A bit about amazing Morecambe

Morecambe was a thriving resort town, one of the nation’s liveliest. It all but died at the beginning of the 1990s, and the council at the time drove away the punk and mod festivals that gave the town an extension of life in the 1990s and 2000s.

Now the communities in Morecambe are igniting its spirit once more and the tribes are returning. The punks are here for Morecambe Punk Festival and Nice ’n’ Sleazy. The steam punks have the magnificent A Splendid Day Out twice a year. Hawkwind chose the West End’s Alhambra for the epic community-inspiring HawkEaster 2018. The Exchange Creative Community has revitalised the other arts and a whole lot more. ITV has just filmed a new detective drama here, The Bay starring Morven Christie, and Cornwall's mega Eden Project no less has just announced that they're coming North to create a major new eco-dome on the seafront.

Morecambe's very own Corrosion nights have kept the goth flame alight, limned by visits to the evocative ancient churchyard of St Peter's Church and the stone graves amidst the ruins of St Patrick’s Chapel (both 7th-8th centuries) in nearby Heysham. 

And now it’s time for an Other gathering...

Other ways you can help

Twitter @gothpassionplay, tweet hashtag #gothpassionplay

Like our Facebook page Morecambe Goth Passion Play

Instagram gothpassionplay ... More social media to come!

And if you're unable to back us financially this time, you can still help us more than you realise by simply spreading the news of our project. The biggest obstacle for indie creators is getting the word out!

Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQs...

Which is where you come in!We want The Goth Passion Play to be a play with a difference, a mini-festival open to all. We’ll have support from the amazing community in the West End of Morecambe and the Bay Area. We also hope for the support of the goth community no matter where you are, and everyone else who believes in supporting indie projects.The play, the place Performed by a cast of professional and community actors, the Morecambe Goth Passion Play is a promenade drama and spectacular that takes its inspiration from the narrow streets, cobbled back alleys and sweeping seafront of the Victorian West End of Morecambe with its amazing views of the Lake District on the other side of the bay.As Jesus carries his cross barefoot and scourged through the streets, he begs for help from a bystander who scornfully refuses. Jesus’s supporters try to hold the bystander to account. Instead he escapes but puts the blame on an innocent goth who had actually wanted to help the future Messiah.Now cursed in the eyes of the world, the wrongly accused goth finds himself doomed across time to roam the earth in search of salvation. Rejected by his community and those he encounters in his wanderings, he comes to understand the reasons why people fear the Other even when it comes from within us. Ultimately he finds kindness in the most unlikely quarters as we all discover the inner goth inside us. Meanwhile, special 'playlets' based on social themes dot the West End, ready for discovery by the audience.Fanfare for the Uncommon ManTaking inspiration from the great gothic novels of the 19th century, the Jarrow Crusade, Pilgrim’s Progress, and the social iniquities of the UK today, The Morecambe Goth Passion Play lays to rest the incipient hatred in organised religion and places the Otherness of the Goth – of us all – into an eternal passion that seeks redemption in resurrection that might not be what you expect.The Goth Passion Play is therefore a powerful drama that rips through the human condition, a community play that speaks for those in need, a global celebration of a unique culture and values. And most of all it gives a voice to the Oppressed and the Other, something given particular resonance in our Disunited Kingdom of Austerity today.The experience will be followed the same evening by Corrosion, Morecambe's very own goth club night that will take place at the Alhambra Theatre, of a shape and form still to come. Many will remember the Alhambra Theatre in its Carleton Club incarnation, when it held sway as one of the truly great Northern club venues.Our creators & partnersThe Morecambe Goth Passion Play is being brought to life by a creative alliance guided by producers Nick Awde and The Other National Theatre: Corrosion, DIY West End Theatre, Desert Hearts, Second Skin Theatre, the Alhambra Theatre, Morecambe Arts so far – and many more to follow. We also hope the Sophie Lancaster Foundation will have a presence at the event.What we needWe’re raising £4,300 in this Indiegogo campaign to go towards making it all work – because The Morecambe Goth Passion Play will be an experience played out in public spaces and is free to all, we won’t be ticketing it.We won't get Arts Council funding, but we would like to pay our creatives and there’s also a long list of administrative things to pay that come with any public event like this. £4,300 won’t cover it all, but the more we get the more we can spend on COSTUMES!, ambulatory scenery, music and musicians... and a truly darkly epic finish!We’re independent and so we need YOUR help to bring the Morecambe Goth Passion Play to life! Like we said, you don’t have to be a goth to support our event, so if you love live events, if you love supporting artists & communities, if you love Art that unashamedly has a Soul, YOU can have a direct influence in making The Morecambe Goth Passion Play 2019 an amazing event for one and all and the seed for something BIGGER to grow.PLEASE PLEDGE NOW!Risks & challengesWe know this is difficult thing to do, but we know we have the vision to create and stage an amazing event thanks to all the talented people who are helping us make this happen on the smallest of budgets. It's just that your money will make us more awesome. We shall overcome!A bit about amazing MorecambeMorecambe was a thriving resort town, one of the nation’s liveliest. It all but died at the beginning of the 1990s, and the council at the time drove away the punk and mod festivals that gave the town an extension of life in the 1990s and 2000s.Now the communities in Morecambe are igniting its spirit once more and the tribes are returning. The punks are here for Morecambe Punk Festival and Nice ’n’ Sleazy. The steam punks have the magnificent A Splendid Day Out twice a year. Hawkwind chose the West End’s Alhambra for the epic community-inspiring HawkEaster 2018. The Exchange Creative Community has revitalised the other arts and a whole lot more. ITV has just filmed a new detective drama here, The Bay starring Morven Christie, and Cornwall's mega Eden Project no less has just announced that they're coming North to create a major new eco-dome on the seafront.Morecambe's very own Corrosion nights have kept the goth flame alight, limned by visits to the evocative ancient churchyard of St Peter's Church and the stone graves amidst the ruins of St Patrick’s Chapel (both 7th-8th centuries) in nearby Heysham. And now it’s time for an Other gathering...Other ways you can helpTwitter @gothpassionplay, tweet hashtag #gothpassionplayLike our Facebook page Morecambe Goth Passion PlayInstagram gothpassionplay ... More social media to come!And if you're unable to back us financially this time, you can still help us more than you realise by simply spreading the news of our project. The biggest obstacle for indie creators is getting the word out!Looking for more information or have a question? See the FAQs...

story:
Résumé du projet

Cette création répond à un besoin de célébrer la capacité de résilience inhérente à l’homme. Cette capacité de transformation devant l’épreuve est pour nous, le collectif CRue, porteuse d’une beauté extrême. Dans une recherche d’authenticité, les interprètes sont amenés à affronter leurs limites physiques et psychologiques, et ensemble, les redéfinissent. L’objectif est de rendre tangible, par une danse empreinte de vulnérabilité et d’une rage de renaître, la force qui​ ​nous​ ​habite​ ​tous​ ​lorsque​ ​nous​ ​la​ ​laissons​ ​s’exprimer.

Le projet a pris racine en 2015 avec des résidences de recherche. Depuis, nous travaillons à sa création à raison de deux semaines de travail avec l'équipe chaque année dû au rythme des organismes subventionnaires.

Cette résidence, offerte par Recto-Verso, est essentielle à sa dernière phase de création, à la création des éclairages et du matériel promotionnel en vue de sa production. Les studios de la coopérative de Méduse est le seul lieu pouvant accueillir les besoins techniques de l’oeuvre à Québec tout en nous permettant de travailler dans l’espace scénique​ prévue pour la diffusion.

Jusqu’à présent, ce projet a bénéficié de l’appui de Première Ovation et du Conseil des arts et des lettres du Québec pour les phases de recherche et de création.


À propos du CRue

Le CRue, collectif en danse contemporaine à été fondé par Julia-Maude Cloutier et Amélie Gagnon en 2014.

Les origines du CRue : Dans un désir de démocratisation des arts, elles préconisent les créations en in situ dans des lieux atypiques qui permettent au spectateur d’avoir une responsabilité sur leur propre expérience de l’œuvre – Rue. De l’autre, elles recherchent les enjeux physiques réels à même le processus de création afin de développer un contenu ancré dans l’expérience véritable, accessible et transparent émotivement, tout en conservant l’état de recherche – Cru.

Elles privilégient un mode de création horizontal : la création est teintée de la personnalité des collaborateurs par leur imaginaire propre. Elles multiplient les collaborations avec des artistes aux médiums artistiques variés – arts visuels, art sonore, art numérique et cinématographique.

À quoi servirons les sous et ce que vous recevez en retour

Les sous amassés iront directement à nos précieux collaborateurs:

- Cachet des danseurs

- Cachet du scénographe, du compositeur et du concepteur lumière et vidéo

- Cachet pour le photographe / réalisateur qui produira le matériel promotionnel du spectacle - vidéo et photographies artistiques 

 

Ce que vous recevez en retour 

Par ce don, vous offrez un appui direct à un collectif de la relève en supportant la création de leur première pièce en salle. Vous recevez en retour des remerciements sur les médias sociaux et de très belles récompenses visuelles allant de la photographie croquée sur le vif à des extraits inédits de la pièce. Pour les catégories mécènes, nous donnons aussi votre nom à une des sections de la pièce!

Défis et risques

Bien que nous déposions encore une fois aux différents paliers gouvernementaux, les délais prévus entre les dépôts et les réponses (entre 3 et 6 mois) ne nous permettent pas d’inclure cette résidence qui s’est confirmé tardivement. C’est pourquoi nous faisons appel à vous pour son financement.

Que cette campagne soit un franc succès ou un succès disons… modéré, nous nous engageons à réaliser autant la résidence que la production du spectacle, même si l’argent doit sortir de nos poches. Parce que c’est aussi ça la résilience, atteindre nos objectifs coûte que coûte, user de créativité devant les épreuves et faire appel à la communauté lorsque nous en avons besoin!


Autres façons de nous aider

Si vous n’êtes pas en mesure de financer cette campagne pour le moment, vous pouvez aussi contribuer en partageant notre collecte de fonds autour de vous. Les outils de partage Indiegogo facilitent la diffusion de l'information!

Suivez-nous sur la page Facebook de Le CRue pour rester à l’affût de nos différents projets.

story:
Our Story

It is a pleasure to meet you!! My name is Tamara Adira and I’m artistic director of Arte y Pasión, a San Antonio based company known for pushing the boundaries of flamenco and Spanish dance and one of the most contemporary Spanish dance companies in the country.  Every performance is a chance to build on our joyful and experimental approach while allowing us to repeat and perfect our work.  We see our work as an opportunity to generate abundance for the arts community in greater San Antonio, and we’ve been around for over 10 years. 

We have launched this campaign to give you, our public, the opportunity to contribute directly to our upcoming season.  Due to funding cuts to the arts, government closures and funding freezes, we have noticed funding grind to a slow trickle for arts across the country.  At a time we need the most to speak out on human rights crises here in our backyard, it is crucial to us that we keep moving forward, as our expression is our work.  

Our 2019-20 season we continue to focus on human rights issues.  We will be working with an incredible artist who is a master in his craft from Spain. Your contribution will empower and enable us to put our full firepower to the work.  

What We Need & What You Get

We have 60 days to run this campaign.  We are asking for $6K.  Depending on how much this campaign makes, we will in turn scale the size and impact of our season.  

A small production can be made for approximately $2-4K.  We would like to put on 2-3 small productions over the upcoming season.  Your funds will go to these places, including but not limited to: 

Working with master artists: We collaborate with master artists to keep our sword sharpened and keep our work relevant, sharp, and up to date.  Your funding will help provide the behind the scenes support to keep this going. 

Renting the theater: the spaces we work in have utility bills, upkeep, and staff to pay.  As much as they would like to give us their space for free, we wish to compensate them for what they provide us with. 

Compensating our artists:  Your funds will pay for hours and hours of rehearsal time, equipment, costumes, study time, and artistic honoraria. Many of our artists only do this work for a living. Your contribution will help these artists continue to pursue their work and continue to perfect their art.

Travel: Your funds will help defray costs of travel for visiting artists. 

Classes and continued study: Your contribution will enable us to continue our studies and continue to improve our work. 

Administrative costs: Your funds will defray the costs for our proposal team, who works hours and hours preparing documents for each production, press releases, publicity, and administrative support. 

We have amazing perks which we are offering, which will help us come closer to our goal, while being very fun for you as well! 

The Impact

This project is valuable to me, and it is valuable to the world because we are using the art of flamenco as a vehicle to spread the message of kindness, peace, and compassion.  

The art of flamenco is here and strong in San Antonio for a definitive reason. When the Spaniards looked for hospitable land here in the New World, they settled here.  Flamenco prevails as testimony to a civilization evolving in complexity. San Antonio emerges parallel to Spain in many ways for her climate, culture, and landscape, with the art of flamenco very much a presence in our daily lives.  

A true sign of advancement in a civilization is the arts.  Arte y Pasión, a member of San Antonio Dance Umbrella, has been a major player in the dance and music community of San Antonio and Texas since 2010. We explore evolution and specific subject matter while preserving the foundation of the great art form, inscribed in 2010 by UNESCO on the Representative List of the Intangible Cultural Heritage of Humanity.  We have participated as an a DreamWeek Partner and with the Artist Foundation. 

Our Track Record

While we've been producing work since 2009, here are the recent projects we've done, on Human Rights issues: 

2019  Vuelo. A project on the migration of butterflies as it relates to our immigrants and the gifts they bring.

2019  Estrellas. A project on genetic memory in descendants of holocaust survivors.

2018  Aguitas. A project telling the universal story of Immigrants through the ages. There is a comparison between 1942 Germany and what is now happening at our border. 

2018  Sanctorum. a performance-ceremony for the internment of a musical time capsule,the San Antonio College (SAC) Multicultural Arts Conference, SA300 San Antonio Tricentennial - A project comparing occurrences at the Mexican Border with 1942 Germany, and the devastation of human trafficking, following the deaths of children in a truck found in San Antonio. 

2017 Tribus. We Flamenco Fest - a project focusing on the different tribes of Humanity and how we co-exist and depend on each other to live.  

2017   Nascent|Nation.  The Brick at Blue Star Arts Complex, San Antonio TX - a focus on the American Minority Experience, with separate discrete installations for Jewish, African American, Woman, and Mexican. 

2017, 2019 Estrellas.  The Brick at Blue Star Arts Complex, San Antonio TX - A focus on the genetic memory of American descendents of Holocaust survivors.

2016   A Glass of Wine.  The Brick at Blue Star Arts Complex, San Antonio TX - a focus on the guilty pleasure of a glass of wine amidst the chaos of the American election. 

2016   Colores. The Carver Jo Long Theater, San Antonio TX – produced by and on the season of The Carver Community Cultural Center - a project about the colors of all of us. 

2016, 2017  Una Flor en el Cruce.  The Carver Jo Long Theater, San Antonio TX, San Antonio Luminaria - a project about the strength of a root system that pushes a flower up through the concrete of a road system, producing the flower in the crossing. Dedicated to all those who had to push up against any sort of resistance. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can’t contribute funds, that doesn’t mean you can’t help!  Please, get the word out, use the Indiegogo share tools, and make some noise about this campaign!

Yours with love,

Tamara Adira

story:
Short Summary

Moving Guitars is a multimedia performance, combining music, dance and video art in a very unique way. World class artists, experts on different fields, will join forces:
Izhar Elias on the baroque and classical guitar.
Florian Magnus Maier on the electric guitar. He will compose new pieces for the "old" and the "new" guitar.
Dancer Kenzo Kusuda will try to move both the old and the new towards a unity.
A gigantic inflatable decor by Cocky Eek will growing on stage, like a new universe, created by Kenzo.
Stop motion masters Paul and Menno de Nooijer will project images on the inflatable, creating a absurdistic world.

Moving guitars will have its premiere in Korzo Theater The Hague on October 10th, after which it will tour The Netherlands.
The finale of the tour will be an extended version with orchestra (Philharmonie Zuidnederland) and more dancers and inflatables in October 2020.
 

What We Need & What You Get

In order to finance the video projections and compositions we still need 4000,- euro.
Your support will also help us financing our rehearsals.
In return we have beautiful rewards for you: you will get a video registration of the complete show, free tickets, CD's or even a composition lesson or a house concert.

Join our beautiful project by supporting us! Bringing together world famous artists of 3 different performance arts discipline will create an amazing new world. Even if you live on the other side of the world you will be able to see the performance: with your help we will make a video registration of the show.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please spread the word! You can use the Indiegogo share tools.
