story:
Short Summary:

Karlovsky & Company Dance, now in our fifth season, has been invited to present three full concert programs in three cities in France, this June. Making a mark on the international dance scene is an incredible accomplishment for our company — we'll not only be sharing our work, but we'll also get to learn first-hand about the differences and similarities between artists and communities across the globe. This exposure also benefits our community, as our presence in Europe will bring recognition to the city of St. Louis.

Before our tour in France, Karlovsky & Company Dance presents the premiere of “Remembrance” on March 23 and 24, 2018 at 7:30pm, at St. Louis’s own Grandel Theatre.  Artistic director and choreographer, Dawn Karlovsky, has created this new evening-length work of contemporary modern dance that reflects on the theme of memory.  Inspired by personal stories and historic accounts dating back to the 1940’s, Karlovsky & Company Dance brings to life a choreographic landscape that shows how the past cycles through generations, and informs our currents perspectives.  This concert will also include the premiere of “The Call Of Mont Sainte-Victoire” by the company’s guest artist, Marie Christine Dal Farra from Vallauris, France.

About Us:

Karlovsky & Company Dance is a St. Louis based contemporary modern dance company in residence at the Grandel Theatre and supported by the Kranzberg Arts Foundation. The company is dedicated to exploring and nurturing the art of dance with innovative choreography and performance.  Founder and artistic director, Dawn Karlovsky, develops movement that stems from conceptual, emotional, and physical elements to generate dances that are visceral, poignant, and thought provoking. Through close collaboration with a diverse group of musicians, visual artists, and choreographers, Karlovsky & Company Dance performs vibrant, inventive works that articulate and illuminate, through movement, the relationships and experiences that reveal our humanity. Karlovsky & Company Dance reaches local, national, and international audiences through concert and informal performances, dance for the camera, site-specific dance, and dance education. 

Dawn Karlovsky is a recipient of the 2015 Artist Fellowship awarded by The Regional Arts Commission of St. Louis.  She teaches modern dance and The Alexander Technique at Washington University/University College, and in the Department of Dance at Webster University in St. Louis.

Karlovsky's choreographic work receives grant support by the Missouri Arts Council, a state agency, and the Regional Arts Commission.  Additional support for this event is made possible in part by the Kranzberg Arts Foundation, The Grandel Theatre, and KDHX.

"Dawn Karlovsky is one of St. Louis' most intriguing choreographers,"

~ Alive Magazine

"Stunning, Stunning, Stunning!" ~ Audience comment

 

What We Need:

Karlovsky & Company needs to raise $4,000 to support our International Tour and REMEMBRANCE Concert.

Your contribution will help with these costs:

Artists’Salaries and Per Diem for travel for performance events = $2,000 (partial amount)

Travel expenses and lodging expenses for tour = $2,000 (partial amount)

What You Get:

  • That good feeling of knowing that you have made a difference! All of money raised will go towards the Artists’ salaries, per diems, travel expenses, and production costs needed to complete of our programs.
  • Our sincere THANK YOU and mention in our concert program.
  • Complimentary ticket(s) to our REMEMBRANCE concert on March 23 and 24, 2018 for gifts of $50 or more made by MARCH 22!
  • A Company letter to recognize your donation as a tax-deductible contribution to Karlovsky & Company Dance.

Impact:

Our company is growing! The opportunity to travel and perform in other cities helps to bring our work to new venues, strengthens our company visibility, deepens our artistic connections, and builds audiences. 

OTHER WAYS TO SUPPORT US:

  • Use social media to share this campaign - Facebook, Email, Tweet, Instagram, text, tell friends about it! 
  • LIKE Karlovsky & Company Dance on Facebook to see what we’re up to!
  • Gift Matching Programs – see if your employer takes part in Matching Gifts programs and your contribution will double! 

Come see us perform!!  

REMEMBRANCE

March 23 and 24, 2018 at 7:30 pm

The Grandel Theatre

3610 Grandel Square

St. Louis, MO 63108

TICKETS: MetroTix https://www.metrotix.com/events/detail/karlovsky-and-company-dance-remembrance

Metrotix: 314-534-1111


To see more about us, visit our website: www.karlovskydance.org

Contact us at: info@karlovskydance.org

WE ARE MOST GRATEFUL FOR YOUR SUPPORT!

 

Personal Statement:

I am encouraged by the enthusiastic welcome and expressed appreciation for my work from those in my community, and now even more expansively, as it reaches international audiences.  This has been a personal goal of mine building over many years. As the reality of this international tour comes closer, I am grateful for all support I have received and the paths that have been laid to make this possible.

Dance for me is beyond entertainment.  It’s a way to touch the lives of others.  I work within the medium of dance as a way to connect with others, and to hopefully provide an experience that inspires, heals, awakens, or brings joy.  It is a vehicle of communication, personal expression, and a powerful tool to share and articulate ideas and experiences.  Working with artists from other countries and communities provides an eye-opening understanding as to how world events, politics, human rights and social justice issues, etc. impact the lives of others in such drastically different ways than what is experienced in our own community.   I am personally and artistically intrigued to see how such worldviews and life experiences affect the aesthetics of artwork created reflecting a larger, more global reality.

~ Dawn Karlovsky, Artistic Director

Karlovsky & Company Dance, now in our fifth season, has been invited to present three full concert programs in three cities in France, this June. Making a mark on the international dance scene is an incredible accomplishment for our company — we'll not only be sharing our work, but we'll also get to learn first-hand about the differences and similarities between artists and communities across the globe. This exposure also benefits our community, as our presence in Europe will bring recognition to the city of St. Louis.

story:
WHY?

In spring of 2016, I was challenged by an amazing woman and mentor to write a solo show. What began as an "I dare you" 10-minute leap off the creative cliff has now turned into a 60-minute solo performance with a variety of characters telling the story of a Texas gal who moves to NYC to pursue her dreams and steps into the biggest role of her life... herself. I'm so excited to take this beautiful show to the Hollywood Fringe Festival this summer for the first time! I invite you to be a part of the journey that will go beyond the Hollywood Fringe to cities like NY and Houston.

What is the Hollywood Fringe Festival, Anyways? 

"The Hollywood Fringe Festival is an annual, open-access, community-derived event celebrating freedom of expression and collaboration in the performing arts community.  Each June during the Hollywood Fringe, the arts infiltrate the Hollywood neighborhood: fully equipped theaters, parks, clubs, churches, restaurants, and other unexpected places host hundreds of productions by local, national, and international arts companies, and independent performers." www.hollywoodfringe.org

What do I Need? 

Producing any theater piece takes heart and soul + funding. Your contribution will make a difference: $4,000 to cover the cost of 4 shows:  registration fee, theater rental, crew, rehearsals/director/asst. director, producer, advertising/PR/networking.

What are the risks/challenges?

It's art.  Anytime you create art that's personal there's a risk to offend, to lose money, to fall flat on your face. But where would we all be without taking those risks? I am well-prepared and have the best creative team behind me to make this project an entertaining and fun evening for every single audience member.  I promise, your money will not go to waste.  With over 56,000 Hollywood Fringe Festival tickets sold each summer, this show is bound to delight and inspire audiences and be an impactful addition to the Festival!

Are there other ways I can help?

I'm an artist.  I get it.  Sometimes you just can't contribute the green stuff, but that doesn't mean you can't help:

Get the word out and show some social media love about my show via Twitter, Facebook, Instagram, LinkedIn, and Pinterest!  I can send you pre-baked tweets and posts for you to easily share on your favorite social media platform.  

Get this Texas gal to Hollywood!!!  Join the adventure today...

story:
WHAT WE’RE DOING…

BLACKOUT

BLACKOUT is a one-act, four-character play that explores grief and mental illness and how they affect our lives. Only, instead of our lives, we’re using superheroes.

 

BLACKOUT begins a year after Cassie Robertson AKA Blackout. Her mentor, Kinetic’s, suicide. She struggles to control her powers and her emotions which have begun to wreak havoc on New York City!. On top of that, her deadbeat brother suddenly comes back into her life and the ghosts of her past are invading her mind! Now Cassie must come to grips with her grief and emotions before she destroys the city she’s supposed to protect.

 

The play is told through scenes that take place in the present day and flashbacks in New York City.

 

WHY WE’RE DOING IT…

Exploring Mental Illness and Grief and creating more diverse stories featuring queer characters.

 

Mental illness and grief are still difficult to talk about in some communities, and it affects people in different ways. BLACKOUT seeks to explore a specific facet of these two incredibly dense topics. Cassie struggles with her own feelings of anxiety and depression that is only compounded by her unprocessed grief over her mentor’s death - and this affects 8pevery part of her life.

 

Also, every single character in BLACKOUT is queer and queer with a purpose.

 

With this show, we want to:

 

Inspire a discussion about mental illness and its effects on us and our lives: What are the dangers of not getting help and how the refusal of help can affect your relationships.

Promote queer art.

Show that the queer experience goes beyond the traditional narrative and that we tackle issues and problems other than our sexuality.

 

The audience of Blackout’s stage reading this past summer spoke about their connection to the material and stated how excited they were for a show of this nature to get up in its feet! And now we are bringing it to you on May 16th. We’re going to have a full cast, a crew, and an amazing director at the helm. We just need your help to make it all happen.

What do we need? What am I paying for?

Perks

We have some amazing perks! We've got artwork, tickets to the show, and tons more that you can find in our perk list. 

Stretch Goal

Any extra money we make through this campaign will go towards paying our actors and crew!

Other Ways You Can Help

Don't have any money? That's totally fine! But we'd really appreciate your help!

Please share the show! Use all the social media!

 

WHO ARE WE?

Producers:

Founded in 2013 by Janelle Lawrence and Miranda Amitrano in a small basement apartment in Yonkers, NY, Broad Views on Broadway originated as a Musical Theatre company driven by compacting the gap between emerging artists and professional environments. Though our mission has mostly stayed the same, we have grown in our actions and make plans to continue to adapt. Broad Views on Broadway is a Music and Theatre company that strives to provide an enriching, nurturing environment for artists.

Since Broad Views on Broadway was first developed in 2013 we have held to our mission of supporting emerging artists. Our goal as a company has been to produce new works in New York City and support their development. 

We are incredibly excited to be working with Shann and to get BLACKOUT on its feet for the first time ever!

Playwright: Shann Smith

Shann Smith is a writer, teacher, video game enthusiast, and film nerd based in Inwood, New York. After spending moving to New York to pursue acting, Shann realized that he was less of an interpreter and more of a creator. He wrote and produced his own show, Super, in 2016 and currently works as the staff writer and content of Plato Learning, where he writes about mythology and develops the popular Mythomagic Tabletop RPG for use in schools across Brooklyn. He is so happy that this show (that he's been working on for nearly three years now) is finally getting its first production!

story:
WedRepCo – an innovative theatrical company that's been active since 2011.

Our goal with this indiegogo campaign is to raise money to help cover costs like theatre space, designers & crew, and all other typical expenses related to theatrical productions.

With your contribution, we will be able to continue providing the NYC+ community with stage productions that entertain, enrich & move audiences.

story:
Rogue Productions premiered their all-new musical Some Holiday in Portsmouth, NH  from 11/22 - 12/1 at the Player’s Ring.

Rogue Productions is the brainchild of Justin Scarelli and Melissa Sweatt - though Some Holiday will be their first-produced musical, they have extensive experience in the world of film production in NH, MA and Los Angeles. Money raised in this campaign will be going to offeset production costs, recording an album of song selections, and compensating the incredible team of musicians, technicians, and cast.

Short Summary

What would you do if...

You’re recently married to your college sweetheart, trying to pay the bills and settle into a career, when an unexpected pregnancy happens. Or maybe you’re a commitment-phobic gay man whose boyfriend reveals he has a small child from a previous relationship. Or even still, an actress who gave up a life on the road with her musician husband for their child, but whose Broadway dreams are still calling.

Would you struggle with balancing your own hopes and dreams with the needs of another? Would there be some humor in all this messy and complicated adulting? Would you maybe...want to sing about it?

You’re in luck, as these scenarios set up the premise of Some Holiday, an original musical written by Justin Scarelli, adapted from his screenplay, with music and lyrics by Justin Scarelli and Marina Altschiller, produced by Rogue Productions.

So we have the team, the dedication and the vision, but creating a transformative and captivating experience/performance for both the actors and the audience will be a massive undertaking. And as this is an original piece, we’d like to be able to professionally record a selection of the songs and scenes to extend its life beyond our initial run of performances.


(L-R Jacob Randlett (Miles), Nicole Jones (Tracy), Chris Ferrill (Chris), Trevor Gatcomb (Sam), Joel Michael King (Dan), Aly Aramento (Grace). Photo by Benji K Photography.)

If this sounds just as exciting to you as it does to us, we hope that you make the choice to become a potential backer, support the team ready to bring this piece of art to life, and become an active participant in our journey!

What We Need & What You Get

As previously mentioned above (or maybe you’re reading it for the first time because you’re an active scroller), Some Holiday was conceived and produced originally for the screen. It played to a sold out crowd at Red River Theatres as well as CinemaSalem in Salem, MA and several universities in NH, MA and VT.

Some Holiday’s journey as a story was not finished, however, as Justin always believed the concept would work well on a stage in front of an audience. It wasn’t until the brilliant and talented Marina Altschiller agreed to help crack the musical DNA, infusing her melodies and lyrics with the existing book, and Melissa Sweatt came on board to help produce, that this belief became reality. 

What WE Need

Reimbursement for:

  • Production/Set Design elements (props, practical set pieces)
  • Marketing and Promotional materials (print, digital media, etc)
  • Cast & creative compensation (talent, stage crew, musicians, etc)
  • Recording (selections of songs for album, video production, etc)
     

What YOU Get

  • Shoutouts (social media, video, etc)
  • Signed posters 
  • Digital download of recorded songs
  • Behind-the-scenes content
  • AND more!
     

Risks & Challenges

Bringing a stage production to life is a particularly delicate and sometimes daunting task, tending to many needs and balancing many layers. So it makes sense that embarking on a brand new property contains a new set of challenges. Our desire to present this show in the best possible way means design that is exciting and a tad technical.  However: 

Our team has skills and experiences from successful professional productions, independent filmmaking and professional sets that we are more than ready to take on the task and any challenges that surely lie ahead - our bios are below if you are interested in scrolling further.

The spirit and the excitement around creating and executing a work of art is something we have built into our already underway preparations - props, cast, staging, etc. All of it will equal out to a well-oiled machine come opening night!

Other Ways You Can Help

If you are unable to contribute financially but still want to contribute, here's how:

Get the word out! Seriously, sharing our campaign with your social media networks is important and much appreciated! 

Follow us on social media! You can find us @someholidaymusical on Instagram and Facebook, or visit our website www.someholidaymusical.com

BIOS

Justin Scarelli (Book/Music & Lyrics)

Justin's  previous work experience at Warner Bros. and the Walt Disney Company exposed him to all aspects of filmmaking and digital media. As a writer/director, some project highlights include the critically-reviewed Movie Night, an episodic web series about a group of movie-loving misfits in Los Angeles; Rated PG: A Parody of Sex and Violence in Contemporary Media, a documentary produced in conjunction with a teen center in Hillsboro, NH that was featured at a national conference in Boston; and Some Holiday, the independent feature that screened at several local indie theaters in NH and MA, and the basis on which this musical is adapted.
 

Marina Altschiller (Music & Lyrics)

Marina is an accomplished veteran of the Seacoast-area theatre scene, logging many hours both behind-the-scenes and on the stage. Acting credits include Dogfight (Rose) and The Gift of the Magi (Della), and her production credits include Little Shop of Horrors (Director), Opening Night Mutiny (AD), The Pavement Artist (Director), and Waiting for Jack (Director). In 2014, Marina founded Dive In Productions as a safe space for theater artists of every level to grow and explore in their craft.
 

Melissa Sweatt (Producer) 

Melissa has been passionate about filmmaking, video production and writing since her middle school days, receiving her first camcorder at the age of 13. She continued to make home movies with her friends throughout high school, and attended an intense two year filmmaking program at Boston University. Since then, Melissa’s freelance work includes music videos, short films and weddings, landing her positions at NH1 News and New Hampshire PBS. Most recently, Melissa moved into a senior staff producer role, working with community members and producers at a local public access station in Concord, NH. In 2018 she, along with Justin Scarelli, founded Rogue Productions, whose focus is to produce engaging and creative content, both on and off the screen.

Instagram

Or even still, an actress who gave up a life on the road with her musician husband for their child, but whose Broadway dreams are still calling.Would you struggle with balancing your own hopes and dreams with the needs of another? Would there be some humor in all this messy and complicated adulting? Would you maybe...want to sing about it?You’re in luck, as these scenarios set up the premise of Some Holiday, an original musical written by Justin Scarelli, adapted from his screenplay, with music and lyrics by Justin Scarelli and Marina Altschiller, produced by Rogue Productions.So we have the team, the dedication and the vision, but creating a transformative and captivating experience/performance for both the actors and the audience will be a massive undertaking. And as this is an original piece, we’d like to be able to professionally record a selection of the songs and scenes to extend its life beyond our initial run of performances.(L-R Jacob Randlett (Miles), Nicole Jones (Tracy), Chris Ferrill (Chris), Trevor Gatcomb (Sam), Joel Michael King (Dan), Aly Aramento (Grace). Photo by Benji K Photography.)If this sounds just as exciting to you as it does to us, we hope that you make the choice to become a potential backer, support the team ready to bring this piece of art to life, and become an active participant in our journey!What We Need & What You GetAs previously mentioned above (or maybe you’re reading it for the first time because you’re an active scroller), Some Holiday was conceived and produced originally for the screen. It played to a sold out crowd at Red River Theatres as well as CinemaSalem in Salem, MA and several universities in NH, MA and VT.Some Holiday’s journey as a story was not finished, however, as Justin always believed the concept would work well on a stage in front of an audience. It wasn’t until the brilliant and talented Marina Altschiller agreed to help crack the musical DNA, infusing her melodies and lyrics with the existing book, and Melissa Sweatt came on board to help produce, that this belief became reality. What WE NeedReimbursement for:
Production/Set Design elements (props, practical set pieces)
Marketing and Promotional materials (print, digital media, etc)
Cast & creative compensation (talent, stage crew, musicians, etc)
Recording (selections of songs for album, video production, etc) 
What YOU Get
Shoutouts (social media, video, etc)
Signed posters 
Digital download of recorded songs
Behind-the-scenes content
AND more! 
Risks & ChallengesBringing a stage production to life is a particularly delicate and sometimes daunting task, tending to many needs and balancing many layers. So it makes sense that embarking on a brand new property contains a new set of challenges. Our desire to present this show in the best possible way means design that is exciting and a tad technical.  However: Our team has skills and experiences from successful professional productions, independent filmmaking and professional sets that we are more than ready to take on the task and any challenges that surely lie ahead - our bios are below if you are interested in scrolling further.The spirit and the excitement around creating and executing a work of art is something we have built into our already underway preparations - props, cast, staging, etc. All of it will equal out to a well-oiled machine come opening night!Other Ways You Can HelpIf you are unable to contribute financially but still want to contribute, here's how:Get the word out! Seriously, sharing our campaign with your social media networks is important and much appreciated! Follow us on social media! You can find us @someholidaymusical on Instagram and Facebook, or visit our website www.someholidaymusical.comBIOSJustin Scarelli (Book/Music & Lyrics)Justin's  previous work experience at Warner Bros. and the Walt Disney Company exposed him to all aspects of filmmaking and digital media. As a writer/director, some project highlights include the critically-reviewed Movie Night, an episodic web series about a group of movie-loving misfits in Los Angeles; Rated PG: A Parody of Sex and Violence in Contemporary Media, a documentary produced in conjunction with a teen center in Hillsboro, NH that was featured at a national conference in Boston; and Some Holiday, the independent feature that screened at several local indie theaters in NH and MA, and the basis on which this musical is adapted. Marina Altschiller (Music & Lyrics)Marina is an accomplished veteran of the Seacoast-area theatre scene, logging many hours both behind-the-scenes and on the stage. Acting credits include Dogfight (Rose) and The Gift of the Magi (Della), and her production credits include Little Shop of Horrors (Director), Opening Night Mutiny (AD), The Pavement Artist (Director), and Waiting for Jack (Director). In 2014, Marina founded Dive In Productions as a safe space for theater artists of every level to grow and explore in their craft. Melissa Sweatt (Producer) Melissa has been passionate about filmmaking, video production and writing since her middle school days, receiving her first camcorder at the age of 13. She continued to make home movies with her friends throughout high school, and attended an intense two year filmmaking program at Boston University. Since then, Melissa’s freelance work includes music videos, short films and weddings, landing her positions at NH1 News and New Hampshire PBS. Most recently, Melissa moved into a senior staff producer role, working with community members and producers at a local public access station in Concord, NH. In 2018 she, along with Justin Scarelli, founded Rogue Productions, whose focus is to produce engaging and creative content, both on and off the screen.FacebookInstagram

story:
The Plot 

'Cliff and Me' tells the story of a life- long love between friends, fans and their shining star.

Crystal first saw Cliff Richard in his white sequinned suit on stage at Birmingham Hippodrome in 1962 when she was nine years old. 

This is a tender and tear jerking show as we follow the lives of Crystal and her friends.- their rivalry, love, laughter and heartbreaking loss. We wonder at their faithful (and occasionally fickle) adoration of Cliff through Britain's ever-changing culture. We watch their changes through baby doll dresses and mini-skirts of the swinging sixties-  bell bottomed trousers during union strikes and ‘winter of discontent’ of the seventies, shoulder pads and power suits of Thatcher’s eighties and finally after a mid-life crisis in the countryside we arrive right up to date to colourful XR climate change activism and a fragmented Brexit Britain. 

 

Who We Are

We are Pamela and Glenn Gaunt, who have recently launched our production company 'Gaunt and Son Productions' to bring to you Cliff & Me! A brand new musical which we are aiming to get put on in the West End in September 2020 in time for Cliff Richard's 80th Birthday! 

Cliff and Me! is the story of 3 fans as they follow Cliff through the decades, and ever changing political times. 

The basis of the musical came from Pamela's life long fandom, and dedication. This new piece of theatre is really for his fans, about his fans, and from his fans. 

It was her determination, to write this show and the collaboration between us that has made it possible to bring this piece to life. We need your help to get us over the finish line and get this production to the West End. 

What We Need & What You Get

We are aiming big, and headed for London's infamous West End. To make this happen we need to raise £20,000 

This is to find some of the basic things such as the Venue, Actors, Musicians, Rehearsal Spaces, Costumes, Make Up and License Rights. We have a range of perks for you to choose from. Wether you are a Cliff Richard Fan or not this show has something for everyone. 

The Impact

This show doesn't just tell the story of Cliff Richard and his fans. It takes us through the ever changing political climate, from activism on Greenham Common to the dread B Word......BREXIT! 

The impact of this show is not just for Cliff Richard Fans but to all activists, husbands who queued up for tickets, and those who just love a good musical! 

Risks & Challenges

We are hoping to go straight into a main stage depending on funding, however we are going to work with the budget that we have. 

Our aim is to have a 300 seater theatre run for 3 weeks, with the possibility of an extension. If this is not attainable due to budget, we will be looking to reduce the run, or reduce the size of the venue. 

With both producers having a strong background across the industry we are adept at troubleshooting and can tailor our budget to the production size. 

Other Ways You Can Help

If you aren't able to contribute financially, we would LOVE you to help us spread the word amongst your friends. Please do share our campaign so that we can bring this exciting production to audiences in London's West End.

story:
Short Summary

Rebbekah Ogden is producing her Final Project Salt Water Moon at Arts Commons, Motel Theatre in Calgary March 13, 14 and 15 2020.

Salt Water Moon is a Canadian classic by David French. This delightful two hander tells the story of Jacob Mercer trying to win back Mary Snow's heart, after leaving her high and dry for Toronto a year ago. However, his welcome home might not be as warm as he was hoping for.

As a graduating student of Rosebud School of the Arts, Rebbekah must produce and act in a show of her choosing before becoming an FRSA (Fellow Rosebud School of the Arts) guild member. For the last three and a half years, Rebbekah has been studying the performing arts and is now getting ready to showcase some of the concepts she has been learning. 

A final project however isn't only time consuming it is also expensive and Rebbekah must come up with the funds herself. That is why she is asking you to help cover expenses such as venue rental, set materials and costume build.

Your contribution would mean, helping Rebbekah graduate and helping her team produce a show of quality and creativity. 

What We Need & What You Get

 We need an estimate $2500. Below is a break down of what we'll need in order to make this project a success.

  • For the venue and rentals $1500
  • designs and builds $500
  • rights for the play and team copies $500

For our gratitude towards your contribution we have some selected perks to offer. 

  •  A hand written thank you postcard
  • Beksart art card
  • Original song composed just for you
  • An original caricature drawing of you by Rebbekah Ogden
  • A chance to win an Original Art piece by Rebbekah Ogden

 

 The Impact

Rebbekah has assembled a team of mostly emerging artists. Her desire is to create an opportunity for emerging artists to showcase their work. Salt Water Moon is being produced in Arts Commons, a building that boasts of 6 theatres and is located right downtown amidst the hub of art culture in Calgary. This gives her team the chance to have their work showcased in front of the professional theatre community in Calgary.

After Graduating from theatre schools, artists have the difficult job of getting their work seen by the professional community, building a sustainable resume can take years. Often the discouragement of rejection after rejection and auditioning with no promise of succeeding, leads artists to quit doing what they love. Yet creating opportunities for themselves and each other is a solution many emerging artists are turning too. Rebbekah and her husband Joel have created their theatre company Creating Genesis with the intention of spearheading productions with other artists in the industry. Salt Water Moon is just the beginning for what Rebbekah hopes to be a promising creative future.

Your contribution to Salt Water Moon today will help emerging artists create art tomorrow.

Other Ways You Can Help

Share the word about Salt Water Moon. Tell everyone you know that this production is being held March 13, 14 and 15 2020 at Arts Commons, in the Motel Theatre. Come on out to the show and enjoy the play.

Lastly, share this Indiegogo campaign on facebook and any other social media stream you prefer. The more noise we make the louder the splash :)

Thank you so much for taking the time out of your day to consider helping us out.

story:
Have you ever wondered:
'Is this the kind of life I want to live?'


It’s a question anyone touched by addiction or mental health issues will have asked themselves. But what should the answer look like?


In an imaginary realm (encompassing the bog of eternal stench and a death cafe) this show will explore this and other questions...

  • What is addiction? And where does it come from?
  • Do we need to be happy all the time? Or can we accept the rainbow of all human emotions?
  • Should we just go and howl at the moon? 
  • Is training to run a marathon even a good idea?

 

Combining personal stories, some twisted secrets, and a wicked sense of humour, with live music, old VHS tapes, and a soupçon of '90s nostalgia, this epic dramedy examines life after death, living with addiction, and the teeny rays of sunshine that seep through the cracks if we can but notice them.

Join Annie McKenzie (actor, writer, director, and Master Chef semi-finalist) and Kester Hynds (musician, composer, performer, and receiver of an honourable mention in the unofficial Forest Hill beans-on-toast cook off) in this quest through the labyrinth of addiction and recovery as they seek to discover whether it’s possible to befriend the “beast within”.

On The Other Side I Found Myself Standing is a work in progress of a new play premiering at The Horse and Stables near Waterloo from 21st to 23rd February as part of Vault Festival 2020. 

The finished show will be heading to the Edinburgh Fringe for the full month of August.

 

Why are we doing this?

As people who have both suffered from severe mental health issues (and associated addictions and substance abuse) Annie and Kester are hoping to bring a joyful and honest approach to this sometimes dark and upsetting subject matter. 

As well as putting together the show itself, the team will be collaborating with several leading addiction and mental health charities (including Cascade Creative Recovery & Phoenix Futures) to deliver a series of one-day workshops for people who have had problematic relationships with drugs or alcohol — and are now tackling their addictions and moving towards recovery. Working with music, movement and the body, the workshops will use many of the games and devising techniques we use during the rehearsal process to help the participants explore their relationship to drink, drugs, as well as their relationship with themselves. The aim with these creative workshops is to help reduce the risk of relapse, deepen engagement with treatment and encourage participants to think about living free from addiction. These will be accompanied by Q&A sessions to help the development of the finished piece.

We plan to perform an initial work-in-progress at The Harbour (Lambeth Consortium) in South West London on 15th February 2020, where the workshop members can see the impact their involvement has had on the production,

With the current mental health crisis in the UK and the rest of the world, we want to open up conversations about a variety of issues: Including addiction, anxiety, depression, imposter syndrome, grief and eating disorders, the pressure for women to be beautiful, the pressure for men not to cry, and a patriarchy that doesn't serve any of us.

We want to create a safe space to openly discuss these things and make steps to get better together: One workshop at a time, one show at a time.

 

What we need (and why)

We are hoping to raise an additional £2000 to help with the running costs of the project and to supplement the funds we are hoping to raise elsewhere, including Arts Council funding and a grant from Create Recovery. 

We will be embarking on a two-week research, development and rehearsal period in early February 2020 with artists Jamie Wood and Crystal Zillwood to create material for the five work-in-progress showings at the Vault Festival.

Jamie Wood is a director and clown and comedy coach who will work with Annie and Kester to help integrate their lived experience and their work into a cohesive piece which is accessible and relevant for the marginalised groups in recovery, as well as a wider theatre audience.

Crystal Zillwood is a dancer, choreographer, movement director and dance teacher. Crystal will work with Annie and Kester to integrate more choreographed movement into the piece.

Your contribution will help us to pay our artistic development team and fund production costs, such as rehearsals, marketing, etc. It will also help us to deliver one-day workshops (and the show itself) to recovering addicts and service users who will benefit from engagement with the piece we are making and the processes we are using.

We feel stories about addiction need to be told better and more honestly, by those who have had first hand experience, and that's what we intend to do.

We want those still suffering to feel hopeful for the future, and that recovery is possible.

 

​What you get

We have a variety of perks available for those donating!

 

STANDARD PERKS

£5 Personalised Tweet
A tweet and personalised image of the cast on Annie & Kester’s Twitter accounts.
E.g. @Annie_Mck & @KesterHynds thank @YOURNAMEHERE for generous support bringing 'On The Other Side I Found Myself Standing' to @VAULTFestival

£5 Personalised Instagram Story
A personalised image of the cast and tagged Insta story on Annie & Kester’s Instagram accounts. 

£10 Instagram Story + Tweet
A personalised tweet and a personal Insta story on Annie & Kester’s Twitter and Instagram accounts. 

£10 'On The Other Side I Found Myself Standing' Badge
A stunning custom badge to treasure forever!

£20 'On The Other Side I Found Myself Standing' Badge + Insta Story + Tweet
A wonderful custom badge plus a Tweet and an Instagram story!

£50 Personalised Song (+ Badge + Insta + Tweet)
A personalised 30 second song recorded in the theatre space for you to share!

£100 Meet & Greet! (+ SONG + Badge + Insta + Tweet)
Meet the cast for a coffee and cake and get the opportunity to find out more about the work we are making, and why!

£250 Join A Rehearsal (+ SONG + Badge + Insta + Tweet)
Come and join us for an afternoon rehearsal to get a real insight into how we work and what we are creating. Then we'll pop for a coffee and cake for a Q&A and discussion.

£500 Supporters Dinner (+ SONG + Badge + Insta + Tweet)
Join the cast and producer for delicious 3-course (sober) dinner cooked by MasterChef semi-finalist Annie McKenzie. Annie will be joined by musician Kester Hynds and producer Jessica McVay.  

 

WORKSHOPS 

£650 — 6hr movement and clowning workshop (10 person entry)
A one day movement and clowning workshop facilitated by Annie McKenzie with live music by Kester Hynds, using techniques and discovery processes from the show.
Up to 10 people may attend. Date TBC. 

£75 — 6hr movement and clowning workshop (1 person entry)
A one day movement and clowning workshop facilitated by Annie McKenzie with live music by Kester Hynds, using techniques and discovery processes from the show.

 

SPONSORSHIP

£250 - Sponsorship Pack 1  (+ SONG Badge + Insta + Tweet)
Your business name listed as a supporter in the programme for one year. Your business name and link listed on the supporters section on the official production website for one year. 

£500 - Sponsorship Pack 2  (+ SONG Badge + Insta + Tweet)
A quarter page advert featured in the programme for on year. Your business name, logo and link listed on the featured supporters section on the official production website for one year. 

£1000 - Sponsorship Pack 3  (+ SONG Badge + Insta + Tweet)
A half page advert featured in all programmes for one year. Your business name, logo and link displayed in the website footer and on the featured supporters section on the official production website for one year. 

 

The impact

The £2000 we are asking for is really the difference between making the project, and not.

We are putting together a very talented team of artists to make this work. We want it to have a lasting social impact to both recovering addicts and the wider public and we want to do this to the best of our ability.

 

Other ways you can help

If you can't help us financially, that's no problem. Tweet, Facebook and Instagram our show as much as you can to get the word out there - make some noise! And share our campaign as much as you can to get the word out there. We'll be forever grateful!

See you on the other side. 

Love, Annie and Kester. X

Your business name, logo and link listed on the featured supporters section on the official production website for one year. £1000 - Sponsorship Pack 3  (+ SONG Badge + Insta + Tweet)A half page advert featured in all programmes for one year. Your business name, logo and link displayed in the website footer and on the featured supporters section on the official production website for one year.  The impactThe £2000 we are asking for is really the difference between making the project, and not.We are putting together a very talented team of artists to make this work. We want it to have a lasting social impact to both recovering addicts and the wider public and we want to do this to the best of our ability. Other ways you can helpIf you can't help us financially, that's no problem. Tweet, Facebook and Instagram our show as much as you can to get the word out there - make some noise! And share our campaign as much as you can to get the word out there. We'll be forever grateful!See you on the other side. Love, Annie and Kester. X

story:
What is "theatre magic"?

Since its inception, Kidz Theater has been asking this question.  What is "theatre magic"?  How do you achieve that "x factor"?

When Kristen Caesar, artistic director, began the company in San Diego in the late 90s, she set out on a quest to make that magic tangible for young performers.  Kidz Theater, its performers, and its staff have now spanned two coasts and over two decades on a quest to find what each performer's brand of magic is.  With a passionate leader in Kristen and a love for the art form of musical theater in each person who comes to Kidz Theater, our quest to make magic tangible becomes more and more real for a new child every single day.

But we can't do it alone.

When Magic Meets Reality

The cost of producing a show in New York City is high.  Like--insanely high.

Money goes toward the rights for shows, rehearsal space, theater rentals, props, costumes, transport rentals, lighting, sound, and pretty much everything else you can think of that goes into making a show. 

And with a broad pool of talent in the tri-state area, we want to remain low cost and accessible to performers so that no child or teen who comes to us wanting to learn is turned away by the cost of tuition.  Thus was born our scholarship program.  We need to make sure we can keep our scholarships so that our program never becomes only for the people who can pay.  

Why Should I Care?

Kidz Theater is one of the only educational theater programs in New York City that offers professional training through productions and classes.  Not only that, Kidz Theater offers opportunities for kids and teens to work behind the scenes; such as board operation, stage management, sound design, and producing. 

Our alumn are currently at musical theater programs across the country, on tour with major productions such as Frozen and Dear Evan Hansen, and have appeared on Broadway in Dear Evan Hansen, Diana, The Cher Show, West Side Story, among others.

Kidz Theater also provides a home for several kids and teens that need the space to grow and evolve as performers.  Our disappearance would cause the performing arts in New York City to suffer greatly.

It Won't Be Easy

Money is tight.  We get it.  But with a network of over 500 alumni (who have gone on to be performers, stage managers, or even doctors), and parents (whose careers span the gamut), we know you all believe in Kidz Theater.  And we know you can get others to believe in Kidz Theater, because our work speaks for itself.

I'm SO Broke.  How Else Can I Help?

The best thing you can do is spread the word.  Share this campaign on your Twitter, or Insta, or Finsta, or wherever you can.  Call your friends and dictate the url to them out loud if you have to.  But word of mouth has always been first and foremost how Kidz Theater survives.

Also, we are always looking for the donations of goods/services to add to our incentives to donate.  If you can offer a 1-hour private lesson, or tickets to a Broadway show; anything that can enrich this campaign and the performers we know (and those we don't, yet!), that is a welcome service.

story:
Scroll down for BSL Video

Who are we?...

Hot Coals Theatre formed, in 2012, of core members Clare-Louise English and Jo Sargeant. We met whilst studying together on the first ever year of the MA Theatre Lab course at RADA.

We, Hot Coals Theatre, believe in theatre, we believe in the power of theatre to change the world, but we believe we can do it with a lightness of touch and with laughter: laugh at us, to laugh at life. 

We are a clown, mask and physical theatre company who takes inspiration from the likes of Charlie Chaplin. His sensitivity and detailed work is something we try to emulate and his belief in tackling hard-hitting issues with the lightest of touch sits right at the core of our work.

As one deaf and one hearing performer, accessibility is close to our hearts and we make work that is inclusive to Deaf and hearing audiences in a shared experience.

“This is an emotionally engaging & beautifully presented story...A truly beautiful piece of theatre” 

★★★★Spy in the Stalls 

A brief synopsis...

Once upon a time, deep in the heart of the forest, a woodcutter goes about life in a world of woodland magic. One day a stranger knocks at his door bringing with her a most unexpected of spells... But when the pressures of social expectation worms its way between them, bringing confusion to their hearts, a choice must be made; stay and conform or run and be free...

Expect laughter and tears in this poignant, moving, fairy tale of love and longing which will capture your heart, using physical theatre, clown and mask.

Meet our wonderful Patron Caroline Parker MBE who has a little message for our BSL (British Sign Language) followers:

 

 

 

Our Mission!

Edinburgh is undoubtedly one of the most expensive festivals to be a part of and though we have some funds, there is a shortfall we need your help with.

Being programmed by such an exciting and respected venue puts us in a superb position to be able to gather interest for our international tour. With your help we can make the absolute most of this opportunity.

We have managed to raise the first chunk of what we need to pay deposits for our accommodation and for the venue, insurances, and marketing. However, we still need to cover two important areas:

Balance of our accommodation cost: £1450 

Team (technical Stage Manager + designers): £2500

Help us to spread the word about accessible theatre by supporting our campaign and we will be grateful… forever!

Have a look at the perks we’ve got for you and support if you can, or share if you can’t.

The Impact: Help us go global!

Having toured the UK with Knock Knock, in Spring 2020 we plan to take our show across the world touring as far a field as the US, China and Australia.
Edinburgh Festival Fringe is a gateway to the rest of the world with 1000’s of representatives from venues across the globe coming together in one place, for one month, actively looking for shows to programme back home. We have to be there!

"Knock Knock represents the new school of disability theatre: raw, entertaining, integrated"

View From the Cheap Seat

Risks & Challenges

Of course, as with any ambitious project there comes a certain amount of risk, mostly financial. Edinburgh Festival is an enormous festival, with hundreds of shows competing for audiences. 

However, we do have a plan and we have done a lot of the leg work already to minimise this risk, and this is why we are here asking for your support...

If we are able to raise the funds to secure the bulk of our expenses before we go, we can minimise the risk. Making sure we have funds set in place to pay our team, means we do not need to rely on unpredictable ticket sales. Paying for our accommodation upfront means we won't be handed a large bill after, and so on.

We don't expect for the festival to make us rich (although, that would be lovely), but that is not the aim of this run. The aim is more long term than that. It's to reach out across the world and let them know we are here, making great, Inclusive work, that they want to share with their audiences back home.

Other Ways You Can Help

Everyone knows someone who likes  to go to a show, or has a friend who lives in Edinburgh, or that person who loves a good cause, or even knows someone who is d/Deaf who may not know about us yet!

If you can't support us financially but are keen to get involved. Then please share this campaign with your networks and spread the word. Think of those you know who might be interested in supporting or evening buying tickets! Every share, every email might just get us that little bit closer!

Thank you!

Jo and Clare

Thank you!

story:
Refreshingly honest and laced with dark humor, The Woman in the Mirror play stands as a testament to personal strength and resiliency in the face of extraordinary and unexpected circumstances.

When her mother was diagnosed with Alzheimer’s disease, Houston media personality Dayna Steele began posting messages on Facebook detailing the alarming and shocking struggles she and her family were experiencing. With biting humor and raw emotion, the posts and now play provide caregivers and future caregivers with an on-stage manual to navigate the disease with love, laughter, and wine. 

The Woman in the Mirror Store

The Woman in the Mirror is written and directed by Houston theatre veteran Marley Singletary and co-produced by Melissa Stevens. Stevens is the widow of famous Houston radio personality Mark Stevens (KLOL) who lost his life to this nasty disease as well. 

Any amount we raise will go towards making this a quality production for Houston audiences. This will cover lighting, set design, sound design, stage crew, marketing and public relations, and an opening night appreciation party. The entire amount will allow us to do a Broadway-worthy production for eleven performances at MATCH in Houston in November of 2020 and then prepare to take it to other cities.

UPDATE: We are creating a filmed Zoom table read that will be produced in several episodes and then available on a video as well as a podcast platform. This is a way for us to start during COVID-19, rehearse, raise funds, and bring this story to the public.

The Woman in the Mirror is intended to give the audience permission to live and laugh and love and cry and rage at Alzheimer’s. In addition, the book also contained practical information relevant to anyone who has a family member suffering from Alzheimer’s. This will carry over to the stage presentation with a talkback after each performance with a variety of consulting experts from neurology, assisted living, long-term care, insurance, and elder law. 

With Dayna's loyal following of "Steeleworkers" from her radio days to the readers of Surviving Alzheimer's with Friends, Facebook, and a Really Big Glass of Wine to her Your Daily Success Tip subscribers,  we hope to make an impact on Houston theatre-goers as well as help caregivers know they are not alone and not forgotten. 

Follow us on Instagram and Facebook for more.

story:
Our Story

Möbius Dance is a Leeds based dance company that supports and nurtures talented, up-and-coming dance artists and choreographers both creatively and practically. 

Möbius Dance helps early career dance artists grow artistically and break down the barriers faced at the beginning of their careers by offering quality employment prospects.

Founded in 2016 by Artistic Director Gianluca Vincentini, we place dance at the heart of our activities, productions and outreach and offer spaces to learn, discover and rediscover, be challenged and be moved.  

This project will offer an amazing opportunity for each participant to be empowered in their learning process, and to take full ownership of their work, as they are given access to a new international scene.

We will encourage skills development and practice sharing through: open classes lead by the Artistic Director and the dancers; discussions; rehearsal exchanges. 

The project will also create opportunities to engage the Malaysian and UK public via open rehearsals and class. During our residency the public can drop in for an hour and be given a real behind-the-scenes experience. We will lead informal Q&A session with attendees. They can also decide to sketch or simply enjoy the rehearsal. 

Please feel free to share the campaign with dance, education and culture lovers, and with anyone who might be interested to entrepreneurially invest in a company that believes in making inclusive and ethical change. 

What We Need 

We need to raise £4000. Your contribution will go towards the flight tickets for four dancers and our artistic director. 

Although £4000 is a really big target, we have already secured accommodation, per-diems, salaries and visa for the dancers and our AD. 

Supporting this project means that you will facilitate activities to support the next generation of artists and shape the future of arts, and making a contribution towards the development of culture. 

Other Ways You Can Help

We please ask you to share and advocate our work with family, friends and colleagues. Get the word out and make some noise for us. Share our website and the other ways you can support us. 

 

VERSIONE IN ITALIANO

La Nostra Storia

Fondata e diretta da Gianluca Vincentini, la compagnia di danza Möbius Dance (MD) sviluppa e propone innovativi programmi di formazione professionale nell’ambito della danza contemporanea grazie alla possibilità di prendere parte ad un repertorio originale ed esclusivo creato appositamente per la compagnia da coreografi sia affermati che emergenti, di fama nazionale ed internazionale. 

Questo progetto offre un'incredibile opportunità per ciascun partecipante di essere supportato nel proprio processo di apprendimento in modo da trarne il maggiore arricchimento possibile e da assumersi la piena responsabilità del proprio lavoro, esponendolo allo sguardo di un pubblico internazionale. 

I partecipanti beneficeranno di un'esperienza preziosa, avranno la possibilità di lavorare ad un progetto vasto, articolato ed altamente professionale, potranno confrontarsi con nuove realtà e nuovi occhi espandendo il loro concetto di danza. Tutto questo dando spazio alle collaborazioni, incoraggiando la partecipazione attiva alla produzione e valorizzando esecuzione e messa in scena. 

Inoltre il progetto vuole ampliare la rete collaborativa tra i professionisti italiani e chi opera all’estero, creando nuove opportunità di studio, lavoro e ricerca sia sul piano organizzativo che creativo e performativo. 

Sentitevi liberi di condividere la campagna con gli amanti della danza, dell'istruzione e della cultura e con chiunque possa essere interessato a investire in modo imprenditoriale in una compagnia che crede in un cambiamento inclusivo ed etico.

Di cosa abbiamo bisogno

Il motivo per cui abbiamo deciso di contare sulla generosità di amici, conoscenti, o chiunque verrà in contatto con la nostra storia, è che – nonostante i contributi di enti pubblici e personali della compagnia – non abbiamo abbastanza fondi per coprire il tutto: in aggiunta all’attuale contributo rimangono 4.000 Sterline.

Qualunque sia il risultato di questa nostra raccolta fondi, vorremmo ringraziare chiunque dimostrerà interesse e supporto, per noi significa molto.

story:
The Project                              

    A Thread is the latest project by Jean Abreu Dance and is an international collaboration with the celebrated artist and sculptor from Sao Paulo, Elisa Bracher and it is for this extraordinary and ambitious collaboration that  we ask you for your generous help and support in the completion and premier of this production in Brazil ,at the "Auditorio Ibirapuera" in Sao Paulo.

    A Thread brings together Jean Abreu’s intense and visceral choreographic language with gravity-defying, brutal sculptures by acclaimed Brazilian artist Elisa Bracher.  This hour long performance is a powerful exploration of the concept of Balance which takes the audience on an emotional journey following an incredible cast of 5 virtuoso international dance artists in a heroic attempt to find balance. The piece subliminally hints at the Greek mythological story of Sisyphuswho carries the weight of a rock up the hill for eternity as punishment for cheating the gods.

    “Each atom of that stone, each mineral flake of that night filled mountain, in itself forms a world. The struggle itself toward the heights is enough to fill a man's heart. One must imagine Sisyphus happy” ‪‎Albert Camus ‪ The Myth of Sisyphus

    Ultimately A Thread deals with an universal question, that of our own weight and our sense of balance, weight that we carry through life, our bodies, and the Balance that we endlessly try to achieve. The show features specially commissioned music by the Ukrainian Composer Heinali  (Oleg Shpudeiko) which will be performed by two live musicians (viola & Theorbo ) together with 16th century Baroque music - Johan Downland and Montiverdi .

    The Pitch 

    A Thread world premier in Sao Paulo , what do we need and why:

    Since July 2015 we have been in ongoing discussions with the world famous “Auditorio Ibirabuera” Concert Hall in Sao Paulo, one of Brazils most prestigious and beautiful  performance venues at the heart of Sao Paulo which was designed by the renowned architect Oscar Niemeyer .Auditorio Ibirapuera  wishes to host the premier A Thread on the 15th and 16th of April 2016. We  are truly ecstatic  with this incredible opportunity  to premier A Thread and presenting the piece in a world class venue will give the project the right push we so need for its success .  We don't want to miss this opportunity and that is why we are reaching out to you.

                                  

    Despite the financial support already offered by institutions both in Brazil ( Itau Cultural Foundation)and UK( Arts Council of Englandand the British Council   )we are short of the necessary funds to complete and premier this exciting project.   The performance fees and expenses we are offered for the show only cover half of the real costs to take a large group abroad. In order to make this performance in Sao Paulo to the highest standard and make most of this extraordiniray opportunity we need to raise a further £12 000 to take on the road a total of 11 people

    Help us to achieve our goal please support A Thread world premier in Sao Paulo at the Auditorio Ibirapuera on 15th and 16th of april 2016.

    Your help will directly support artist travels as well as logistic and productions cost , rehearsal space, expenses and accommodation costs allowing us to complete the journey of this incredible  Project 

    About Us

    Jean Abreu Dance

    Jean Abreu Dance was founded in 2009 ,with the generous support of the ArtsCouncil of England ,as a vehicle to produce and widely present the work of Artistic Director and Choreographer Jean Abreu .What Inspire the company in producing and making work is the strong desire to collaborate with a diverse range of artists and genres. Creating provocative and emotionally powerful dance performance that challenges and captivates audiences across the globe 

    Jean Abreu is originally from Brazil and came to London in 1996 after winning a scholarship to study at the Trinity Laban Conservatory of Music and Dance and he has lived in London ever since.Jean choreographed his first work in 2003 and later that year was honoured with the Jerwood Choreography Award. Since then, his work has toured throughout the UK, Europe, USA, China and Brazil including performances for London Dance Umbrella, Young Vic Theatre, Southbank Centre and the Royal Opera House in London. Jean Abreu collaborated with Math rock band 65daysofstatic on INSIDE which premiered at the Edinburgh Festival in 2010 to rave reviews .

    ****"brutally visceral" The List 

    ****"Dark, atmospheric and utterly absorbing" The Scotsman

    His most recent work BLOOD was commissioned by the Royal Opera House and was a major collaboration with the British visual Artist Gilbert and George.

    How your donation will help the company and how we will spend it:

    The raised funds will allow Jean Abreu Dance and artist Elisa Bracher to work together for a final week of rehearsals prior the premier at Auditorio Ibirapuera at her studio, which will be transformed in a temporary dance studio so the company and the artist  can finalize A Thread.

    The funds will be utilized to pay for 

    11 Airfare tickets -London to Sao Paulo - for 5 dancers , 2 musicians , 2 technicians , 1 tour manager, 1 Artistic Director  in total £ £8,110

    Food expenses £1,320

    UK airport transfers £350

    Visas for the company £150

    Production cost for the sculpture £820

    Production & travel insurance - £600

     Rehearsal Space UK £650

    Total spending £12,000

    Choose how to help us –  here come The Perks

    Whatever level of support you are able to give is accepted with the upmost appreciation. You choose how much you can help and be sure that you will get a fantastic perk in exchange for your generosity.

    From the downloadable Sound Track of A Thread specially composed by Heinali to exclusive video links for diaries from the rehearsal process in Sao Paulo, personalised thank you messages so you can share with friends  as well as post cards from Sao Paulo cards singed  and send by us all 

    We are also offering signed special edition 30 x 30 cm framed photographs of the company in action    

                 


    And 4 of you will be lucky enough to be treated to an exclusive access to the studio in London or Sao Paulo to watch some of the rehearsals talk to the artists and be treated to drinks and light refreshments.

    For the Art collectors ,6 limited Edition print work (60 x60 cm) donated by Elisa Bracher and made especially for the project.( example of the print)

                             


    Get Clicking !

    For all of you who will make this amazing gesture of supporting  us we will keep you informed about the project .For those who wish to support us but are not able to do it this time , or maybe this project is not for you , never mind , please share with a friend that might be in a position or inclined to do so . 

    All money raised will go a long way to get us closer to our desired  funding target and to reach our goal to take A Thread to have its worlds premier in Soa Paulo. Your help can make sure this project will go ahead!

    Thank you for taking the time to look at our Indigogo campaign 


 Jean Abreu dance 
Non for Profit Registered Company in England and Wales. 
Company No. 6989520
Board of Directors
Vera Dantes 
Sean Cross
Mat Heinl
story_txt:
The Project                              
A Thread is the latest project by Jean Abreu Dance and is an international collaboration with the celebrated artist and sculptor from Sao Paulo, Elisa Bracher and it is for this extraordinary and ambitious collaboration that  we ask you for your generous help and support in the completion and premier of this production in Brazil ,at the "Auditorio Ibirapuera" in Sao Paulo.
A Thread brings together Jean Abreu’s intense and visceral choreographic
language with gravity-defying, brutal sculptures by acclaimed Brazilian artist
Elisa Bracher.  This hour long performance is a powerful exploration
of the concept of Balance which takes the audience on an emotional journey
following an incredible cast of 5 virtuoso international dance artists in a
heroic attempt to find balance. The piece
subliminally hints at the Greek mythological story of Sisyphuswho carries the weight of a rock up the hill for eternity as
punishment for cheating the gods.


“Each
atom of that stone, each mineral flake of that night filled mountain, in itself
forms a world. The struggle itself toward the heights is enough to fill a man's
heart. One must imagine Sisyphus happy” ‪‎Albert Camus ‪ The Myth of Sisyphus
Ultimately A Thread deals with an universal question, that of our own
weight and our sense of balance, weight that we carry through life, our
bodies, and the Balance that we endlessly try to achieve. The show features specially commissioned music by the
Ukrainian Composer Heinali   (Oleg Shpudeiko) which will be performed by two live musicians (viola &
Theorbo ) together with 16th century Baroque music - Johan Downland and Montiverdi .
The Pitch 

A Thread world premier in Sao Paulo , what do we need and why:
Since July 2015 we have been in ongoing discussions with the world
famous “Auditorio Ibirabuera” Concert Hall in Sao Paulo, one of Brazils most
prestigious and beautiful  performance venues at the heart of Sao Paulo which was designed by the renowned architect  Oscar Niemeyer  .Auditorio Ibirapuera  wishes to host the premier A Thread on
the 15th and 16th of April 2016. We  are truly ecstatic  with this incredible opportunity  to premier A Thread and presenting the piece in a world class venue will give the project the right push we so need for its success .  We don't want to miss this opportunity and that is why we are reaching out to you.

                              
Despite the financial support already offered by institutions
both in Brazil ( Itau Cultural Foundation)and UK( Arts Council of Englandand the British Council   )we are short of the necessary funds to complete and premier this exciting project.  
The performance fees and
expenses we are offered for the show only cover half of the real costs to take
a large group abroad. In order to make this performance in Sao Paulo to the highest
standard and make most of this extraordiniray opportunity we need to raise a
further £12 000 to take on the road a
total of 11 people
Help us to achieve our
goal please support A Thread world premier in Sao Paulo at the Auditorio Ibirapuera on 15th and 16th of
april 2016.
Your help will directly support artist travels as well as logistic and productions cost , rehearsal space, expenses and accommodation costs allowing us to complete the journey of this incredible  Project

Jean Abreu Dance

Creating provocative and emotionally powerful dance performance that challenges and captivates audiences across the globe 
Jean Abreu is originally from Brazil and came to London in 1996 after winning a scholarship to study at the Trinity Laban Conservatory of Music and Dance and he has lived in London ever since.Jean choreographed his first work in 2003 and later that year was honoured with the Jerwood Choreography Award. Since then, his work has toured throughout the UK, Europe, USA, China and Brazil including performances for London Dance Umbrella, Young Vic Theatre, Southbank Centre and the Royal Opera House in London. Jean Abreu collaborated with Math rock band 65daysofstatic on INSIDE which premiered at the Edinburgh Festival in 2010 to rave reviews .
****"brutally visceral" The List 
****"Dark, atmospheric and utterly absorbing" The Scotsman
His most recent work BLOOD was commissioned by the Royal Opera House and was a major collaboration with the British visual Artist Gilbert and George.

story:
Short Summary

Lost Paradise is a modern dance version of the jukebox musical format, taking 5 previously choreographed works, weaving them with new choreographic/theatrical material, and creating a new narrative, which strives to question our never ending quest(s) in finding our perfect mate: the One. How honest are we in our search? Is the persona we present to people we meet the real 'us', or a made up version to hide our true self? The project is an immersive experience for audiences: not where audiences just sit and assume the role of a typical passive dance viewer. It combines modern dance choreography, acting, both live singing, lip-syncing and karaoke, live-feed video and projection, allowing the public to witness, participate, and engage in the unfolding and development of the performance: building a active relationship with all the participants in the room.

Slippage is a new 30-minute dance film which has been directed by actor/director, Jason Kaufman, and choreographed by Maurice Fraga. Slippage started in 2003 in NYC, exploring the boundaries of female to female partnering work. Through many investigations and performances, Slippage has finally evolved to its final state: a physically demanding trio for women, with contact improvisational derived movement, where the movement is brutal, rough, challenging, yet also gentle and calm, and where the protagonist must find a final resolution to a traumatic memory  that haunts her.

UPDATE: March 9th, Slippage has earned an Award of Merit Special Mention (Experimental Category) from The Accolade Global Film Competition!

What We Need & What You Get

Ekilibre Dance Company (EDCO) was founded in 2006 as the vision and project of choreographer Maurice Fraga. Since its founding, EDCO has continued to develop its activities and profile within the United States and abroad. In 2015, Artistic Director, Maurice Fraga, received a residency grant at the Djerassi Resident Artist Program to focus in on his choreographic theory and process, which eventually lead to his investigation on finding new and innovative ways to interact with audiences.

Having a dance company is an uphill battle to undertake: getting committed and strong dancers to work for minimal compensation, convincing producers to give you a chance to shine, attracting audiences, and of course, finding funding. EDCO is creating this campaign in support of our work, which includes Lost Paradise, and Slippage. We are aiming to raise the money to help cover production costs and film festival submissions.

Our $2,500 goal is nothing close to the total needed, but we want to make sure we create a successful campaign to cover some costs. 

The Impact

EDCO does NOT currently receive ANY funding (government or private) for the work we produce and present: all costs are paid out by the Artistic Director himself or through any donations giving by supporters. Contributions made to this campaign will allow the company to take another step forward in being able to set up a foundation that will allow EDCO to become a true 501(c)3, begin applying for national and state grants, and ensure that the company is able to keep presenting works.

A lack of tangible experience for the audience inevitably, distances them from engaging in the work, and too often, modern dance choreographers and companies settle and create this type of one-sided performance event. I believe that by creating work that connects to audiences on an emotional and human level, giving them a felt experience, will allow them to see how modern dance can reflect small and large aspects of their lives, ultimately creating an interest in seeing and supporting more dance. Our work is about changing the perception of modern dance, not following the status quo.

What You Get

By donating to our campaign, we would like you to think of it as an investment and not just a handout. You are becoming a friend and a supporter of not just our company, but of dance, and of culture. You are investing in helping Ekilibre and its dancers make a difference, and begin a change in the perception of modern dance. 

You support will allow us to make inroads in how to dance can have a larger and more apparent affect on the lives of those performing the works, and those witnessing them. 

It would be wonderful to be able to live in a society that think of our jobs as "real" jobs and not just hobbies: we do work hard. Just because what we create is not mass produced and sold for commercial use, does not mean it is not valid and important.

We encourage you to donate what you can, and not just think about what item or prize you will get in return. Think about the long-term effect of your contribution, and how it will enable us to begin our dance revolution. 

Other Ways You Can Help

Even if you can't contribute financially to this campaign, please help by sharing this fundraising effort to anyone who might have an interest in supporting the arts and one that will be making an impact in other ways.

story:
About the creator/director of ONIRIA TANGO

Hello, my name is Diana Cruz. I have dedicated my entire life to dance as a performance art; creating, choreographing, performing, instructing...  but most importantly: Learning.  Oniria Tango is part of this learning process, both literally and metaphorically.

I grew up in Paraguay, learning from the best dance teachers in the country. In 2006 I left my country to continue pursuing my dance career.  While living in Argentina, I fell in love with Tango.  Ever since I have been traveling around the world, with my Tango partner Nicholas Jones (together we are NaturalTango) instructing, performing and choreographing for dance productions and festivals. I am currently based in Denver, CO.


ABOUT THIS PROJECT

Now, for the first time, I am producing, directing, co-choreographing, and dancing    my dream dance concert! Oniria Tango, a glimpse into an intense culture, through the lens of Argentine Tango dance, music and painting.

I gathered some of the best Tango Artists in the world. I flew to Argentina to define concepts and start working with the dancers and painter, based in Buenos Aires; I am now flying them all here,  to Denver, CO, to share a stage for the first time in this production.

A life-size Mural (24ft X 8ft) will be painted ON STAGE, depicting captivating images of Tango, South America passion and mythology. The tango dancers will translate the story of the Mural through the power, passion, and grace of their movement.


THE MAGNITUD OF YOUR CONTRIBUTION

I have my entire life invested in this event, artistically and financially. I have reached my personal financial limit putting together many elements of this massive production. The goal amount of this campaign reflects only about 30% of the full budget required. The NaturalTango Festival, (a social dance event that I manage annually), is turning all its profit to the Oniria Tango production. A successful ticket-sales on the three shows should hopefully cover another percentage of the expenses.  YOUR CONTRIBUTION WILL COMPLETE THIS PROJECT and make it come to life!


WHAT MY PROJECT NEEDS TO SUCCESSFULLY COME TO LIFE

  • Theatre Rental (2 dress-rehearsal days and 3 show nights)
  • Lighting equipment and personnel 
  • Stage Manager
  • Sound Technician 
  • Dancers Fees (9 dancers)
  • Painter Fee (painting a 24 feet x 8 feet mural and the costumes for the show)
  • Mural art and Body art painting materials
  • Costumes
  • Props and Backdrops
  • Plane tickets
  • USA  Visas 
  • Photos and videos
  • Advertising/Printing (graphic designer, fliers, posters, programs)
  • Per Diem for the artists


WHAT YOU GET

Besides making possible that this unique production gets on stage and open its curtains, your contribution will be rewarded with exciting perks!


HELP SPREAD THE WORD!

Whether you can contribute or not, thank you for reading about the project, your interest is a meaningful support. Spreading the word is just as valuable to me as donating. Please, email this campaign to people who might be interested in contributing. Please, post it on your social media pages and profiles. THANK YOU!!
