story:
Short Summary

Actor/Director/Educator Mihaly Szabados brings his talent for children's entertainment to 2016 Fringe Kids Festival.  Come see us there between June 29th and July 10th at the George Ignatieff Theatre.

As I watch my daughter grow up, I remember all the fears I used to have growing up.  You remember, you had them too.  Fears of the dark, fears of spiders, or snakes, or shadows, or imaginary monsters under your bed.  With Iza the Brave, we will be bringing the world premiere of a fun and educational musical comedy to Toronto.  This is a collective creation where your kids and mine can laugh, and sing, and dance their fears away with us and our Monster friends.


                                       

           Iza the Brave 

   The New musical for Children                   Ages 6 and up


Cast and co-writers:

Iza:                                     Amaka Umeh

Nicholas, Iza's Dad:     Deshay Padayachey

Barbara:                           Jada Rifkin

Giuseppina:                      Maiza Dubhé

Monsters:

Momster:                          Samantha Chaulk

HariYet:                             Sarah Marchand

Rebookah:                        Micaela Comeau

Music by: 

Micaela Comeau & Samantha Chaulk

Writer, Director, Producer:

Mihaly Szabados


                                                 PERFORMANCE LIST:

 At the George Ignatieff Theatre 

                           15 Devonshire Place, Toronto, ON M5S 2C8

Friday, July 1st   1:45 PM

Saturday, July 2nd   3:45 PM

Monday, July 4th   10:00 AM

Wednesday, July 6th   1:15 PM

Thursday, July 7th   4:15 PM

Friday, July 8th    10:00 AM

Saturday, July 9th   3:00 PM


Amaka Umeh:

Since graduating from Randolph Academy's Triple Threat College Program (Narrator in Into the Woods; George W. Bush in Stuff Happens), Amaka Umeh has performed at Hart House Theatre (Ariel in The Tempest; Marianne Bachmeier in This is for You, Anna), Lower Ossington Theatre (ensemble in Jesus Christ Superstarand Hairspray), Toronto Fringe and Next Stage Theatre Festival (All Our Yesterdays).  All Our Yesterdays received the Patron's Pick Award and an Honourable Mention in the Best of Fringe Awards for 2015.  This was Amaka's first time co-creating a show and she cannot wait to do it again! She would like to thank Mishy, The Real Iza, and this Brave cast for their kindness, humor, and devotion – and her precious friends and family, for supporting and taking care of her.

Deshay Padayachey:

Hailing from Australia, Deshay studied Acting at QUT and Improv at the Second City Training Centre, Toronto. His credits include the Fox TV Series Terra Nova, Netflix Kids Series Mako Mermaids,  Feature film The Little Things and the upcoming film No Boys Allowed. He’s performs on stage with the sketch group No Revolutions. 

Jada Rifkin:

Jada is a Toronto-based actor, singer, and dancer. For Toronto Fringe: Lenora in Quarter Life Crisis the Musical (Dora Award for Best Female Performance at Toronto Fringe Festival 2015), Muse in Busyness (Fringe Kids - 2014). Other recent theatre credits include: Mrs. Blewett in Anne of Green Gables (LOT), Lisa in Mute the Musical (GTA Tour), Queen of Hearts in Alice in Wonderland & Sher Khan in Jungle Book (Qatar and Singapore Tour, Creativiva Inc.). Randolph Academy Graduate. Catch Jada in King of the Castle at Factory Mainspace also at the Toronto Fringe this year!

Maiza Dubhé: 

Maïza has completed her training in Acting and Physical Theater in New York City and Montréal. Since then, she has worked on stage: Spade Theatre's Waiting For the Parade, Felix (Chocolate Moose Theatre Co at the Montreal Fringe), on film: Science ou Fiction? (TV5)  P.O.R.N.O.(Unis TV), and the webseries Le client a toujours raison. She recently relocated to Toronto and is one of the leads in MAD Resilience Films' upcoming project, Pardonnez-moi mon père. This is the first time Maïza is doing a show with real monsters, ever. And she is horribly happy about it.

Micaela Comeau:


Micaela Comeau is new to Toronto but definitely not new to the performing world. She has been acting, singing, dancing, and playing piano and ukelele since very young and and she revels in every opportunity to work in the arts. She is also a teacher (piano, ukelele, voice, musical theatre and dance) and a singer/songwriter, as well as a playwright of children's musicals and she has been running these musicals in Nova Scotia for the past four years. She moved to Toronto last year to bring them here. Micaela is excited to be working with the very talented, open-minded, and creative group of individuals involved in "Iza the Brave."


Sarah Marchand: 

Sarah is an MA graduate from the University of Toronto’s Centre for Drama, Theatre and Performance Studies. She holds a BFA in Theatre Performance and Honours English Literature from Concordia University. In 2013, she received the Hnatyshyn Foundation’s Emerging Artist Grant in English Theatre. Sarah has worked on diverse projects ranging from burlesque, Beijing Opera and clown. Sarah loves performing for young audiences and has had a blast helping to create this show. You can also catch her in Birthday Cake, happening at the TO 2016 fringe. Follow her at sarahmarchand.com! 

Samantha Chaulk:

Please be a part of this amazing show so Iza can face Rebookah Monster, Momster, and HairYel.  Bring your kids, grand-kids, nieces, nephews, stepchildren, neighbour's children (with permission), students, student's children, grand-nieces, grand-nephews, and of course, your inner child!

Links:

https://www.facebook.com/Iza-the-Brave-82804664...

 https://www.facebook.com/Mihaly-Szabados-Official-140292076108547

What We Need & What You Get

With your help, we can help pay:
The entrance fee,
Rehearsal space rentals,
Monster assembly,
Costumes and props, 
Musical director, 
Publicity, advertisement, 
Keeping the monsters fed so they don't eat Iza!

Other Ways You Can Help

Some people just can't contribute,and that's okay.  But that doesn't mean you can't help:

  • Ask folks to get the word out and make some noise about our campaign.
  • Remind them to use the Indiegogo share tools!

And that's all there is to it.  Thank you all for your help!
story_txt:
Short Summary 
Actor/Director/Educator Mihaly Szabados brings his talent for children's entertainment to 2016 Fringe Kids Festival.  Come see us there between June 29th and July 10th at the George Ignatieff Theatre.
As I watch my daughter grow up, I remember all the fears I used to have growing up.  You remember, you had them too.  Fears of the dark, fears of spiders, or snakes, or shadows, or imaginary monsters under your bed.  With Iza the Brave, we will be bringing the world premiere of a fun and educational musical comedy to Toronto.  This is a collective creation where your kids and mine can laugh, and sing, and dance their fears away with us and our Monster friends.


                                       
           Iza the Brave 
   The New musical for Children                   Ages 6 and up

Cast and co-writers:

Iza:                                     Amaka Umeh
Nicholas, Iza's Dad:     Deshay Padayachey
Barbara:                           Jada Rifkin
Giuseppina:                      Maiza Dubhé
Monsters:
Momster:                          Samantha Chaulk
HariYet:                             Sarah Marchand
Rebookah:                        Micaela Comeau

Music by: 
Micaela Comeau & Samantha Chaulk

Writer, Director, Producer:
Mihaly Szabados

                                                 PERFORMANCE LIST:
 At
the George Ignatieff Theatre 
                           15 Devonshire Place, Toronto, ON M5S
2C8
Friday, July 1st
  1:45
PM
Saturday, July 2nd
  3:45
PM
Monday, July 4th
  10:00
AM
Wednesday, July 6th
  1:15 PM
Thursday, July 7th
  4:15 PM
Friday, July 8th
   10:00 AM
Saturday, July 9th
  3:00 PM





Amaka Umeh:

Since graduating from Randolph Academy's Triple Threat College Program (Narrator in Into the Woods; George W. Bush in Stuff Happens), Amaka Umeh has performed at Hart House Theatre (Ariel in The Tempest; Marianne Bachmeier in This is for You, Anna), Lower Ossington Theatre (ensemble in Jesus Christ Superstarand Hairspray), Toronto Fringe and Next Stage Theatre Festival (All Our Yesterdays).  All Our Yesterdays received the Patron's Pick Award and an Honourable Mention in the Best of Fringe Awards for 2015.  This was Amaka's first time co-creating a show and she cannot wait to do it again! She would like to thank Mishy, The Real Iza, and this Brave cast for their kindness, humor, and devotion – and her precious friends and family, for supporting and taking care of her.

Deshay Padayachey:

Hailing from Australia, Deshay studied Acting at QUT and Improv at the Second City Training Centre, Toronto. His credits include the Fox TV Series Terra Nova, Netflix Kids Series Mako Mermaids,  Feature film The Little Things and the upcoming film No Boys Allowed. He’s performs on stage with the sketch group No Revolutions. 

Jada Rifkin:

Jada is a Toronto-based actor, singer, and dancer. For Toronto Fringe: Lenora in Quarter Life Crisis the Musical (Dora Award for Best Female Performance at Toronto Fringe Festival 2015), Muse in Busyness (Fringe Kids - 2014). Other recent theatre credits include: Mrs. Blewett in Anne of Green Gables (LOT), Lisa in Mute the Musical (GTA Tour), Queen of Hearts in Alice in Wonderland & Sher Khan in Jungle Book (Qatar and Singapore Tour, Creativiva Inc.). Randolph Academy Graduate. Catch Jada in King of the Castle at Factory Mainspace also at the Toronto Fringe this year!

Maiza Dubhé: 

Maïza has completed her training in Acting and Physical Theater in New York City and Montréal. Since then, she has worked on stage: Spade Theatre's Waiting For the Parade, Felix (Chocolate Moose Theatre Co at the Montreal Fringe), on film: Science ou Fiction? (TV5)  P.O.R.N.O.(Unis TV), and the webseries Le client a toujours raison. She recently relocated to Toronto and is one of the leads in MAD Resilience Films' upcoming project, Pardonnez-moi mon père. This is the first time Maïza is doing a show with real monsters, ever. And she is horribly happy about it.

Micaela Comeau:


Micaela Comeau is new to Toronto but definitely not new to the performing world. She has been acting, singing, dancing, and playing piano and ukelele since very young and and she revels in every opportunity to work in the arts. She is also a teacher (piano, ukelele, voice, musical theatre and dance) and a singer/songwriter, as well as a playwright of children's musicals and she has been running these musicals in Nova Scotia for the past four years. She moved to Toronto last year to bring them here. Micaela is excited to be working with the very talented, open-minded, and creative group of individuals involved in "Iza the Brave."


Sarah Marchand: 


Sarah
is an MA graduate from the University of Toronto’s Centre for Drama, Theatre
and Performance Studies. She holds a BFA in Theatre Performance and Honours
English Literature from Concordia University. In 2013, she received the
Hnatyshyn Foundation’s Emerging Artist Grant in English Theatre. Sarah has
worked on diverse projects ranging from burlesque, Beijing Opera and clown.
Sarah loves performing for young audiences and has had a blast helping to
create this show. You can also catch her in Birthday Cake, happening at the TO
2016 fringe. Follow her at sarahmarchand.com!

story:
A Rare Opportunity To Make History

We're asking lovers of the theatre, of science fiction and fantasy, of brilliant, thought-provoking argument, to help us complete a very rare staging of one of the most unusual dramatic works in history-  George Bernard Shaw's Back to Methuselah!


The Washington Stage Guild, now in its 30th season, presents eloquent plays of idea and argument, passion and wit in downtown Washington, DC. The Stage Guild has gained international praise for its focus on the works of Irish playwright George Bernard Shaw, producing them nearly every year. 

To celebrate this landmark season we began a three-year project: to present a rare full production of Shaw's visionary, brilliant cycle of plays, Back To Methuselah, culminating in 2016 with the final installment. Methuselah is regarded as one of the first works of science fiction every written for the stage,  Given its scope, it's been rarely produced since its premiere; the Stage Guild's is only the third fully professional production of the entire cycle since its premiere in 1923.


As we approach the final, largest play in the cycle, we seek funding to allow us to cast and design it fittingly. The Washington Stage Guild is a 501(c)3 non-profit organization with an admirable history, its artistic excellence and managerial practices earning it a place in the 2015-16 DC Catalogue of Philanthropy.

http://cfp-dc.org/nonprofits/1465/Theatre-Downtown-Inc-t-a-The-Washington-Stage-Guild

"George Bernard Shaw’s rarely done epic play, Back to Methuselah, is a riveting and compelling stroke of drama. Broken into three parts and performed over a series of three seasons, Washington Stage Guild has undertaken a massive project with the production of this seldom produced Shavian epic. A strikingly intriguing piece of theatrical history that will unfold in Washington over the next three years, this is an extremely rare chance to witness the production of the play in its entirety." -- DC Theatre Scene


What We Need & What You Get

We need $25,000 to:

  •  Cover the salaries of the extra cast members needed
  • Design and execute costumes and special makeup called-for in the script
  • Produce an introductory video to recap the two earlier portions of the cycle.
  • Commission the special effects that are needed for the story.
  • Market the brilliant, quirky finale of the cycle.
  • Conclude the run with a revival of the earlier segments, allowing audiences to experience the entire cycle in a single week. 
Donors will be offered a number of perks in gratitude for their support, and will be acknowledged in the show's program. Donations are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.


What It Means 

George Bernard Shaw was a Nobel Prize winner and one of the most significant playwrights of the early modern era. Plays such as Pygmalion, Arms and The Man, and Saint Joan made him famous around the world. One of his most extraordinary works is Back To Methuselah, a cycle of plays that poses questions about humanity with brilliant wit and challenging ideas. The cycle begins with Adam and Eve in the Garden of Eden, and concludes 35,000 years in the future!


Because of its vast length Methuselah was originally performed over three evenings, but has rarely been produced at all. Aside from its New York premiere in 1923, only two or three other professional productions had been done before the Washington Stage Guild, internationally known for our expertise with the brilliant plays of GBS, decided on a three-year project of presenting the important plays, ending with the final part in our 30th season.

Who's It For?

Some of you may be able to attend the production. There are lovers of Shaw, ("Shavians") in all parts of the world, most of whom have never seen this visionary work. And its leap into the future as the plays proceed make it one of the first works of science fiction ever put on the stage. The sparkling dialogue and the exchange of ideas have seldom been equaled. 

A complete production now is woefully overdue for theatre-lovers, literature lovers, fantasy and science fiction lovers. And so as we approach the most challenging section of the cycle, we are asking for help from all those people! Whether you plan to come, or simply support the idea of a complete cycle, help us do justice to this production and bring a Back To Methuselah for our time to a wonderful conclusion. 


Other Ways You Can Help

If you can, help us reach as many people as possible!

  • Tell anyone you know about this exciting project and explain why it matters to you.
  • Use the Indiegogo share tools!

"Washington Stage Guild’s Back to Methuselah is fascinating. There is a myriad of reasons to see it, and here is a unique and rare opportunity to experience this hidden Shavian gem."-- DC Theatre Scene

story:
Who are we? 

Talofa lava and greetings, my name is Sani Muliaumaseali'i and I'm the creative director of the Gafa Arts Collective (GAC) London's first Samoan Arts Collective.   We're  a cross-cultural multi disciplinary group of artists,writers, designers and musicians.  Gafa means genealogy in Samoan and our work reflects this unity.

           www.gafasamoa.com

BIGGEST PACIFIC ARTS FESTIVAL ON EARTH!
We have  been chosen to be part of the delegation to represent Samoa at the 12th Festival of Pacific Arts in Guam, (FOPA) in May 2016  and we're taking a  15 strong contingent. Held every four years since 1972,  FOPA  brings together artists and cultural practitioners from around the Pacific region for two weeks of festivity. 
RARE HONOUR
Given we're London based with a multi-cultural membership (Samoans, Kiwis,Aussies,Britons,Swedes,Romanians and others make up the collective) - to be asked to represent Samoa is indeed a special honour. Many in the collective know only  of  Samoa through the work we do in the sharing of the Samoan culture through the arts.

WALKING FORWARD INTO THE PAST TO GUAM:  
'A family called Samoa'  was inspired by the true story of Samoan Chief I’IGA PISA who was exiled by the German rulers of Samoa for his role in the ‘Mau Pule’ independence movement. He was among a group of 73 Samoans exiled to the Saipan / Marianas in 1909. I’iga Pisa covertly built an outrigger canoe and escaped to the open sea,  paddling for hundred of miles eventually stopping in Guam. 'My heart is my compass' -  I'iga Pisa was my great grandfather. 
Based on history and legend we employ music, spoken word,dance, opera, theatre and installation to tell the story of family of Samoa.Tales of contemporary Samoans feature and we uncover the intersecting lines of culture and experience common to all. 
 'A glorious fusion of traditional Samoan and contemporary arts. The work is multifarious, witty and intensely powerful - there is nothing else quite like this!’  Michael Walling Artistic Director Origins Festival of First Nations
What we need and What you'll get: 
We need  £10,000 to take this majestic work to the festival. The funding would go  towards our travel costs (totalling £20,000) so we need your help to  make this project fly. 
By helping us get this project off the ground you will be rewarded for your generosity with a range of unique, original and EXCLUSIVE GAFAwards. The wide ranging GAFAwards are listed to the right of your screen. 

Humanity and hope:

'A Family called Samoa' was written to celebrate 50yrs of Samoa independence in 2012. There was no London celebration and  I wanted to change that. I was lucky that I had many talented friends that who wanted to join me. Writer and theatre maker Stella Duffy, Artist and innovator Rosanna Raymond, Opera Star Aivale Cole, Film maker Paul Yandall, graphic designer Luana Asiata and lighting whizz Dominic Warwick joined a cast of volunteers, who all collaborated to create a powerful and magical piece.  

 'What we achieved – as a show – was amazing. What we created – as a company – was a gift.” Stella Duffy

  I didn't know what shape the piece would take or how it  come about, but I knew  it had to have layers. A story of this magnitude could not be told on one level, and so was borne the 'layered art experience': An interactive, multi-disiplinary experience which  turned conventional theatre on its head. 

'You have to go to this!!! Amazing performances, visually stunning, interactive brutally honest. Samoan history told in a powerfully compelling way. Brilliant! '- Vika- theatre goer.
OUR WORK SO FAR:

A Family called Samoa was our inaugural piece, and since then  the GAFA Arts Collective has gone on to produce work that is innovative, original and transformative: Here's a list of some the 

  • R'OTELLO - The Rugby Opera: 2015. Wandsworth Symphony Orchestra, & Gafa Arts Collective. Written and directed by Sani Muliaumaseali’i Caius House Battersea. 
  • FUN PALACE STOPHIT: 2015 Opera and Sport against domestic abuse, Battersea Millenum
  • KAVA GIRLS 2014: A play with songs: Edinburgh festival. Written and directed by Sani Muliaumaseali’i
  • PACIFIC VOICES 2014: Operatic and spoken word concert:Produced, Directed  by Sani Muliaumaseali’i, Chelsea Town Hall, Chelsea. 


Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially? We understand. Here are some other ways you can help us make our campaign a success. 

  • Follow and connect with us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and help spread the word!

  • Share this campaign with anyone and everyone: Tell the world about our campaign - spread the word y'all! Remember to use the Indiegogo sharing tools:

R'OTELLO - The Rugby Opera: 2015. Wandsworth Symphony Orchestra, &
Gafa Arts Collective. Written and directed by Sani Muliaumaseali’i
Caius House Battersea. 


FUN PALACE STOPHIT: 2015 Opera and Sport against domestic abuse, Battersea Millenum


KAVA GIRLS 2014: A play with songs: Edinburgh festival. Written and directed by Sani Muliaumaseali’i


PACIFIC VOICES 2014: Operatic and spoken word concert:Produced, Directed  by Sani Muliaumaseali’i, Chelsea Town Hall, Chelsea. 


























    
Other Ways You Can Help

Can’t contribute financially? We understand. Here are some other ways you can help us make our campaign a success. 

Follow and connect with us on Facebook, Instagram and Twitter and help spread the word!
Share this campaign with anyone and everyone: Tell the world about our campaign - spread the word y'all! Remember to use the Indiegogo sharing tools:

story:
ABOUT SCUM: a manifesto

Scantily Glad Theatre premieres its latest show, SCUM: a manifesto, created by S.E. Grummett and Caitlin Zacharias, at the PotashCorp Fringe Theatre Festival in Saskatoon from July 28th-August 6th at the Broadway Theatre.

SCUM interweaves the true story of Valerie Solanas and her encounters with pop-art legend, Andy Warhol, with two modern day women navigating the trendy new world of modern feminism. SCUM satirizes what it means to be a feminist in today’s society and pokes fun at our modern misconceptions of gender equality. Witty banter, movement, pop art and projection create the amusingly dark world of SCUM. Since its creation, the play has undergone a series of developmental workshops to evolve it into a full length production. 

SCUM is created entirely by students and recent grads of the U of S Department of Drama program: S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor), Ivan Kolosnjaji (Actor), Jessie Kraus (Actor/Props), Meleody Mountain (Stage Manager/Director) and Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor)

ABOUT SCANTILY GLAD THEATRE

Founded in 2014, Scantily Glad Theatre is an emerging Saskatoon-based theatre company. Our goal is to create original work that provokes laughter, emotion and thought. Scantily Glad Theatre’s first show, The Loveseat premiered at the PotashCorp Saskatoon Fringe Festival last summer. The Loveseat told the story of David and Anna, a young couple going through a divorce, who must reexamine their relationship after they can’t decide who keeps the couch. SCUM: a manifesto is the second work by Scantily Glad Theatre. 

WHY TELL THIS STORY?

"I need feminism because it's a crucial movement towards an complete equal society between men and women. It demands a world where women have the same rights, opportunities and freedom as men. I need feminism because I'm constantly under pressure to look, act and be a certain way. If I wear makeup I'm "looking for attention", but if I don't wear makeup I " look tired and sick". If I do something courageous I "have balls", but if I show my vulnerability I'm "being a pussy". I do not live in an equal world and neither do you, anyone who says otherwise is simply wrong."

-Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor)

“Feminism gets a bad-rap today. A recent study found that only 10% of both men and women identify themselves as a feminist. Even stars like Lady Gaga refuse to use the term “feminist”. But this is part of the problem. Feminism is about equality. True equality. And there’s nothing wrong with that. I was immediately intrigued when I first heard about Valerie Solanas and her S.C.U.M. Manifesto. Her history, her writing, her relationship with Andy Warhol: right away, I knew this was a story I wanted to tell. ” 

-S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor) 

 "When I was first looked at the S.C.U.M. manifesto I thought it was a satire on the extremist Feminism so naturally I was shocked to discover that every word was written earnestly. I think it is important to differentiate this extremist Feminism to what feminism actually is and how important equality is. I think it’s important to really look extremist feminism and see it for what it is. This show does that in a funny and entertaining way and I’m so happy to be a part of making it happen."

-Meleody Mountain (Stage Manager/Director)

MEET OUR TURDS

S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor) is a director, filmmaker and actor from Saskatoon. Last summer, Grummett premiered her first solo-written play The Loveseat at the PotashCorp Saskatoon Fringe Festival. Grummett has also worked as an actor in a variety of Greystone Theatre shows: Picasso at the Lapin Agile, Caucasian Chalk Circle and Coram Boy. Grummett also directs for the screen. Her first feature, Paper Airplanes, premiered at the Yonkers International Film Festival in New York and she has made a number of short films including Dust, Paper or Plastic?, & Broken Image. Grummett is a recent grad with a BFA Acting at the University of Saskatchewan with a minor in Digital Culture & New Media. SCUMis the fourth show created with her partner-in-everything, Caitlin Zacharias. Sarah is very excited to be working with such a dream-team on this show.

Jessie Kraus (Actor/Props) is a Saskatoon actor. He has been recently studying at the University Of Saskatchewan BFA -Acting program for the past four years. He has also done workshops in Larval Masques, Clown, and with the prestigious SITI group from New York City. He has appeared on stage recently with Greystone Theatre and their productions of: Vernon God Little (2014), Coram Boy (2015), and as Albert Einstein in Picasso at the Lapin Agile (2015). This also Jessie's second stint at the Saskatoon Fringe after appearing in Within Theatre's Mumbling at the Universe: A Love Letter to Carl Sagan (2015). Jessie is really excited to be joining Scantily Glad Theatre as an Actor and Props Master, "It's a great learning opportunity to further my prop skills and work in very collaborative setting."

Ivan Kolosnjaji (Actor) is a Saskatoon-based actor/improviser. This is his first ever Fringe show and he's very excited to work with a stellar cast and crew. You may have seen Ivan in Coram Boy as Thomas Ledbury or in Picasso at the Lapin Agile as Picasso, both Greystone Theatre productions. He hopes you enjoy the show and get to know a little bit about his fellow Ruthenian, Andy Warhol.

Meleody Mountain (Stage Manager/Director) is a Saskatoon-based actor and stage manager. She has been studying at the University of Saskatchewan in the BFA acting program for the past four years. She has appeared on the Greystone stage in Coram Boy (2015) and Les Belles-Soeurs (2016). She also stage managed the Greystone production of Caucasian Chalk Circle. This is her first time being part of a Fringe production and she is very excited to be joining Scantily Glad Theatre's team.

Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor) is thrilled to bring SCUM: A Manifesto to the Potash Fringe Festival this summer, and make her Fringe stage debut with her best friend and creative soulmate Sarah Grummett. She has spent the last two years on the Greystone stage playing Thomas (Coram Boy) and Germaine Louzon (Les Belles-Soeurs), and recently completed her fourth year of acting at the U of S. Caitlin believes everyone should have equal opportunities and rights, and that spaghetti can also be a breakfast food. She would like to thank her family and friends for their love, undying support and minimal judgement.

HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS

Theatre ain't cheap. And as students, it can be difficult to feed yourself anything more than a cup o' soup, let alone fund a show! But by supporting us through this campaign, you will be helping us bring this show from script to stage.

Our budget is as follows: 

Fringe Application & Venue Costs: $750.00

Printing & Advertising Costs: $450.00

Projector Rental: $100.00

Set & Props: $100.00

Costumes: $100.00

TOTAL: $1500.00

By raising these funds prior to the Fringe, we are able to use our ticket sales to pay our team and support future creative projects.

OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP

Please, share this campaign with your friends, family, loved ones, exes, allies and nemeses. If you are in Saskatoon, please come out and see our show! You can support us by being a member in the audience and sharing in a laugh. 

PotashCorp Fringe Theatre Festival (Saskatoon) is in its 27th year of operation. The festival runs from July 28 to August 6, 2015 in various venues in around the Broadway area.

Venue: Broadway Theatre

Friday, July 29th                   7:40

Saturday, July 30th             6:05

Sunday, July 31th                 9:20

Monday, August 1st             4:25

Wednesday, August 3rd     8:40

Thursday, August 4th          7:40

Saturday, August 6th           6:05

Tickets: $15, on sale at the door or online at http://www.25thstreettheatre.org/tickets/

*MATURE AUDIENCES ONLY: Violence, Nudity, Sexual Content, Course Language and other good stuff* Please: leave the kids at home!

We also have other fundraisers you can support: 

Eat a burger to support local theatre: Fundraiser BBQ on July 9th at Rona Preston Crossing.

Raise a pint to support local theatre: Pub Crawl on July 23rd at Outlaws Country Bar.

More info available on our Facebook page: https://www.facebook.com/scantilygladtheatre

Thank you for your support!
story_txt:
ABOUT SCUM: a manifesto
Scantily Glad Theatre premieres its
latest show, SCUM: a manifesto, created by S.E. Grummett and
Caitlin Zacharias, at the PotashCorp Fringe Theatre Festival in Saskatoon
from July 28th-August 6th at the Broadway Theatre.
SCUM interweaves the true story of Valerie Solanas and her encounters
with pop-art legend, Andy Warhol, with two modern day women navigating the
trendy new world of modern feminism. SCUM satirizes what it
means to be a feminist in today’s society and pokes fun at our modern
misconceptions of gender equality. Witty banter, movement, pop art and
projection create the amusingly dark world of SCUM. Since
its creation, the play has undergone a series of developmental workshops to
evolve it into a full length production. 
SCUM is created entirely by students and recent grads of the U of S
Department of Drama program: S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor), Ivan Kolosnjaji
(Actor), Jessie Kraus (Actor/Props), Meleody Mountain (Stage Manager/Director)
and Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor)
ABOUT SCANTILY GLAD THEATRE
Founded in 2014, Scantily Glad
Theatre is an emerging Saskatoon-based theatre company. Our goal is to
create original work that provokes laughter, emotion and thought. Scantily Glad
Theatre’s first show, The Loveseat premiered at the PotashCorp Saskatoon
Fringe Festival last summer. The Loveseat told the story of David and
Anna, a young couple going through a divorce, who must reexamine their
relationship after they can’t decide who keeps the couch. SCUM: a
manifesto is the second work by Scantily Glad Theatre. 
WHY TELL THIS STORY?
"I need feminism because it's a
crucial movement towards an complete equal society between men and women. It
demands a world where women have the same rights, opportunities and freedom as
men. I need feminism because I'm constantly under pressure to look, act and be
a certain way. If I wear makeup I'm "looking for attention", but if I
don't wear makeup I " look tired and sick". If I do something
courageous I "have balls", but if I show my vulnerability I'm
"being a pussy". I do not live in an equal world and neither do you,
anyone who says otherwise is simply wrong."
-Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor)
“Feminism gets a bad-rap today. A
recent study found that only 10% of both men and women identify themselves as a
feminist. Even stars like Lady Gaga refuse to use the term “feminist”. But this
is part of the problem. Feminism is about equality. True equality. And there’s
nothing wrong with that. I was immediately intrigued when I first heard about
Valerie Solanas and her S.C.U.M. Manifesto. Her history, her writing, her
relationship with Andy Warhol: right away, I knew this was a story I wanted to
tell. ” 
-S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor) 
 "When I was first
looked at the S.C.U.M. manifesto I thought it was a satire on the extremist
Feminism so naturally I was shocked to discover that every word was written
earnestly. I think it is important to differentiate this extremist Feminism to
what feminism actually is and how important equality is. I think it’s important
to really look extremist feminism and see it for what it is. This show does
that in a funny and entertaining way and I’m so happy to be a part of making it
happen."
-Meleody Mountain (Stage
Manager/Director)
MEET OUR TURDS
S.E. Grummett (Writer/Actor) is a director, filmmaker and actor from
Saskatoon. Last summer, Grummett premiered her first solo-written play The
Loveseat at the PotashCorp Saskatoon Fringe Festival. Grummett has also
worked as an actor in a variety of Greystone Theatre shows: Picasso at the
Lapin Agile, Caucasian Chalk Circle and Coram Boy. Grummett
also directs for the screen. Her first feature, Paper Airplanes, premiered
at the Yonkers International Film Festival in New York and she has made a
number of short films including Dust, Paper or Plastic?, & Broken Image.
Grummett is a recent grad with a BFA Acting at the University of Saskatchewan
with a minor in Digital Culture & New Media. SCUMis
the fourth show created with her partner-in-everything, Caitlin Zacharias.
Sarah is very excited to be working with such a dream-team on this show. 
Jessie Kraus (Actor/Props) is a Saskatoon actor. He has been recently
studying at the University Of Saskatchewan BFA -Acting program for the past
four years. He has also done workshops in Larval Masques, Clown, and with the
prestigious SITI group from New York City. He has appeared on stage recently
with Greystone Theatre and their productions of: Vernon God Little
(2014), Coram Boy (2015), and as Albert Einstein in Picasso at the Lapin
Agile (2015). This also Jessie's second stint at the Saskatoon Fringe after
appearing in Within Theatre's Mumbling at the Universe: A Love Letter to
Carl Sagan (2015). Jessie is really excited to be joining
Scantily Glad Theatre as an Actor and Props Master, "It's a great learning
opportunity to further my prop skills and work in very collaborative
setting."
Ivan Kolosnjaji (Actor) is a Saskatoon-based actor/improviser. This is his first
ever Fringe show and he's very excited to work with a stellar cast and crew.
You may have seen Ivan in Coram Boy as Thomas Ledbury or in Picasso
at the Lapin Agile as Picasso, both Greystone Theatre productions. He hopes
you enjoy the show and get to know a little bit about his fellow Ruthenian,
Andy Warhol.
Meleody Mountain (Stage Manager/Director) is a Saskatoon-based actor and stage
manager. She has been studying at the University of Saskatchewan in the BFA
acting program for the past four years. She has appeared on the Greystone stage
in Coram Boy (2015) and Les Belles-Soeurs (2016). She also stage
managed the Greystone production of Caucasian Chalk Circle. This is her
first time being part of a Fringe production and she is very excited to be
joining Scantily Glad Theatre's team. 
Caitlin Zacharias (Writer/Actor) is thrilled to bring SCUM: A Manifesto
to the Potash Fringe Festival this summer, and make her Fringe stage debut with
her best friend and creative soulmate Sarah Grummett. She has spent the last
two years on the Greystone stage playing Thomas (Coram Boy) and Germaine
Louzon (Les Belles-Soeurs), and recently completed her fourth year of
acting at the U of S. Caitlin believes everyone should have equal opportunities
and rights, and that spaghetti can also be a breakfast food. She would like to
thank her family and friends for their love, undying support and minimal
judgement.
HOW YOUR DONATION HELPS
Theatre ain't cheap. And as students,
it can be difficult to feed yourself anything more than a cup o' soup, let

By raising these funds prior to the

creative projects.

friends, family, loved ones, exes, allies and nemeses. If you are in Saskatoon,

story:
Deadline at the fringe is The Let Go Theatre Co's third production and is set to be our biggest to date and we need as much help to make it as successful as we think it can be. 

"Face it Stuart, you've just stayed too long at the fair. You always did."

Charlotte and Stuart together once more in the den they shared after University. Crippled by the burden of being in their twenties and subject to what seems will be a lifetime of unrewarding hard graft and inevitable self destruction. The piece explores a generation who tie themselves to their friends. Why is it that we crave those people who trap us in this cage of 'failure'? 

They won't be able to provide for their children, their parents or themselves. You know what. F**k it. YOLO! 

Ourselves and Chris met many moons ago at the RSAMD and we cannot quite believe that we are about to embark upon a fringe production together this Summer. A piece written, performed, directed and produced by ourselves. We haven't got a clue what we are doing and we have no one to tell us what to do but we are doing it all the same. We started writing this piece in 2014 and moved up to Glasgow last year and with Chris on board we set to making a production out of it. This happened somehow and with such supportive and exciting feedback we put our plans into motion to get Deadline to the Edinburgh Fringe- a festival we have always wanted to be a part of. Being a part of a production at the festival is wonderful in whatever capacity your involvement but to be taking something that us three pals from drama school have created from scratch feels very special. We are ready to challenge ourselves and we hope that with your support we can really make the most out of this venture. We intend to take our production elsewhere after the fringe and it is really with a look into Deadlines future that we ask for your help. We think it is a play that as well as being entertaining covers topics that, as we have experienced, hit home with our generation and explores issues regarding higher education and employment that plenty of us have been struggling with these past few years. Although these issues may come across as superficial to many it is something that is very real to us and our lives just now- however banal to some. We started writing this play through the themes we decided were most important to us and the drama surrounding them that interests us. It is a journey through the 'twenties crisis'...not knowing where you're going or how you're going to get where you want to go. We found ourselves in such a situation and turned to our creativity to anchor us and this helped spur us on to make our own work. We hope that you will put your faith in us so we can continue a development that we intend to see through to the end. 

Chris, Olivia & Pierce. X

Risks and challenges

To be able to provide all the opportunities that we can in this first production we need to raise the minimum of £3000. This covers the cost of rehearsal space, basic set and props, advertising and the venue at the frige

Other risks include lack of an audience which will hinder the team being paid.

Failure to deliver the project due to lack of funding

As with any kind of theatre project, there are inherent risks such as cast illnesses or unforeseen production delays and we'll be relying on the skills, experience and talents of our established and hard-working team, as well as working closely with our partners and supporters, to ensure these risk are mitigated as much as possible.

story:
Creating a New Theater Space for Millennials

The Akron Civic Theatre is partnering with Millennial Theatre Company to bridge the gap between youth and adult community theater opportunities for young adults ages 18-35 (Millennials). Together, the organizations will create a theatrical space for Millennial voices – for both theater-makers and theatergoers -- and expand Summit County’s arts menu to serve and to speak to an under-represented demographic in community theater. 

The Civic will act as an incubator and fiscal agent for Millennial Theatre Company. As a regional cultural center that works with myriad nonprofit performing arts organizations each year, the Akron Civic Theatre has both the experience and the infrastructure to mentor this startup venture and help get it off the ground.

The partnership begins with the staging of Heathers: The Musical, based on the deliciously dark-humored teen cult film classic, presented Friday, July 22 through Sunday, July 24 in the Civic's intimate cabaret format, where the audience members join the actors on stage. (Ticket information is available www.AkronCivic.com.)

The goal of this Indiegogo campaign is to secure $2,000 to offset expenses for the production of Heathers: The Musical, specifically the costs of royalties, professional stagehands and costuming.

Filling the Theater Gap

For the last five years, the Civic’s All-City Musical has been very successful in bringing together Summit County’s most talented high school-aged performers with theater professionals to present an annual, fully staged, professional-quality musical theater production.

We have discovered along the way that many teenagers who “age out” of local youth theater and the traditional arts education system are still interested in participating in theater and would like to take on more mature content. However, they are not necessarily finding opportunities -- either on stage or backstage -- in adult community theater, and there are very few circumstances in which they can serve in roles of artistic leadership. They are also seeking theater experiences that reflect and speak to their own experiences, interests and values. 

Extending the All-City Musical model by working together, the Civic and Millennial Theatre Company will engage this audience of actors and theatergoers. The repertoire focuses on content that is generation-relevant, and the production process  reflects a decidedly non-traditional approach. For instance, the Company embraces non-traditional casting choices and a democratic process (vs. a hierarchical one) in which all players participate in shaping the production.

story:
What's so awesome about this project? 

In a Nutshell: Our first reading of Girls in White Dresses happened in April, in the lobby of the Phoenix Theater--casual, over beers and pizza. The reading itself only took 40 minutes.
The conversation it prompted afterwards was 90 minutes.  
Sitting around with these talented, smart, young actresses of color and listening to them talk so openly about what it means to be a woman-- in the world, in theater, in these cities...we realized just how vital this conversation was and all the ways it has been denied to us. 
Along with our talented cast we will use our favorite theatrical elements: devised movement and music, a surreal set, puppetry, projection,  and lots of fight choreography (!) to bring Cristina's powerful and poetic words to life. 
We are excited and fortunate to have the opportunity to share this gorgeous play with our wider community, Help us make this show a reality!!

Synopsis:  
Girls in White Dresses is a lyrical imagining of the final days of four of history's forgotten daughters - Olga, Tatiana, Marie, and Anastasia Romanov. We enter their world of repetition and isolation as they struggle to balance their royal obligations and their personal desires. The play explores their slaughtered potential and how young women all over the world, throughout multiple histories, are denied opportunity and the freedom to pursue opportunity. Through movement, poetry and music we watch four young sisters face their certain end with as much curiosity and courage as they can. 
Four of the Twin Cities' most engaging and creative actresses of color create an ensemble seldom seen on stage and lend their talents to a story about what it means to be an afterthought - a sister - a daughter - a woman. 

A lil' history: 
We, Cristina and Katherine, were connected by Jeremy Cohen (Artistic Director of the Playwrights' Center here in Minneapolis) in January and quickly bonded over a shared vision for what new work in the Twin Cities could look like--specifically, more like us! We are interested in telling stories that  focus on women, reclamation of histories and heritage of people of color, and are visually compelling.
One day in early Spring we sat down at Glam Doll Donuts and applied for 2 opportunities: the highly competitive residency at New Works Lab Stratford in Connecticut, and the ArtsNest "Fledgling" program here in Minneapolis. Happily, we received both! We have just returned from our successful residency at New Works Lab where we produced a reading of Cristina's play How the Colds Were Razed (As Told by Gorilla Girl) and could not be more excited to work together again and continue to develop our creative partnership.

Meet the Team:

Cristina Castro (Playwright)
Cristina Castro is a playwright/performer who hails from San Antonio, Texas and has been based in Minneapolis since 2007. Her recent honors include the Jerome Many Voices Fellowship for Emerging Playwrights of Color at The Playwrights' Center, Silver Award in Playwriting from the National YoungArts Foundation in Miami, Fl. In 2011, she was selected as a Summer Intensive Apprentice with the LAByrinth Theater Company in New York City. While living abroad in the United Kingdom she studied with London International School of the Performing Arts founder Thomas Prattki, Royal Shakespeare Company co-founder John Barton, and at Shakespeare’s Globe Theatre. As a performer she has acted in the Twin Cities with theaters such as Mixed Blood (The House of Spirits), Park Square (August: Osage County), Theater Coup d'Etat (Romeo in Romeo & Juliet and Hamlet), the Playwrights’ Center, Teatro del Pueblo (Quita Mitos), Little Lifeboats (Parhelion), and History Theater (RAW STAGES New Works Festival). Cristina' play HOW THE COLDS WERE RAZED (As Told By Gorilla Girl) was recently workshopped at the New Works Lab at Stratford in Connecticut. Cristina is a 2011 alumna of the University of Minnesota/Guthrie Theater B.F.A. Actor Training Program. 
Katherine Pardue (Director)
Katherine is a director and theater educator newly based in Minneapolis . She focuses on devised theater and new works. Katherine is Sarah Rasmussen's Associate at Jungle Theater in Minneapolis, where she assistant directed Two Gentlemen of Verona and The Oldest Boy (upcoming Fall '16). She has worked with (selected) Siti Company, Brooklyn Soundpainting Company, Powerhouse Theater, Loom Ensemble, Oberlin College, The New School, New Native Theater, LaMaMa ETC, Jungle Theater, Sojourn Theater, and New Works Lab Stratford. She worked on staff at Powerhouse Theater for 6 years, most recently as Associate Education Director. She has been lucky to have generous and talented directing mentors in Tomi Tsunoda, Emily Mendelsohn, and Maureen Towey.  B.A. Oberlin College

CAST
Megan Burns  (Marie)
Marisa Carr (Olga)
Comfort Dolo (Tatiana)
Am'Ber Montgomery (Anastasia)

Stage Manager-- BriAnna M. Daniels 
Fight Choreographer-- Annie Enneking 
Puppet Design-- Gaea Dill-D'Ascoli 

Here are the RAD things you are supporting:  

We are hoping to raise $4,000 to cover the cost of 
1) Paying our cast WELL, the work of women--women of color even more so--is undervalued all too often. This is the majority of our budget. 
2) Compensating designers and support staff fairly
3) Building our crazy/awesome major set piece (a Ten Foot Tall dining room table)
4) Building a puppet (materials + design and craft by Heart of the Beast Theater's Gaea Dill-D'Ascoli)
5) Hiring a BOSS fight choreographer (Annie Enneking!!) 
6) Paying for high quality video and photos of the production to use for future grant applications and funding opportunities 

Added bonus: almost all of our perks are handmade with love--cards, stamps, patches, writing, curated mailings
~*~*~*~*~*~*All you Pretty Things: Let us send you pretty things!!!*~*~*~*~*~ 

You don't have to give $$$ to help! 
We want to fill the theater for each performance--so just getting the word out there however you can is so helpful! 

Performance Info: 
September 16, Friday @ 8pm 
September 17, Saturday @8pm 
September 18th, Sunday @2pm 

September 22nd, Thursday @8pm 
September 23rd, Friday @8pm 
September 24th, Saturday @2pm 
September 24th, Saturday @8pm 

'Girls in White Dresses' performs at The Phoenix Theater 2605 Hennepin Ave,  Minneapolis, MN
Tickets ARE NOW available  at www.phoenixtheatermpls.org/project/girls-in-white-dresses/

What's so awesome about this project? 
In a Nutshell: Our first reading of Girls in White Dresses happened in April, in the lobby of the Phoenix Theater--casual, over beers and pizza. The reading itself only took 40 minutes.The conversation it prompted afterwards was 90 minutes.  Sitting around with these talented, smart, young actresses of color and listening to them talk so openly about what it means to be a woman-- in the world, in theater, in these cities...we realized just how vital this conversation was and all the ways it has been denied to us. Along with our talented cast we will use our favorite theatrical elements: devised movement and music, a surreal set, puppetry, projection,  and lots of fight choreography (!) to bring Cristina's powerful and poetic words to life. We are excited and fortunate to have the opportunity to share this gorgeous play with our wider community, Help us make this show a reality!!Synopsis:  Girls in White Dresses is a lyrical imagining of the final days of four of history's forgotten daughters - Olga, Tatiana, Marie, and Anastasia Romanov. We enter their world of repetition and isolation as they struggle to balance their royal obligations and their personal desires. The play explores their slaughtered potential and how young women all over the world, throughout multiple histories, are denied opportunity and the freedom to pursue opportunity. Through movement, poetry and music we watch four young sisters face their certain end with as much curiosity and courage as they can. Four of the Twin Cities' most engaging and creative actresses of color create an ensemble seldom seen on stage and lend their talents to a story about what it means to be an afterthought - a sister - a daughter - a woman. A lil' history: We, Cristina and Katherine, were connected by Jeremy Cohen (Artistic Director of the Playwrights' Center here in Minneapolis) in January and quickly bonded over a shared vision for what new work in the Twin Cities could look like--specifically, more like us! We are interested in telling stories that  focus on women, reclamation of histories and heritage of people of color, and are visually compelling.One day in early Spring we sat down at Glam Doll Donuts and applied for 2 opportunities: the highly competitive residency at New Works Lab Stratford in Connecticut, and the ArtsNest "Fledgling" program here in Minneapolis. Happily, we received both! We have just returned from our successful residency at New Works Lab where we produced a reading of Cristina's play How the Colds Were Razed (As Told by Gorilla Girl) and could not be more excited to work together again and continue to develop our creative partnership.
Meet the Team: 
Cristina Castro (Playwright)Cristina Castro is a playwright/performer who hails from San Antonio, Texas and has been based in Minneapolis since 2007. Her recent honors include the Jerome Many Voices Fellowship for Emerging Playwrights of Color at The Playwrights' Center, Silver Award in Playwriting from the National YoungArts Foundation in Miami, Fl. In 2011, she was selected as a Summer Intensive Apprentice with the LAByrinth Theater Company in New York City. While living abroad in the United Kingdom she studied with London International School of the Performing Arts founder Thomas Prattki, Royal Shakespeare Company co-founder John Barton, and at Shakespeare’s Globe Theatre. As a performer she has acted in the Twin Cities with theaters such as Mixed Blood (The House of Spirits), Park Square (August: Osage County), Theater Coup d'Etat (Romeo in Romeo & Juliet and Hamlet), the Playwrights’ Center, Teatro del Pueblo (Quita Mitos), Little Lifeboats (Parhelion), and History Theater (RAW STAGES New Works Festival). Cristina' play HOW THE COLDS WERE RAZED (As Told By Gorilla Girl) was recently workshopped at the New Works Lab at Stratford in Connecticut. Cristina is a 2011 alumna of the University of Minnesota/Guthrie Theater B.F.A. Actor Training Program. Katherine Pardue (Director)Katherine is a director and theater educator newly based in Minneapolis . She focuses on devised theater and new works. Katherine is Sarah Rasmussen's Associate at Jungle Theater in Minneapolis, where she assistant directed Two Gentlemen of Verona and The Oldest Boy (upcoming Fall '16). She has worked with (selected) Siti Company, Brooklyn Soundpainting Company, Powerhouse Theater, Loom Ensemble, Oberlin College, The New School, New Native Theater, LaMaMa ETC, Jungle Theater, Sojourn Theater, and New Works Lab Stratford. She worked on staff at Powerhouse Theater for 6 years, most recently as Associate Education Director. She has been lucky to have generous and talented directing mentors in Tomi Tsunoda, Emily Mendelsohn, and Maureen Towey.  B.A. Oberlin CollegeCASTMegan Burns  (Marie)Marisa Carr (Olga)Comfort Dolo (Tatiana)Am'Ber Montgomery (Anastasia)Stage Manager-- BriAnna M. Daniels Fight Choreographer-- Annie Enneking Puppet Design-- Gaea Dill-D'Ascoli 

Here are the RAD things you are supporting:  
We are hoping to raise $4,000 to cover the cost of 1) Paying our cast WELL, the work of women--women of color even more so--is undervalued all too often. This is the majority of our budget. 2) Compensating designers and support staff fairly3) Building our crazy/awesome major set piece (a Ten Foot Tall dining room table)4) Building a puppet (materials + design and craft by Heart of the Beast Theater's Gaea Dill-D'Ascoli)5) Hiring a BOSS fight choreographer (Annie Enneking!!) 6) Paying for high quality video and photos of the production to use for future grant applications and funding opportunities 
Added bonus: almost all of our perks are handmade with love--cards, stamps, patches, writing, curated mailings~*~*~*~*~*~*All you Pretty Things: Let us send you pretty things!!!*~*~*~*~*~ 

You don't have to give $$$ to help! We want to fill the theater for each performance--so just getting the word out there however you can is so helpful! 
Performance Info: September 16, Friday @ 8pm September 17, Saturday @8pm September 18th, Sunday @2pm 
September 22nd, Thursday @8pm September 23rd, Friday @8pm September 24th, Saturday @2pm September 24th, Saturday @8pm 'Girls in White Dresses' performs at The Phoenix Theater 2605 Hennepin Ave,  Minneapolis, MNTickets ARE NOW available  at www.phoenixtheatermpls.org/project/girls-in-white-dresses/

story:
Short Summary

I am a queer nonbinary trans* writer and actor, holding it together in NYC. This is my first feature-length project. I am writing about race politics and identities and trans politics/identities in the American Civil War because i see these struggles intertwined with each other, even now. I also believe that all history is queer history, and that i have a responsibility to think about how my life would have looked, and the lives of my loved ones, if i were not in this cultural moment. This is a story about the cost of failing to know yourself, and about how power destroys the possibility of love. You know, a light romp!

What We Need & What You Get

Your contribution gets me:

  • TIME! Time to finish the screenplay out to where i can show it, beyond its current mangy 90 typo-ridden pages. I am a poet first and foremost, and i dearly want time to get the language right.
  • The ability to PAY MY ACTORS, directors, and dramaturges. I know i am writing something that gets deep into other people's stories and it is important to me to get help and be open to perspectives. I am really lucky to have the Tank and the ability to put up this reading, which will be kind of a workshop for the piece. But i need to be able to compensate people, or i might as well be talking to myself.
  • Even if this falls short of the fundraising goal, i will have something to split up among my incredible, brilliant cast. They deserve it.

The Impact

  • Articulating the stories of queer bodies in history gives us a connection to a past that has been violently erased. My America is a queer America, as difficult and uneven and problematic as that may have been. I want to be able to show that to an audience.
  • Of course, as my annoying former coworkers reminded me, "the whole trans thing is very hot right now." This is the moment to tell this story. Your contribution lets this come to life now, when we need it.
  • This is my first screenplay, but my work as a writer (my whole life, culminating in several poetry publications including a full-length book last year) and my work as a performer (acting with groups like Sacred Circle Theatre Company and Threadbare Theatre Workshop) have been longing to come together. I am thrilled and grateful that i finally have a full-fledged concept, a story i can tell. I just need a little bit of resource to get it into the world.
  • This has been a whirlwind for me-- the characters started coming together in April, and in May i heard about the opportunity to do a reading at the Tank. It was a strange "yes" to say, but it came to me loud and clear.

Risks & Challenges

  • I know that practically everyone, especially creatives, especially in NYC, are in these tight spaces, balancing money and time. I know an Indiegogo is asking people to prioritize one thing, sight unseen, out of countless options. But the fact is, i have the story, i have the moment, and the talent is all around me. It is just about connecting with the resources.

Other Ways You Can Help

  • Tell everyone you know! Spread the word! Tell your rich uncle! Write it up in your blog! Use the Indiegogo share tools! Thank you!
  • And if money is JUST not your thing (i get you, believe me, i do) but you are interested in this project, please get in touch! This is just the beginning of the journey-- i know there will be more ways to get involved.

story:
WHO I AM:

Hello! My name is Danielle Russo. I am a choreographer, director and dancer based in New York City. My choreography has been presented nationally at the American Dance Festival, Jacob's Pillow and The Yard; and internationally in Austria, Belgium, Canada, France, Mexico, Panama, South Korea, Spain and Sweden. 


WHAT I DO: 

Danielle Russo Performance Project (DRPP) is a network of movement-based artists that design conceptual performances for unconventional formats and spaces. Although its primary medium is dance, the result is always multi-disciplinary and non-conformist. Its productions breathe between public spaces with the intent of engaging an evolving, indiscriminate audience. 

As its artistic director, my responsibility is both the choreography and the wholistic experience. I create magnified, immersive environments that feed off sensory stimulation and its awakening of the familiar. I have installed intimate performances in surreal environmental conditions either amplified or augmented by my own doing: parlors flooded by 450,000 white roses, cement pillars suspending bodies with industrial cellophane, foyers recarpeted in inexhaustible bubble wrap, the spoon-feeding of German chocolate cake to a string of strangers, so on and so forth. 


WHY I AM HERE:

Salome, and the anatomy of invisible corners is an intimate, site-specific dance theater production buried in the guts of an abandoned pool on Governors Island's South Battery, contemplating obedience, ritual and the ritual body. Audience members will be invited to witness the performance from above at ground level or by entering into the shallow end of the pool. 

Salome... is a two-part project in collaboration with filmmaker Luke Ohlson.  In addition to its live public performances, time spent on Governors Island will be documented into a full-length film for future screening and projection mapping into vacant pool spaces.

There will be 3 FREE PUBLIC PERFORMANCES: JUNE 18, 19 and 25. All on-site rehearsals June 13 - 26 will be free and accessible to the public, as well. 


WHERE I WILL BE:

In 2003, Governors Island was transferred to both the National Park Service and The City of New York, leading to the creation of The Trust for Governors Island. The Trust has not only preserved but evolved its historic property into an open public space, as well as an educational and artistic laboratory.   

OpenHouseGI, a program created by the Trust for Governors Island, provides 150,000 square feet of indoor space and over 20 acres of outdoor space free of charge to organizations that create programming that is free and open to the public. This unrestricted and unparalleled approach has provided the city’s artistic communities with a much needed venue for experimentation, as well as a chance for all creators and programming groups to connect with a extraordinary, diverse public.

 

HOW DRPP WILL BENEFIT:

COMMUNITY

  • Governors Island is a summertime home for the residents of New York City’s five boroughs + its influx of international tourists. The ranging age, cultural, social and political demographic of its audience is truly unique. A Community Conversation will follow our final performance, with the hope of facilitating a direct dialogue between the creative team and the public. 

AUDIENCE DEVELOPMENT

  • In 2015, Governors Island welcomed approximately 450,000 visitors in its 120-day season! Nearly 16,000 visitors averaged per weekend. This season will be its first to offer public access to the entire historic district + 30 acres of parkland. We can safely expect at least 32,000 visitors on The Island during our two-weekend event! Honestly, I cannot think of another way in which I could have my work so readily accessible to such an enormous and diverse audience. An audience gives purpose to the work, and it is crucial for the work to reach beyond the immediate professional dance community. 

PROFESSIONAL GROWTH

  • Salome... will appear alongside prominent international performance artists such as Eiko Otake. This is a tremendous honor.  
  • It is my mission to nurture DRPP into a sustainable organization that consistently compensates both its performers and multi-disciplinary collaborators.


However, organizations must fund their own programs as The Trust has no programming budget. 

Although free performances are wonderful from a community and development perspective, no ticket sales = no income. 



My $6000 fundraising goal is to simply cover my artists' wages. 



I believe that it is critically important for an artist to be paid for her/his work. All too often, this is not the case.

Additionally, the infrastructure of most funding systems do not cooperate with project timelines as dictated by submission deadlines for presenting organizations and venues. Nor do they offer much financial aid for the necessary process leading up to production. It can be near impossible for the self-made artist to garner organizational support for her/his small to medium-sized company. I have put together an all-star creative team for this event: Jason Collins (performer), Joanna DeFelice (set designer), Jenny Lai (costume designer) Ingrid Kapteyn (performer) and Luke Ohlson (filmmaker). The production of Salome... on Governors Island will be the culmination of a 1-year process. Presently, they have invested: 11 months = 132 rehearsals = 948 work hours!


WHY I NEED YOUR HELP:

It's been 4 years since I've led a crowdfunding campaign. With your help, I was able to pay my performers for their time and work at Jacob's Pillow in 2012. I'm humbly asking for your help again. 


I have already paid $15,754 out of my own pocket for this project's operational expenses spanning July 2015 - May 2016:

  1. performers' hourly rehearsal wages........................................$10,490
  2. rehearsal space...........................................................................$3,050
  3. liability insurance...........................................................................$400
  4. damages security..........................................................................$500
  5. identification & safety materials..................................................$200
  6. print marketing materials..............................................................$614
  7. costume materials........................................................................$300
  8. 1/3 of set materials.......................................................................$200

This campaign will directly support the artists involved during its final 2 weeks of process and production:

  1. 2 Performers (hourly rehearsal + performance wages)..........$1,600
  2. 1 Filmmaker (1-year stipend)......................................................$1,100
  3. 1 Set Designer (1-year stipend)..................................................$1,100
  4. 1 Costume Designer (hourly design + creation wage)...............$700
  5. 1 Choreographer (1-year stipend)..............................................$1,100

Any additional funding received will help offset:
  1. 2 Technicians................................................................................$800
  2. 1 Consultant..................................................................................$300
  3. printed programs.........................................................................$400
  4. 2/3 of set materials.....................................................................$500
  5. load-in/strike vehicle...................................................................$300
  6. performers' safety and rehearsal gear.......................................$100 


THE IMPACT:

Your donation will be supporting a person; a hard-working, talented, generous and highly professional artist that has wholeheartedly committed to the process of this project without relying on immediate compensation. This is an extraordinary person. Help me pay the members of my creative team for their time, craft and faith in our collaboration. 


OTHER WAYS YOU CAN HELP:

We greatly appreciate any and all support! If you are interested in contributing to the project by other means, we are seeking assistance with: 

  • vehicle to transport set materials on June 13 and June 27
  • bluetooth stereo system(s) and/or other large sound system 

...and keeping the buzz buzzing! Help us spread the word about Salome... and this fundraising campaign by sharing this page.


Thank you for your time and consideration!


Warmly,

Danielle


*Danielle Russo Performance Project is a non-profit organization 501(c)(3) under Fractured Atlas. All donations are tax-deductible to the extent allowed by law.

story:
Love Shakespeare and believe everyone should be able enjoy his works? Well, we do, too!



We at the Santa Fe Shakespeare Society are determined to bring quality community theatre to the people of New Mexico.  Totally volunteer-based, the casts include seasoned professionals working beside people completely new to Shakespeare.  Admission is on a sliding-scale, so everyone can afford to see outdoor Shakespeare under the magic skies of Santa Fe.

By helping us, we will be able to start our TRAVELING GLOBE PROJECT- a portable reproduction of Shakespeare's Globe stage (using RECYCLED materials as available). It will be the central design element of Romeo and Juliet this season, and go on to not only introduce audiences to Shakespeare's stage, but encourage the idea of recycled materials being used in theatre productions!

The most gratifying feedback we get is from youth, who tell us "they love Shakespeare now" and "understand the words!"

Fundraising in the past has included a rummage sale, personal donations, crowd funding and in-kind trading.  Right now, we need to fund the final GLOBE PROJECT part of our set, and costume rental, and we could use your support! We'd love to not only meet our funding goal, but surpass it!

If you can't help us financially this year, we bet you know someone who can! Please spread the word far and wide! Your goodwill and good thoughts mean a lot to us!

story:
I've been a performer for over 30 years. I started when I was 7 years old singing and dancing in Australia (where I'm from) in Shopping Centers and Theme parks. My name is Daniel Thompson but since getting my greencard and coming to America 2 years ago I changed it to the stage name Danny Tesla so that I would stand out, be remembered and not get lost in online searches with thousands of other Daniel Thompsons. So if google Danny Tesla you'll see some videos of me performing and I've attached some extra videos to this campaign.  

I've performed in Musicals, Cruise Ships, Disney Tours, and created my own one man show which I performed over 1000 times in clubs, corporate events and casinos. Now with over 3000 shows under my belt I have the experience and ability to create a show that I know audiences will enjoy which is what this is all about.

I started creating and developing this Musical 20 years ago and now I am very confident in knowing given the right location with the right cast and and perfect venue this show will be a hit and give joy and happiness to millions of people around the world in the years to come.
 While my first aim is to have it become a residency here in Las Vegas at one of the casinos, from there I expect it will tour and one day soon become a movie.

But it all starts here with your contributions and support. I've invested most of my money and time over the years into this musical because I believe in it so much and know how amazing it will be. 
CITY GYM has already been work shopped, showcased, and staged with a cast. and now with my final tweaks it's ready to go!
Then what the money is for? The biggest cost is rehearsing the cast. I'm planning to get top performers from Las Vegas some will already be in shows on the strip. We also have to pay for the venue and crew costs.

Most shows spend a fortune on Advertising to sell tickets but for this production we are selling tickets through this campaign so we don't need to include that in our budget. other perks will be video downloads of the show and CD's of the soundtrack. 
An exact budget will be made when I know exactly what we raise. The more money we raise the better the production. For example I would love to have Mr Chocolate Ice Tea make his entrance on stage in a DeLorean. While it's not necessary it would be very cool :)

If we don't receive enough funds to meet our goal then I will be asking a lot of performers and staff to work with very little to no pay which I've never done before. I've always paid everyone that has worked on this show in the past so I could find the best people available in Singapore or Sydney.  Now in Las Vegas the talent is the best in the world and I believe it's only fair they deserve to be paid for their time and contribution.
Now for the 1st time the two leads will be parodies of Michael Jackson and Madonna. They will be singing new original songs. Imagine Michael and Madonna singing a love duet.
Can you find people that can sing dance and act like these stars? In Vegas YES!
Absolutely! A lot of people ask me are you allowed to use these stars image etc without their permission? In Las Vegas the law allows parody and CITY GYM being a musical comedy definitely falls into that category. The songs while in the style of the 80's are all original. It's nice to watch an impersonator perform the songs of the stars, but they are always compared and rarely equal the original artist. But In CITY GYM it's even greater as you are seeing all these icons from the 80's performing new work never seen before!!!

If you can't afford to see the show or buy the cast recording at the moment please support us by sharing our campaign via Indiegogo so not only you can enjoyt it one day but all the future casts, crews and audiences can be entertained and enjoy the happiness this fun show gives people.  

Many many thanks,
Danny
story_txt:
I've been a performer for over 30 years. I started when I was 7 years old singing and dancing in Australia (where I'm from) in Shopping Centers and Theme parks. My name is Daniel Thompson but since getting my greencard and coming to America 2 years ago I changed it to the stage name Danny Tesla so that I would stand out, be remembered and not get lost in online searches with thousands of other Daniel Thompsons. So if google Danny Tesla you'll see some videos of me performing and I've attached some extra videos to this campaign.  I've performed in Musicals, Cruise Ships, Disney Tours, and created my own one man show which I performed over 1000 times in clubs, corporate events and casinos. Now with over 3000 shows under my belt I have the experience and ability to create a show that I know audiences will enjoy which is what this is all about. I started creating and developing this Musical 20 years ago and now I am very confident in knowing given the right location with the right cast and and perfect venue this show will be a hit and give joy and happiness to millions of people around the world in the years to come. While my first aim is to have it become a residency here in Las Vegas at one of the casinos, from there I expect it will tour and one day soon become a movie.But it all starts here with your contributions and support. I've invested most of my money and time over the years into this musical because I believe in it so much and know how amazing it will be. CITY GYM has already been work shopped, showcased, and staged with a cast. and now with my final tweaks it's ready to go! 
Then what the money is for? The biggest cost is rehearsing the cast. I'm planning to get top performers from Las Vegas some will already be in shows on the strip. We also have to pay for the venue and crew costs. Most shows spend a fortune on Advertising to sell tickets but for this production we are selling tickets through this campaign so we don't need to include that in our budget. other perks will be video downloads of the show and CD's of the soundtrack.  
 An exact budget will be made when I know exactly what we raise. The more money we raise the better the production. For example I would love to have Mr Chocolate Ice Tea make his entrance on stage in a DeLorean. While it's not necessary it would be very cool :)If we don't receive enough funds to meet our goal then I will be asking a lot of performers and staff to work with very little to no pay which I've never done before. I've always paid everyone that has worked on this show in the past so I could find the best people available in Singapore or Sydney.  Now in Las Vegas the talent is the best in the world and I believe it's only fair they deserve to be paid for their time and contribution.   Now for the 1st time the two leads will be parodies of Michael Jackson and Madonna. They will be singing new original songs. Imagine Michael and Madonna singing a love duet.

In Las Vegas the law allows parody and CITY GYM being a musical comedy definitely falls into that category. The songs while in the style of the 80's are all original. It's nice to watch an impersonator perform the songs of the stars, but they are always compared and rarely equal the original artist. But In CITY GYM it's even greater as you are seeing all these icons from the 80's performing new work never seen before!!! If you can't afford to see the show or buy the cast recording at the moment please support us by sharing our campaign via Indiegogo so not only you can enjoyt it one day but all the future casts, crews and audiences can be entertained and enjoy the happiness this fun show gives people.   Many many thanks,Danny

story:
Who are you?

My name is Eric Bond and I'm an actor and playwright in Peoria, Arizona and I need your help to stage the world premiere of my play, In The Blood of the Lamb.

A play?

Yes!

What is it about?

In The Blood of the Lamb follows a well to do family grappling with faith, temptation, and sin in the backwoods of 1920’s New York. It's based in part on the unsolved mystery of the Hinterkaifeck Slaughter in Germany as seen on Buzzfeed Unsolved  (link down below)

What do you need?

My team and I need $ 10,000 to stage this production. This money will go to

  • Securing rehearsal and staging space
  • Budgeting for Lights, Sound, and Set
  • Making Costumes and Props
  • Paying the Designers and Actors for their work in bringing the show to life

Why should I support this?

  • You'll be supporting local theatre by local theatre makers
  • This show will fill the lack of Sincere Drama missing on our stages
  • You will bring some of that old time religion back to audiences today

When will it run?

Our projected run is from June 8th to June 24th, but we won't make it there without your help.

 

Want to learn more?

Hinterkaifeck Slaughter: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sHMGMddHT6Q

More about me: EricchristopherBond.com
