story:
OUR LIVES NEED

    MORE COMEDY!!             

 

IMPORTANCE OF PLAY:

      Theatergoers:   Whenever you're in a restaurant, don't you want to know what is going on in the kitchen?  Behind those closed doors?  WELL, HERE'S YOUR CHANCE!  'The Puma and The Dumbwaiter' takes you into the chef's restaurant,  to meet the spirited customers, and enjoy the madly comic situations. 

THIS  IS THE PREMIERE SHOW.

     SUPPORT MY DREAM!

 

     Many chef stories have been told in cinema, on television and in books.  But my research found that very few, if any, chef-protagonist restaurant farces have been created as stage plays.  That's an important theatrical niche to fill.

Please help me mount

this premier production,

 because getting an initial play

 staged is as difficult

 as hanging laundry on a rainbow. 

  Yes, that difficult!

     This play has been professionally read enthusiastically by important South Coast Mass. theaters, wherein actors stand and are directed to read from a script on stage in front of an excited audience.    

   IMPORTANT  

ENDORSEMENTS:

       This play was submitted to major, prestigious American theaters, as Chicago's Goodman, Providence's Trinity Repertory, Philadelphia's Walnut Street Theater,  and many others around the country.  Manhattan's famous Playwrights Horizons expressed that the play was "delightfully madcap...complete with snappy one-liners and an outrageous cast of characters."

      Joseph Robinette, famous playwright with 55 published plays, expressed admiration in the writing - "you have indeed developed as a farceur." - and " it certainly deserves a production."

      Ken Wolf, Artistic Director of Manhattan Repertory Theater, wrote "you have written a crazy and wonderful farce.  We would be thrilled to bring it to life as part of our play production program."

Production theater company:

     The Manhattan Repertory Theater has been producing serious plays on Times Square for many years.  Those who work with Ken Wolf and those who have had their plays mounted express enormous enthusiasm for this company's first-rate stage performances.  Their theater, on 45th street, is nearly sold out each evening.

Go to their website and read the positive reviews:

http://manhattanrep.com/play-production-program/

 

SHORT SYNOPSIS OF PLAY:

     A mountain lion, pictured above, lurks in the chef's basement kitchen, blocked from getting to the upstairs restaurant/bar area by a gate.  However, the puma could have access to the frightened customers if he ascends by dumbwaiter.  With that scary dilemma, the play focuses on another dramatic issue.  Skeleton bones of Native Americans are found under the restaurant foundation.  By custom and law, the ownership of the bones comes into serious question.  Who owns them?  The Indian tribe? The State? The restaurant owner?  Everyone seems to have a legitimate claim.  Meanwhile, the police chief, pursing the puma, accidentally shoots a slow-witted farmer. He's carried into the bar presumed dead.  When a dreaded Health Inspector shows up, to avoid detection, the farmer's corpse is frantically pushed helter-skelter on top of a kitchen cart.  Miraculously, he comes alive and the passionate ownership debate resumes. A Marx Brothers chase over the Indian bones concludes the finale with a happy ending.   

 Your Contribution:

      I truly hope you can identify with the importance of this playwrighting endeavor of mine.  It's a dream unrealized. Staging this play will bring notice to my other plays, both comedies and dramas.

     I'm a tenacious terrier like my little Yorkie, Gabriel, on my face book page.  We share a common trait:  we grab hold and don't let go.

    With your help, subscribing to my dream, I may succeed.  I have some interesting perks for those who help me. 

     I look forward to whatever way you choose to help this project, especially passing this project along to your friends in your networks.      

 Visit: 

 https://facebook.com/
matt.tudor.963                          

  Again,  with sincere gratitude,  thank you.  Matt

story:
Venezuelan Actress, Jessica Liñan - Crowd Funding

Hello all,

My name is Jessica Liñan and I am an actress; student of the University of Los Andes, Ula Mérida from the faculty of theatre. I commenced to do acting in 2007, and now I am in my fifth & final year of studies about to complete my thesis. 

One of my most aspiring dreams is to be able to present my work in other corners of the world. Consequently, whilst I have studied I have been developing various works of art that I wish to present. Ultimately, I have been doing this to further my career and now I desire to travel round Europe for 4 months with two pieces of theatre by Venezuelan director Haydée Pino, called 'Amor Por Kilo' and 'El Vestido' respectively. 

Furthermore, I have designed a workshop of a Venezuelan martial art called Garrote. Garrote is a style of fencing that uses a specially designed stick made of vera (typically found in Venezuela). The martial art originates from the state of Lara in its modern form, but is thought to have been born out of the Spanish colonisation in the 16th century. 

I have taken this traditional style of combat and fused it together with physical theatre hoping to express new languages in corporeal acting. The workshop is designed to direct actors, showing them new kinds of Latin American culture with a touch of theatre. 

So, why crowd funding?

The truth is, that thanks to the grave humanity crisis in Venezuela, artists are incredibly limited to support that they can receive in order to work & travel. And I'm talking about artists that are gifted & intelligent, that have ideas & techniques that they can offer to the world. It seems impossible to the developing artist to find a way to rise above all the strenuous disasters that are affecting my country & sincerely be an artist with the intention of showing their work. The economic crisis here in Venezuela is the worst in the world. The average monthly minimum wage is less than $2 and only getting lower with every passing month. As you can imagine, even the thought of saving $1600 for a ticket to Europe, which is what it costs, due to the ridiculous inflation that has affected all flights leaving Venezuela, just that thought alone has me searching. The crisis here has turned citizens into prisoners.

So, why crowd funding? Well as a young developing artist, I am looking for a key to my cell. All I want is to travel to Europe, present myself as an artist, and return back to Venezuela to continue my development. Obviously, however that simple desire is made impossible by the economic crisis. Consequently all I need is $1600 to buy my ticket. The rest is ready. I'm all set. I just need a ticket.

Video

Therefore I have made this short subtitled video, together with my producer & photographer Richard Anderson, as a little taster of the works that I wish to present to the fine European people. So, I hope you enjoy this video and I only ask that you please support a young Venezuelan artist who is struggling in crisis, but has nothing else than the desire to act & present herself to the world. 

 

Saludos y todo mi amor

Jessica Liñan

story:
About The Artist

Olivia Dwyer received her B.A. in Dance and Sociology from the University of Colorado at Boulder under the guidance of artists such as Michelle Ellsworth, Erika Randall, and Donna Mejia. Dwyer has worked with a wide range of artists including Faye Driscoll, Sidra Bell, and Rennie Harris, as well as premiered work nationally at several acclaimed venues and festivals such as Sans Souci Festival of Dance Cinema and Gibney Dance in New York City. As a social justice practitioner, Dwyer is interested in creating work which grapples, complicates, and challenges codified social interaction while adopting an interdisciplinary approach to creating work, blending the world of dance with technology, film, and performance art.

About The Art

​On Saying Goodbye: The Leaving is mine + my collaborators first ever evening length work, premiering at Gibney Dance in New York City this upcoming July. This performance is a part of Gibney’s POP series, a program supporting the dance community through subsidized theater rental. This is a once and a lifetime opportunity as it allows us to fully develop ideas that we have only been able to explore in small chucks. This multimedia work involves live webcams, dance and film. As an intersectional piece with many moving pieces, we are so excited to have the opportunity to fully flesh out these ideas in an evening length work. To read more about the piece, see below!

On Saying Goodbye: The Leaving explores human agency, leaving, longing, and grieving. We explore performative questions like: what would breaking past the “4th wall” look like? Is there a 5th wall, and where does it “exist”? When do performers become people and people become performers? Why do we keep ourselves stuck in one place for the sole purpose of pleasing an audience? On Saying Goodbye investigates deeper questions too, like: what it is too be an observer, a performer and a human all at once? We explore what it means to leave each other. Not in a metaphorical sense, we don’t have time for metaphor. We must know truth. We must practice for loss. What is it to truly leave? To walk away from someone, you know you’ll never see again? To grieve what’s already gone. Bodies are fleeting. Emotion is fleeting. Every moment is lost and never coming back again. How do we contend with this reality? We attempt to see it all, soak it in, let it go and let it die again and again in attempts to embrace the inevitability of loss and the beauty of now. 

What We Need 

Our goal is $7,000! It may seem like a lot, but donating just the price of a ticket to the show, 15-20 dollars, could make a tremendous difference! Your donations are vital to making this amazing project possible! Creating dance costs money, but I believe all artists and dancers should be paid as much or as close to the same fair amount as any other profession. If you believe the same, please consider donating today! Here's what your donations will pay for:

  • Artist Fees
    • What We Need: $3,170 to pay 4 dancers, 1 Lighting Designer, and 1 Stage Manager for rehearsals and performances 
  • Travel and Living Expenses while in New York City 
    • What We Need: $1,910 for 5 flights to New York City Roundtrip and Hotel Fees 
  • Rental Fees at Gibney Dance Center 
    • What We Need: $1,920 for venue rental fees 

The Impact

Your donations will not only make it possible to premiere this work, but more importantly make it possible to pay artists and dancers what they deserve. Dance is a physically, emotionally and mentally demanding profession. My collaborators work hard and I am committed to honoring them. 

Beyond fair pay, funding this project means creating opportunities not only for myself as a choreographer but for my dancers to gain performance experience in New York City at a renowned and loved venue. 

Risks & Challenges

If we do not reach our goal, we truly risk not being able to make this project happen! Please consider donating anything you can to help support this cause! Every penny helps!

Other Ways You Can Help

Can't donate right now? I understand! If you would still like to support this project, please consider sharing the campaign with friends and family!

story:
What We Need (in General)

The producers of Special are raising money to fund the production of a new holiday classic (including venue rental, supplies for the show (like a whole bunch of '70s wigs, sparkly lights, and dry ice), and payment for a lovely, hard-working cast of six who'll take on the roles of dozens of famous and infamous real-life characters from the worlds of blockbuster science fiction movies, variety show extravaganzas, action figure marketing and Canadian animation!

Why Is This "Phase I" of the Campaign?

We're going to raise as much as we can now -- but since (GUARANTEED!!!) seats at the show are one of the funding perks, we may run a Phase II campaign closer to Opening Night if we don't reach our goal in Phase I (so people will have a second chance to secure their (GUARANTEED!!!) seats for a regular performance or the Very SPECIAL New Year's Eve Extravaganza as we get closer to the holiday season!

What You Can Get

  • You get to help launch (and see) a fantastic original show packed with comedy, sing-a-longs, champagne toasts, and even a chance to get pulled into the action as an extraterrestrial barfly.
  • A guaranteed seat during the run of the show (including a Very SPECIAL New Year's Eve performance).
  • Exclusive SPECIAL merch.
  • Acknowledgement in the program as a booster of the show.
  • Advertising space in the program.
  • And even associate producer and/or angel status for our high-level backers!

The Creators

ANDREW OSBORNE (playwright/producer) is an Emmy-winning writer with film, TV, theater, video game, and comic book credits (including the Discovery TV show CASH CAB, the Sundance Film Festival premiere ON_LINE, and the Image Comics series BLUE ESTATE).  His play NO LOVE was staged by L.A.'s Eclectic Company Theater in 2012 and he was a co-writer of SUPER VISION for the Builder's Association in NYC in 2004, in addition to writing and directing four original musical revues for The Pinehills Players (Plymouth, MA) and his feature film debut, APOCALYPSE BOP.  

KERR LORDYGAN (director) is an L.A. theatre vet with numerous stage and screen credits as an actor (including LOST: THE MUSICAL, OUTSMARTED, NUCLEAR FAMILY), director (including NO LOVE, THE LAST TRAIN TO NIBROC, CARRYING ON)  and writer [including plays ASKANCE and THE HIT -- soon to be a feature film -- and the web series IRON NEST OF THE MOON).  He's also produced theatre and is currently a member of Theatre of NOTE in Hollywood, CA after having served as President of the Eclectic Company Theatre in North Hollywood, CA for six years.

Other Ways You Can Help

If we can get it for free, we don't need to pay for it, so let us know if you'd like to pitch in or help out and we can tell you everything we're looking for (from betamax tapes and oxygen tanks to Oscar statues and an accordion)!  Just tweet Andrew @NewBaitShop or email baitshop3@gmail.com!
story_txt:
What We Need (in General)
The producers of Special are raising money to fund the production of a new holiday classic (including venue rental, supplies for the show (like a whole bunch of '70s wigs, sparkly lights, and dry ice), and payment for a lovely, hard-working cast of six who'll take on the roles of dozens of famous and infamous real-life characters from the worlds of blockbuster science fiction movies, variety show extravaganzas, action figure marketing and Canadian animation!
Why Is This "Phase I" of the Campaign?
We're going to raise as much as we can now -- but since (GUARANTEED!!!) seats at the show are one of the funding perks, we may run a Phase II campaign closer to Opening Night if we don't reach our goal in Phase I (so people will have a second chance to secure their (GUARANTEED!!!) seats for a regular performance or the Very SPECIAL New Year's Eve Extravaganza as we get closer to the holiday season!

What You Can Get

You get to help launch (and see) a fantastic original show packed with comedy, sing-a-longs, champagne toasts, and even a chance to get pulled into the action as an extraterrestrial barfly.
A guaranteed seat during the run of the show (including a Very SPECIAL New Year's Eve performance).
Exclusive SPECIAL merch.
Acknowledgement in the program as a booster of the show.
Advertising space in the program.
And even associate producer and/or angel status for our high-level backers!


The Creators
ANDREW OSBORNE (playwright/producer) is an Emmy-winning writer with film, TV, theater, video game, and comic book credits (including the Discovery TV show CASH CAB, the Sundance Film Festival premiere ON_LINE, and the Image Comics series BLUE ESTATE).  His play NO LOVE was staged by L.A.'s Eclectic Company Theater in 2012 and he was a co-writer of SUPER VISION for the Builder's Association in NYC in 2004, in addition to writing and directing four original musical revues for The Pinehills Players (Plymouth, MA) and his feature film debut, APOCALYPSE BOP.  
KERR LORDYGAN (director) is an L.A. theatre vet with numerous stage and screen credits as an actor (including LOST: THE MUSICAL, OUTSMARTED, NUCLEAR FAMILY), director (including NO LOVE, THE LAST TRAIN TO NIBROC, CARRYING ON)  and writer [including plays ASKANCE and THE HIT -- soon to be a feature film -- and the web series IRON NEST OF THE MOON).  He's also produced theatre and is currently a member of Theatre of NOTE in Hollywood, CA after having served as President of the Eclectic Company Theatre in North Hollywood, CA for six years.

story:
Are you getting here after the campaign is over?

You can still donate directly to TOSOS! We hope you'll consider helping us out.

Send "Two From TOSOS: This is Now" to Dublin

NYC's oldest professional LGBTQ theater continues its collaboration with the prestigious International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival, now in its 15th year.

This Year's Entry:

  • "Unseasonable" and "The Butt Trumpet," by Kathleen Warnock
  • Directed by Barry Childs, with Sound Design by Morry Campbell
  • With an acting ensemble of Jamie Heinlein, Ellen Reilly & Lisa Rosetta Strum

Opening May 14 at the Momentum Acting Studio as part of the evening of Women's Shorts.

You may have seen "The Butt Trumpet" at last year's TrumpCon, and won't soon forget the indelible image of a presidential spokesmodel creating music...or something...from an unusual orifice. (This play was written in a Paula Vogel mini-bakeoff, so it is Art, thank you very much!)

"Unseasonable" takes place immediately after an "incident," which seems to be what we are calling them these days, in a hospital where two women try to figure out what happened to them...and what happens next. 

Getting There & Thanking You

We've been doing this for awhile now, and know how to get the most bang out of our buck (or euro). Every contribution takes us closer to our destination, and we are grateful for anything you can give (and have some nifty perks to offer.)

This campaign's goal is to raise the funds to pay for airfare and lodging for the cast and crew to Dublin this May. Anything we raise over that will go directly into the production (see below!)

What We Need & What You Get

The full production budget covers roundtrip airfare for the ensemble and playwright, and a furnished flat for them to stay in, along with a per diem and 2 meals a day.

Every artist and designer involved gets paid a fee or stipend. 

Additional costs include rehearsal space, paying a designer (our friend and colleague Duncan Plaster) to create poster and postcard designs, and paying printers to print them. There's a line on the budget for props and costumes, and...not a whole lot more.

Other Ways You Can Help

Not everyone has the resources to make a monetary contribution, but we have alway cheerfully accepted your good wishes, your sharing of our work on social media or by actually speaking to other human beings, and giving and getting great big hugs in person.

And if you'd like a postcard but can't contribute right now, just let us know. We'll send you one.

Why This is Such a Great Collaboration

We first went to the International Dublin Gay Theatre Festival in 2008, and have continued nearly every year since. And when we weren't able to go in 2010, we threw a benefit here in NYC to help raise funds for the festival.

In addition to the great friends we've made, and the plays we've enjoyed and brought back here to New York to read and produce, we've also been able to bring over productions we saw in Ireland, most recently "Eirebrushed," which we produced at Downtown Art on E. 4th St. in November, 2016. Yes, THAT, November, 2016, and we found the message of the play to be energizing in a time when many were reeling.

Two years later, we're still learning not to normalize/live in a new normal, and this year's plays are a reflection of their times. From a rude, satirical look at what comes out of the White House, to a story of lives suddenly changed forever by violence, these plays show us (and the world beyond the US) what we're thinking of, what we're doing, and what we both hope for and fear.

We've got a great team, with Barry making his directing debut in Dublin, and Morry providing the sound effects and music that's essential to both these plays.

Jamie Heinlein has already been to the festival twice, and leads an acting ensemble that includes Ellen Reilly (who took a part in the reading of Brian Merriman's "Wretched Little Brat" during the run of "Eirebrushed"), and Lisa Rosetta Strum, who is making her TOSOS debut, but has already read with Brian Merriman at my Drunken! Careening! Writers! reading series.

We hope you'll contribute to help us get to Dublin, and come see us at our invited dress rehearsal the first week of May (date/venue to be announced shortly!)

As always, we appreciate your support, now more than ever.

With gratitude,

Team TOSOS

Barry Childs, Director

Morry Campbell, Sound Design

Actors Jamie Heinlein, Ellen Reilly & Lisa Rosetta Strum

Kathleen Warnock, Playwright & Ambassador of Love for North America

story:
Where Your Money is Going

Contributors funds will go towards:

  • New York City rehearsal space
  • Performance venue fees
  • Dancers Costumes 

About the Dancers

​We have 14 young dancer from the ages of 11-21 years. We come together from all different backgrounds and training studios to make magic together. 

The Impact

Performing in New York will give these dancers the opportunity to showcase their talents in an atmosphere throbing with creatives as well as expose them a real dance world experience. Not only will this be a great way to expand on their resumes but it is always a great stepping stone for them to reach for their dreams as young dancers. 

Risks & Challenges

We are in need of costumes and props to help this dream come to fruition. Our fundraising gala was a great footing to aid us in our monetary goal this season however we still on the journey to reach our goal.  

Other Ways You Can Help

Tell a friend and share this link anywhere you can. Thank you for your help and support.

story:
Short Summary

Welcome to the No Nuts Comedy Tour!

We are a female lead show of comedians who are unapologetically themselves on and off stage.  The diverse styles of the comedians on the bill ensures something for everyone as it ranges from playfully irreverent deadpan to highly animated side-splitting stories and jokes! 


Audiences are made up of people from different perspectives and backgrounds so a show's lineup should be too.  We are hoping to the gender gap in comedy tours by showcasing women across the country from each city we visit, thus the name, No Nuts.

Not alone in it, but 2020 hit comedians, performers, and venues hard. The best way for us to recover (mentally and financially) is to tour and share the laughter with everyone. Most importantly we want everyone to stay safe and have fun, so all CDC and regional requirements will be followed strictly.

We are using all our rewards points and membership discounts, but we still need help to offset some of the startup costs of the tour and hope to make a brand out of it to continue putting women in the spotlight. 

 

 

What We Need Help Covering: 

Our current tour is scheduled to start in Atlanta, GA on September 29 at the Punchline, we  go out to CA and will finish it off in Providence, RI at Askew. We are raising money to help cover the costs of marketing, some travel (we are using a lot of points), food & hotel expenses.

What You Get

  • ANY amount up to $49: and you will get: our undying love & gratitude

  • Any amount between $50- $99: our undying love & gratitude plus a personal shout-out on a Facebook live video while we are on the road!

  • $100 - $150: our undying love & gratitude, a personal shout out, plus 2 ticket(s) to any show.

  • $151 - $200: our undying love & gratitude, personal shout out, 2 tickets to any show and a No Nuts Comedy T-Shirt.

  • Over $200: our undying love & gratitude, personal shout out, 2 tickets to any show, No Nuts Comedy T-Shirt and a signed poster.

  • Over $300: our undying love & gratitude, personal shout out, 2 tickets to any show, No Nuts Comedy T-Shirt, signed poster, private link to our comedy album.

 

**Personal shout-outs will take place on Facebook live while we are on the road!

Tickets will be reserved at the venue of your choice and will be available at the box office.

Shirts will be ordered, processed, and shipped at the beginning of the tour.

Signed posters will be sent out after the tour (we want this to be special)!

Private link to our individual comedy albums will be sent after the tour is complete and the video has been completed (may take 2-6 months).

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Share, share and share some more of our content.

Invite your friends in who live in the cities we visit on the FB event page

Comment, like, follow us on FB and IG--    @NoNutsComedy

Tell everyone you think would enjoy a live comedy show to attend.

Invite your friends to like and follow our social media.

Sharing is a huge part! It helps market the tour directly and costs you nothing.  We are most appreciative and that will certainly make a big impact overall.

story:
About the Show: MAJOR MOTION PICTURE

The theatre is territory worth fighting for where eccentric characters lose and gain the grounds for their power, identity and desire. MAJOR MOTION PICTURE explores themes of propaganda, belief, and surveillance through trailblazing contemporary dance theatre.

Out Innerspace's team of 7 performers and 6 design and production collaborators are about to start the final production phase. This is it! We need to raise $8,000 for the last 5 weeks leading up to the premiere January 29th & 30th in Victoria BC. The integration of all the elements including infrared surveillance cameras, a wired costume full of gadgets, lights, sound, interactive video, a ton of costume changes, and radical dancing are all coming together. Our team needs to invent and build systems to wirelessly activate the theatre from a dancer, from a costume, from a camera, from the music... As you can imagine, it is an enormous amount of work, a magical type of work and it is going to take all the skills, inventiveness, diligence and instinct of our entire team.

Your support helps us ensure that all the performers and designers can be in the theatre together, that everyone has their costume, enough lights are in the air, the projector "talks" to the infrared cameras, the dancers can make digital graffiti, our performing choreographers can have an outside eye...that all the gadgets can be tweaked, rigged and fool proofed so the legs of this show are ready to premiere and tour with our most innovative strides yet!

"If the theatre and dance are bedfellows in contemporary creations, the fact remains that we constantly ask to which genre the work really belongs. Out Innerspace Dance Theatre proves to us that the indefinable tastes better and that if there is a genre, it is defined to both of them!" -La Plume du Spectateur

"Unlike anything you've ever seen. Suffice it to say you’ve never seen movement like this, or characters like this, on a dance stage before." - The Georgia Straight

"The choreography is intricate and irreverent...It’s a treat to see this talented and boldly imaginative company touring Canada.” -The Globe and Mail

                                                                                                                               photos by Wendy D
MAJOR MOTION PICTURE is two years in the making and its tour will celebrate 10 years of Out Innerspace. We are joined by an incredible team of lawless and quicksilver collaborators, trustworthy partners, passionate students and avid friends of OIS. We want to make extraordinary, unforgettable and inclusive dance experiences in hopes to situate dance deeper in public hearts and discover more about the human spirit and world we live in. Your support not only funds our most critical and final steps but leads our team to new frontiers to make something full of imagination, mirth and meaning. A lot of research, risk, imagination, rigor, time and sweat has gone into this project and we are thrilled to be getting ready to share it with you!

As a charitable non-profit organization, Out Innerspace dedicates all resources to quality and innovative dance creation, dissemination and education. Each project includes research in production technology, community outreach activities, and vocational training for young emerging professionals. Your support not only helps us bring our 10th anniversary creation to life but helps us generate meaningful dance experiences to diverse public across Canada. Thank you so much for taking the time to learn about us, our project and our campaign.

Come See us Live!

MAJOR MOTION PICTURE  premieres at Dance Victoria in Victoria B.C.

January 29th & 30th at 7:30pm

followed by National tours in fall 2016 and 2017.

Full tour schedule coming soon to our website www.outinnerspace.ca

Choreographed and performed by David Raymond & Tiffany Tregarthen
in collaboration with Laura Avery, Ralph Escamillan, Elissa Hanson, Arash Khakpour, Renée Sigouin & Elya Grant (apprentice).
Mentor: Crystal Pite
Lighting Design: James Proudfoot
Video Design and Manipulation: Craig Alfredson & Eric Chad
Costume Design: Kate Burrows & Sherry Randall
Sound Design: Tristan Vloeberghs & Kate De Lorme
Production Manager: Jeremy Collie-Holmes
Stage Coordinator: Heidi Quicke 
General Manager: Linnea Strom from New Works

Our Ways of Saying Thank You!
Every gift big or small helps us get closer to our goal and we are excited to offer perks including personal social media, postcard and video thank-yous, tickets to the show, invites to rehearsals, postcards from the company on tour, production photos, and even your own costume item! If you're Canadian and give a gift of $25 or more, you will get a tax receipt for the amount of your donation (minus the dollar

value of perks).

Other Ways You Can Help!
Like us on Facebook
Spreading the word about this campaign and our show is a fantastic way to help!
#majormotionpicture #outinnerspace
Come see the work at Dance Victoria January 29th & 30th at 7:30pm or on tour across Canada. 

Partner With Us!
Out Innerspace is dedicated to making innovative dance and educating the next generation of dance artists and would love to create valuable cultural partnerships with businesses or organizations interested in cultivating creation and opportunities through sponsorship contributions. We are excited to discuss opportunities and partnerships and can be reached at info@outinnerspace.ca.

Join the phenomenal group of OIS partnerships, producers, and presenters including Dance Victoria (Victoria BC), Brian Webb Dance Company (Edmonton AB)
The Firehall Arts Centre (Vancouver BC), L'Agora de la Danse (Montreal QC), Live Art (Halifax NS), Vernon District Performing Arts (Vernon BC), Banff Centre for the Arts (Banff AB), D'Ambrosio Architecture + Urbanism (Victoria BC), ArtsSpring, (Salt Spring Island BC), Arts Umbrella (Vancouver BC).

More About Out Innerspace Dance Theatre
Out Innerspace Dance Theatre officially formed in 2007 and incorporated as a Vancouver based non-profit society in 2009. It is now nationally celebrated for uncompromising rigor and ingenuity resulting in an extraordinary performance language that is both distinct and universal. Directed by David Raymond and Tiffany Tregarthen, OIS is a team of dedicated interdisciplinary artists who collaborate to make contemporary, relevant, meaningful and unapologetically accessible dance. They strive for their practice as problem solvers, audience engagers, social organizers, educators, risk takers, and artists to help position important topics, shared experiences and contemporary dance at the forefront of public interest. Entering their 10th season, OIS was awarded the support of the CanDance Creation Fund for their 4th full-length creation and are embarking on their 4th national tour.

Through its 4-year post-secondary program Modus Operandi, OIS nurtures the next generation of professional dance artists. M.O. provides pivotal dance development within a responsive, relevant and rigorous curriculum with leading experts. Alumni are currently participating with over 40 companies and artists across Canada. A long list of exceptional Canadian dance professionals are dedicated to supporting M.O. as one of the pre-eminent institutions of contemporary dance training in Canada and the training ground for some of Canada’s best dancers. Visit M.O. on Facebook and on our website.

If you're Canadian and give a gift of $25 or more, you will get a tax receipt for the amount of your donation (minus the dollar value of perks).
Other Ways You Can Help!Like us on Facebook Spreading the word about this campaign and our show is a fantastic way to help!#majormotionpicture #outinnerspaceCome see the work at Dance Victoria January 29th & 30th at 7:30pm or on tour across Canada. 
Partner With Us!Out
 Innerspace is dedicated to making innovative dance and educating the 
next generation of dance artists and would love to create valuable 
cultural partnerships with businesses or organizations interested in 
cultivating creation and opportunities through sponsorship 
contributions. We are excited to discuss opportunities and partnerships and can be reached at 
info@outinnerspace.ca.Join the phenomenal group of OIS partnerships, producers, and presenters including Dance Victoria (Victoria BC), Brian Webb Dance Company (Edmonton AB)The Firehall Arts Centre (Vancouver BC), L'Agora de la Danse (Montreal QC), Live Art (Halifax NS), Vernon District Performing Arts (Vernon BC), Banff Centre for the Arts (Banff AB), D'Ambrosio Architecture + Urbanism (Victoria BC), ArtsSpring, (Salt Spring Island BC), Arts Umbrella (Vancouver BC).



More About Out Innerspace Dance TheatreOut Innerspace Dance Theatre officially formed in 2007 and incorporated as a Vancouver based non-profit society in 2009. It is now nationally celebrated for uncompromising rigor and ingenuity resulting in an extraordinary performance language that is both distinct and universal. Directed by David Raymond and Tiffany Tregarthen, OIS is a team of dedicated interdisciplinary artists who collaborate to make contemporary, relevant, meaningful and unapologetically accessible dance. They strive for their practice as problem solvers, audience engagers, social organizers, educators, risk takers, and artists to help position important topics, shared experiences and contemporary dance at the forefront of public interest. Entering their 10th season, OIS was awarded the support of the CanDance Creation Fund for their 4th full-length creation and are embarking on their 4th national tour.Through its 4-year post-secondary program Modus Operandi, OIS nurtures the next generation of professional dance artists. M.O. provides pivotal dance development within a responsive, relevant and rigorous curriculum with leading experts. Alumni are currently participating with over 40 companies and artists across Canada. A long list of exceptional Canadian dance professionals are dedicated to supporting M.O. as one of the pre-eminent institutions of contemporary dance training in Canada and the training ground for some of Canada’s best dancers. Visit M.O. on Facebook and on our website.

story:
Quotidian Mandala: a solo dancer searches for enlightenment through cycles of repetition.


Playing with direct confrontation, a solo dancer searches for enlightenment through cycles of repetition. Infused with strength, emotional intuition, and fierce intellect, she embraces her own demure fragility. She is at moments elusive; we just catch the curve of her spine in profile, the arch of her feet, bend of her knees, her hips rocking back and forth. Her movements, shapes, and the universal space are both foreign and familiar, and flow into an archetype of wholeness.

 


This project challenges the individual's relationship to society. 


Support this film for the new ideas, choreography, cinematography, and music score it brings into the world. Support the film for the artists featured. Support this film for the women involved at the highest levels - director and co-producer, choreographer, dancer, camera operator -  and help change the film world itself.



This film is being shot through Scary Cow, a film incubator in San Francisco. This means our experienced professional crew donates their time and equipment.

ALL money raised will support this production - even if we don't reach our entire goal, we're still filming!

Money raised will offset costs for location rental, insurance, set design, wardrobe, and food for casts and crew during our 12 hour production day.



Meet our team - we have some truly amazing people working on this project...


Director Jessica Gomula's video and interactive media works have been showcased internationally at ISEA, Dubai, UAE; Eastern Bloc, Montreal, Canada; Ionion Center for the Arts and Culture, Kefalonia Greece; OZU, Monteleone Sabino, outside Rome, Italy; POP Revolution Festival, Lecce, Italy; CST Institute for Computer Music and Sound Technology, Zurich; MuseumsQuartier Wien, Vienna, Austria; Institut Intermédií, Prague, Czech republic. Gomula-Kruzic’s work has also been shown nationally at Quench ArtSpace, Waitsfield, Vermont; Center for Contemporary Arts, Santa Fe, New Mexico; ARTS Lab, Albuquerque, New Mexico; CounterPulse, San Francisco, California; Climate Theatre, San Francisco, California; BASIC, San Diego, California; Yerba Buena Center for the Arts, San Francisco, California; Dance Mission Theatre, San Francisco, California.


Pauline Jennings’ choreography for stage and interactive installations has been performed in festivals and showcases nationwide, including the San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, Merce Cunningham Studio, EMPAC (Emergent Media and Performing Arts Center, RPI), and ODC Theater. Internationally, her work has been shown by venues including the Museumsquartier Wien, Institut Intermédií (Prague), ProART International Choreography Platform (Brno), Eastern Bloc (Montreal), Primo Piano LivinGallery (Lecce), and Takt Kunstprojektraum (Berlin). Recently, Pauline presented an interactive installation at the 20th International Symposium on Electronic Art (ISEA), Dubai, United Arab Emirates. Additionally, she premiered new emergent stage works Encrypted Trajectory (Dibden Center for the Arts) and 6 Phrases, 3 Rules (Spruce Peak Performing Arts Center), and a collaborative work with Heidi Boisvert for The Wassaic Project Festival (2015).


Dancer Jennifer Mellor currently performs with DOUBLE VISION, with whom she tours nationally and internationally, and is the artistic director of Jennifer Mellor Dance Project, which has performed in San Francisco, New York, and Tulsa. She has also danced for Beth Soll & Company, Ella Rosewood Dance, Holly Heidt, Laurel Desmarais, Andy Byers & Jonathan Peck, and Allie Tsypin in New York; Copious Dance Theater, Courage Group, High Release Dance, Diane Frank and Lisa Burnett in San Francisco; Tulsa Dance Theater, FootSong, A Call to Feet Tap Dance Ensemble, and Dance on Tulsa, where she was featured in works by Johnson/Long & Co, Dina McDermott, Mimi Chen, and Kathy Dunn Hamrick.


Composer Sean Clute's diverse creative activities have been presented at venues such as The Kitchen, CEAIT Festival, San Francisco Museum of Modern Art, TED2005, Uspannwerk Kreuzberg (Germany), Shabla Solar Eclipse Festival (Bulgaria), La Case A Chocs (Switzerland), La Ma Ma etc., Times Square Deli Dance, CBGB’s, REDCAT Theater, University of Illinois Urbana-Champaign, California College of the Arts, Mills College, and California Institute of the Arts. Sean has also been recognized with a Fulbright Award and residency at the MuseumsQuartier Wien in Austria, a Djerassi Resident Artist Award, and a Meet the Composer Award. He has an extensive background in music and intermedia art and holds an MFA in Electronic Music and Recording Media from Mills College where he was awarded the Music Alumnae Scholarship, Crothers Award, Hellman Award, Lynn T. White Award, and Frog Peak Collective Experimental Music Award.


Please contribute... but if you can't, you can still help our project by sharing it with people you know!

story:
Production of a ballet based on the story of Billy Elliot

We are Mary, Geral, and Gaby, Venezuelans and students of the tenth semester of Social Communication mention of Media Arts in the Universidad Católica Andrés Bello.

As we are in the last semester of the career, the university requires us to make a graduation project to have the title of licensed. This project is about the production of a ballet based on the story of Billy Elliot.

The production is an academic activity that must fulfill different requirements: choreographic montage of the story, development of scenography, costume design for the staging, and rental of specialized professionals in lighting and sound. In addition, we have to provide to our dancers the basic sustenance as food and water, during the making progress of the play.

Our principal objective is to present the identity of the man as classical dancer, in spite of the social judgments. In Venezuela, if a boy says that he wants to be a dancer, he receives criticism and rejections. Although we are in an advanced century, sexism and taboos are still very present in our society. And this case is one of them; a dancer can be pigeonholed as homosexual only for wanting to dedicate and devote his life to dance.

This is why the story of Billy Elliot works as an example of the situation of Venezuelan dancers. Billy is an 11 year old boy who through his passion for dancing he becomes a professional ballet dancer, despite the obstacles and prejudices that stands in his way.

This story began with a movie, later it was taken to the theatre as a musical presented in cities such as London and New York. In this opportunity, we propose a value-added to the piece: telling the story through ballet. This way, we offer a space where the young dancers can be projected, and also have more experience of expressing themselves in a scenario. So they manage to boost their artistic careers thanks to be known in the world of dance.

Regrettably, in Venezuela the dance doesn’t receive the importance that deserves, and mostly is left to one side because it is not considered as a real job. The dancers don’t have sufficient spaces to demonstrate their skills and talent. Besides, they can’t sustain themselves since the dance is not well paid.

Currently, The Venezuelan society lives a social, political and economic crisis that affects all areas of life. For us, young people, getting money is so difficult. We must deal with the high cost of things and the insecurity that surrounds our daily life. In addition, a half time salary doesn’t generate the necessary income to be able to support the project by our own.

Although we have the support of our families, it is difficult for us to afford all the production requirements. That’s why we are telling our story here, and with your help you will be contributing to making true this project.

Thanks to all of you who are reading this! We know that there are still difficulties on the road, but there is more strength to bear them. Even if you cannot contribute financially, just sharing our story you will give your grain of sand.

Producción de un ballet basado en la historia de Billy Elliot 

Somos Mary Morillo, Geraldine Sepùlveda y Gabriela Manotas, venezolanas y estudiantes del décimo semestre de Comunicación Social  mención Artes Audiovisuales de la Universidad Católica Andrés Bello. 

Al estar en el último semestre de la carrera, y para poder optar por el título de licenciadas, es indispensable la realización de un trabajo de grado. Trabajo que nosotras ya hemos conceptualizado: la producción de un ballet basado en la historia de Billy Elliot.

La producción, como actividad académica que es, debe cumplir con distintos requisitos: montaje coreográfico de la historia, desarrollo de escenografía, vestuario para la puesta en escena y alquiler de técnicos especializados en iluminación y sonido. Además de poder  ofrecer a nuestros bailarines, durante el desarrollo de la pieza, sustento básico como lo es comida y  agua.

Nuestro principal objetivo con esta producción es escenificar la identidad del hombre como bailarín clásico pese a los juicios sociales. En Venezuela, el  que un chico exprese que quiere ser bailarín es significado de críticas, señales y rechazo. Aunque nos encontramos en un siglo avanzado, la sociedad venezolana sigue siendo machista y llena de tabúes. Y este es uno de ellos, un bailarín puede ser encasillado como homosexual solo por querer dedicar su vida a la danza y así dejar de recibir el apoyo de amigos y familiares.

Es por ello que la historia de Billy Elliot, funciona como ejemplo a la situación de bailarines venezolanos. Billy un niño de 11 años quien a través de la pasión por el baile, pese a los obstáculos y prejuicios que se presentan en su camino, se convierte  en bailarín de ballet profesional.

Esta historia inició en una película, luego fue llevada al teatro como un musical presentado en ciudades como  Londres y Nueva York. En esta oportunidad, proponemos un valor agregado a la pieza: contar la historia a través del ballet. De esta forma ofrecemos un espacio para que jóvenes bailarines se proyecten, tenga la experiencia de expresarse en un escenario y, así impulsen su carrera artística al darse a conocer dentro del mundo de la danza.

Lamentablemente en Venezuela la danza no recibe la importancia que merece y la mayoría de las veces es dejada a un lado porque no es considerada un oficio y los bailarines no disponen de suficientes espacios que les permitan demostrar sus habilidades y talento; o no logran poder sustentar su vida solo con el baile por no ser justamente remunerado.

La sociedad venezolana vive en la actualidad una crisis social, política y económica que afecta todos los ámbitos de la vida, y para nosotros los jóvenes obtener dinero no es tan accesible al toparnos con muchas puertas cerradas, el elevado costo de las cosas y la inseguridad que envuelve nuestro día a día. Incluso al trabajar, un sueldo de medio tiempo no genera los ingresos necesarios para poder sustentar por nuestra cuenta el proyecto en su totalidad.

Aunque contamos con el apoyo de nuestras familias, con la situación que nos envuelve como país, resulta difícil costear todos los requisitos de la producción y es por ello que estamos aquí contando nuestra historia, con tu ayuda estarás aportando a que este proyecto deje de ser un sueño y se convierta en realidad.

¡Gracias a ustedes que están leyendo! Sabemos que todavía quedan dificultades en el camino, pero existe más fuerza para sobrellevarlas. Incluso si no te es posible colaborar monetariamente, solo compartiendo nuestra historia aportaras tu granito de arena.

story:
Night Bomber Regiment 588

Despite flying wooden biplanes and having little military training, the women of Night Bombers 588 were among the most highly decorated fighting forces in the Red Army. The Nazis called them Nachthexen, The Night Witches.


This is a story whose time has come. A story that honors the Night Witches' contribution to defeating the Nazi war machine. By the end of the war, many of them had flown a thousand missions, averaging over ten per night. They dropped 23,000 tons of bombs on Axis forces from planes built for crop dusting. We will tell this story with action, heart, and humor.


We have a great venue at 6470 Santa Monica blvd (a prime Fringe location!). And the backing of the award winning Thrillpeddler Theatre Company.



Venue rental and rehearsal space are expensive! Not to mention costumes and props needed to create a true sense of combat. We are determined to make this happen. Our cast and crew are committed. Our material production value however depends on your contributions.

With your help we can create a strong theatrical experience. One that makes the hardship and courage of these women come to life.


To thank you for your help we have T-shirts and posters with our logo, tickets to the performance of your choice, and fun ways to recognize your contribution!

Beyond raising funds, we also want to generate interest. Luckily this hasn't been terribly difficult. People who hear this story want to share it. It's what got us started! We appreciate your sharing our page with friends or even just telling people that the Night Witches existed! 

Thank you!

See you at the theatre!!

story:
Who Are We?

Grace Courvoisier & Dance Company (GC&DC) is a project based dance company in New York City. We believe that the physicality of a woman's body can house historical and emotional landscapes. We aim to excavate female vulnerability and vulgarity through voice and movement. GC&DC will present Daughters of David, in which four young women explore both the labor and the love they've taken in from the David's of their conscious and subconscious. Directly influenced by the male archetypes of world history and personal history; David Bowie, Michelangelo's statue of David, David the ex-boyfriend... these girls process their idea of loyalty to these men, but also their rebellion, exploring the space between Father David and Male Suppression.
Daughters of David  will premiere at 22 Boerum Pl, Brooklyn, NY through CRAWL -  a multi-disciplinary, nomadic arts presenting series that fosters and supports creative meetings between artists and audiences. This is GC&DC's 2nd season with CRAWL.

___________________________________________________

"This fantastic portrait of a woman on the verge held the audience in captivating silence "

- Oberon's Grove
__________________________________________________

Your generous contribution directly funds these highly acclaimed and successful performing artists. Their emotional commitment  has shaped and molded the beautiful atmosphere that Daughters of David represents. Performances by Elise Ritzel, Alexis Convento, Emily Palmquist, and Kristin Yancy,

The Impact

We totally get it! It's extremely hard to give towards an art form, such as dance, with no real preservation skill besides the memory of its existence.

The funds raised on Indiegogo  will go directly to the women involved, who have made tremendous alterations in their characters and commitments, to share the universal feeling of loving someone who is not worthy of receiving it . The success of this campaign will ensure that the artists have been paid, and afforded the needed rehearsal space and technical fees. GC&DC, like any dance company, is familiar with the drawbacks and challenges of keeping this performing art alive. We have decided to invest our energy into making movement, so you may be moved by our making. 
We are excited about this new work, and a big thank you from Grace Courvoisier & Dance Company.

photo of Elise Ritzel by Alexis Convento

Other Ways You Can Help

Your bank account is small, but we know your heart is big! You can still help spread the word for Daughters of David!  Share this campaign on your social media, and spread the daughters story of strength, and loyalty to one another.

You can find their story on the following platforms:

Instragram: @gcourvodance
Facebook: facebook.com/GCandDC
Twitter: @GCandDC

#jointhecrawl #gcdc #dancenyc
story_txt:
Who Are We? 
Grace Courvoisier & Dance Company (GC&DC) is a project based dance company in New York City. We believe that the physicality of a woman's body can house historical and emotional landscapes. We aim to excavate female vulnerability and vulgarity through voice and movement. GC&DC will present Daughters of David, in which four young women explore both the labor and the love they've taken in from the David's of their conscious and subconscious. Directly influenced by the male archetypes of world history and personal history; David Bowie, Michelangelo's statue of David, David the ex-boyfriend... these girls process their idea of loyalty to these men, but also their rebellion, exploring the space between Father David and Male Suppression.

Daughters of David  will premiere at 22 Boerum Pl, Brooklyn, NY through CRAWL -  a multi-disciplinary, nomadic arts presenting series that fosters and supports creative meetings between artists and audiences. This is GC&DC's 2nd season with CRAWL. 

___________________________________________________   "This fantastic portrait of a woman on the verge held the audience in captivating silence "
- Oberon's Grove
__________________________________________________


Your generous contribution directly funds these highly acclaimed and successful performing artists. Their emotional commitment  has shaped and molded the beautiful atmosphere that Daughters of David represents. Performances by Elise Ritzel, Alexis Convento, Emily Palmquist, and Kristin Yancy,   The Impact
 
We totally get it! It's extremely hard to give towards an art form, such as dance, with no real preservation skill besides the memory of its existence. 
The funds raised on Indiegogo  will go directly to the women involved, who have made tremendous alterations in their characters and commitments, to share the universal feeling of loving someone who is not worthy of receiving it . The success of this campaign will ensure that the artists have been paid, and afforded the needed rehearsal space and technical fees. GC&DC, like any dance company, is familiar with the drawbacks and challenges of keeping this performing art alive. We have decided to invest our energy into making movement, so you may be moved by our making.  We are excited about this new work, and a big thank you from Grace Courvoisier & Dance Company.



photo of Elise Ritzel by Alexis Convento   Other Ways You Can Help Your bank account is small, but we know your heart is big! You can still help spread the word for Daughters of David!  Share this campaign on your social media, and spread the daughters story of strength, and loyalty to one another.
You can find their story on the following platforms:
Instragram: @gcourvodanceFacebook: facebook.com/GCandDCTwitter: @GCandDC
#jointhecrawl #gcdc #dancenyc

story:
We are CYPHER!

Young artists who effectively communicate positive messages through the creative arts and mentoring while motivating and inspiring students of all ages.

CYPHER House Productions is currently working towards a non-profit status, but until that is obtained, we have established a core group that provides schools and organizations with high quality arts programs that include dance, music, and the visual arts. One of our main objectives is to communicate life skills and positive messages through multiple artistic platforms. We mentor students to become leaders and mentors themselves.

What We Need:

Our team has grown considerably within the last year, but there are still kids that would like to be part of our program, but can't due to lack of transportation. We hope to be able to reach as many students as possible by providing them with rides to and from practices. Although we do have an active group of supportive parents, we still need help transporting the current students to and from our performances. Owning a van would lighten the load immensely. 

Here's where your money will be going:

  • $35, 000.00 : A new 13 passenger van
  • $6, 000.00: A trailer for transporting our sound and lighting equipment
  • $1,000.00: towing package
  • $2,000.00: Tax, Title, and License, and additional fees
  • $2,000.00: Advertisement wrap for van and/or trailer. 
  • $2,000.00: Sound and lighting equipment maintenance and upgrade.  
  • $2,000.00: Fuel for our trips for about half a year.

The Impact

Your contribution will:
  • Help us to reach and provide mentoring services for more students in and out of our community. 
  • Relieve van rental costs
  • Provide us with the freedom that we need to reach schools with our positive messages such as:

Team Building & Sportsmanship

 Self Management & Social Skills

 Self Esteem & Self Worth

 Nutrition & Healthy Living

Drug & Violence Prevention

Staying in School & Goal Setting

 Decision Making & Positive Risk Taking

Anti-Bullying & Character Development


Much deserved!

This van provision is by no means a selfish request. Our CYPHER Directors have worked unselfishly for years in efforts to better serve their students and  community. Their infectious spirit is evident in their work and the CYPHER students share similar passion and work ethic. Anyone who has been involved with this group of artists can attest to the positivity that this group emanates. Your contribution towards a van for CYPHER will not only help to educate students in the arts, but it's an invaluable investment towards  future leaders.

THANK YOU! 

Contributors will receive perks from like dance classes and CYPHER merchandise. This is our small way of saying "Thank you" because this wouldn't be possible without each and every one of you.  


Other Ways You Can Help

Please help us spread the word about CYPHER House Productions and A VAN FOR CYPHER ! You can do this by telling your friends, coworkers, family, and networks about this project and sharing our Indiegogo fundraising campaign with them!  We appreciate every post, shared link, and gesture made on our behalf. 

 Follow us on our platforms:

Check out and SHARE our website! www.cypherhousepro.com

LIKE us on Facebook! https://www.facebook.com/cypher.sa.9

FOLLOW us on Instagram!  http://www.instagram.com/CYPHERMVMNT

story:
The Play

Born at the same time on the same day in the same hospital, Pig and Runt have been inseparable ever since. They speak in their own language, play by their own rules, and create an insular world for themselves in which boundaries blur between truth and illusion. But encroaching adulthood calls for an end to their idyll. On their 17th birthdays, in a kind of last dance, they feverishly drink, fantasize, and try to hold onto the childhood that’s slipping through their fingers.

Our Production

Enda Walsh is one of the most exciting playwrights alive, infusing Beckett-esque surrealism with crazed physical comedy and relentless energy, taking huge formal risks to place the audience directly in the perspective of his obsessively delusional characters. “Disco Pigs” is no different – as a way of representing the inscrutable shared world of teenage friendships, the two characters literally speak their own made up language. Pig and Runt create their own world using extremely limited means – just their imaginations and each other. The play itself embodies that act of desperate creation, as the two actors voice and embody dozens of characters and locations, creating a whole imaginary world with just their voices and bodies.

The hope of our production is to heighten that connection. The show will be done completely practically – no theatrical lighting or piped in sound, just practical lights and live sound effects, all controlled or created by the actors. The entire performance will be underscored by live percussion, which will function as both soundtrack and sound design.

We’re staging the play in the style of a house show, with performances taking place in the basement of Hostel Earphoria, a DIY venue in Logan Square – the play will have an open and casual atmosphere, with free drinks and an opening band.

What We Need

We deliberately conceived this project as a low-budget endeavor – one that we could tackle with minimal resources and without compromises. However, despite our show's simplicity, we still have financial necessities to cover. 

  • Rights: $258
  • Renting Rehearsal Space: $825
  • Stipend for Artists: $350
  • Various Design Costs (e.g. clip lights, LED lights, Flood Light, disco ball, replacement drum heads): $115

The hope is that we can completely cover the costs of production through fundraising, and make admission free with a suggested donation, which will further our goals of accessibility and bringing in new audiences.

Who We Are

The Team is composed of…

Director and Producer: Michael Rogerson

Designer: Sean Gunderson

Actors: Tom DeFrancisco and Sophie Neff

Percussionist: Aidan Kranz

Movement Director: Collin Quinn Rice

Dialect Coach: Daniel Chenard

Graphic Designer: Anna White

Some Details

The production will have two performances, one on Thursday March 22nd and the other on Saturday March 31st, both taking place at Hostel Earphoria (3464 W Diversey Ave, Chicago IL). Here's a link to the Facebook event: https://www.facebook.com/events/166869559653104...

Thank you for your time and your generosity! Any amount helps!

story:
In April 2019, Soul In Motion, under the direction of Michael Friend and Pam Lassiter, will celebrate 35 years in the arts with a grand concert at the historic F. Scott Fitzgerald Theater in Rockville, MD, featuring several premiere African Dance and Drum Ensembles. Five years ago, Soul In Motion 30 featured Mama Kadiatou and Balafon, Coyaba, Farafina Kan, An Ka Fo, Taratibu, Vision Contemporary Dance Ensemble, and Rockville's own - The Finest.  Thanks to your support, our 30th Anniversary Concert in 2014, was capacity filled at the 442 seat theater.

We're asking you to please assist Soul In Motion financially to make our 35th Anniversary event a huge success. Our overall goal is $25,000.  Your tax deductible contributions will assist with defraying the expense of advertising, catering, theater rental, costumes, technical support, artist fees, transportation, and lodging.

It's also our goal, once again, to bring the beauty of African Dance and Drum to the residents of Rockville, MD in a way that will be memorable, educational, and energetically entertaining.

Over the last 34 years, we've successfully produced an anniversary concert for friends, families, and fans. Some of the memorable programs of the past include "Soul In Motion 30", "It's Our time", "Still Here", "Kakilambe", "Soli_Kassa", "Make History Now", "Back to the Root", "1-2-3 Senegal"; and most recently "Prequel". Many of you attended all or several of these performances and we greatly appreciate your continued support. Unlike the two-day presentations of the past, we understand that Soul In Motion 35 will be a much larger undertaking - and we need your support.

If you're unable to give financially at this time we totally understand. We want to encourage you to past the word of the Soul In Motion 35th Anniversary campaign to your friends and family via FaceBook and other social networking sites. Your support in this way is needed and greatly appreciated.

From the entire Soul In Motion Family - THANK YOU!!!!!

story:
The Show

FANATICAL is a brand-new musical about love, creativity, and community. This show follows a group of passionate, dedicated fans determined to put on the best sci-fi convention ever, to celebrate cult comic and TV show Angel 8.... no matter what gets in their way.

FANATICAL is a collaboration between US playwright Reina Hardy and UK composer and lyricist Matt Board. The Stable have been working with Matt and Reina to develop the show and will be presenting the world premiere at The Playground Theatre, a new venue in West London, in November 2018.

Its a fantastic show but we need your help to bring the best possible version of it it to the stage.

Let's get ready to launch!
 

The Cast

The cast will be lead by SUANNE BRAUN (Stargate SG-1, Mamma Mia, Onassis, Red Dwarf) as Trix and...

AMY LOVATT as Lizette. Click HERE to check out Amy's amazing YouTube channel about all things musical theatre.

Stay tuned for updates as more cast members are announced!
 

The Songs

Here we have a behind the scenes look at a couple of numbers in rehearsal!

Look What I Made

Performed by Akiya Henry, Maimuna Memon & George Rae
 

You Should See her Fly

Performed by Izuka Hoyle
 

The Team


The Stable | Producers
Recognising the challenges in getting new musical theatre work staged, The Stable was established in 2014 to commission, develop and present innovative shows by emerging writers of exceptional talent

The Stable has commissioned 4 new musicals to date. Their work has been featured on BBC Radio 4's Front Row and  The Stable have received a development grant from the Wellcome Trust, enjoyed a successful raise on Equity platform Crowdcube and secured support from ArtsForward to help develop their slate of shows.

For more information please visit www.thestablemusicals.co.uk.


Matt Board | Music & Lyrics
Matt co-wrote the book, music and lyrics to “Austentatious” which was a critical and audience favourite at the Landor Theatre in 2009, a New York Times pick of the 2007 New York Musical Theatre Festival, and has also been produced in Philadelphia and Calgary.  Matt was a finalist in both the 2013 Search For A Twitter Composer competition and the 2014 Stiles and Drewe New Song Award and was commissioned by Comedy Central to write “Friends: The Opera” for a gala performance in London.

Matt’s other work includes music and lyrics for children’s musical “Ella and the Dragophant”, book, music and lyrics for the one-act two-woman musical “Two’s A Crowd”, which featured in the Perfect Pitch New Musicals Festival.


Reina Hardy | Book
Reina is a playwright. Her plays, which usually contain magic and sometimes contain science, have been seen across the US, including at Rorschach Theatre in DC, the Vortex in Austin, and the 2013 NNPN National New Play Showcase. She’s a Michener Fellow, winner of the 2014 KCACTF TYA Prize, finalist for the Terrence McNally Prize and the recipient of an Interact 20/20 Commission. 


The Playground Theatre | Venue
The Playground Theatre is a new venue in West London run by Co-Artistic Directors Anthony Biggs and Peter Tate. Their mission is to work with both established and emerging artists in the UK and internationally. The ethos is one of cross-fertilization between different forms and different cultures with the aim of creating work that is bold and imaginative, while fully engaging the rich diversity of the community of which it is a part.
 

Shaun Kerrison | Director

Jim Henson | Musical Supervisor

Anthony Whiteman | Choreographer

PJ McEvoy | Designer

Original dramaturgy by Lotte Wakeham. 


What We Need & What You Get

The show uses a live band, and we want to enhance this with chip and pin sampling technology to mimic 1980's gaming soundtracks and give FANATICAL a unique and authentic sound. As well as being INSANELY COOL, the use of this technical innovation is somewhat pioneering in musical theatre where we haven't seen this being done before!

Chiptune is a genre of music composed using the 8-Bit soundchips from the gaming consoles of the 80s and 90s.  It takes the blips and bleeps from our favourite retro video games and ramps that playful, high-energy soundscape all the way up to 11. Chiptune has been a staple of the online composing scene for the past couple of decades but it's rarely been used in musical theatre before.

It's perfect to evoke the geeky world of Fanatical. If we meet our goal we will be able to fully realise the composer Matt's soundscape by providing funds for this technology as well as being able to hire additional band members to make the whole thing sound completely awesome. 
 

 

 

 

 

 

 

If you choose to get involved, we've got lots of rewards for you, from programme credits and social media shoutouts to season tickets and getting your very own song written for you - we've got something for every level of donation.

Special mention to our Pass It On perk where not only will you be helping the show, The Stable will also donate  a ticket to someone who could not otherwise afford to attend in your name. For full details on this and all of our other rewards check out the perks on the right hand side.
 

Other Ways You Can Help

Please follow us and share our campaign on Twitter:
@FanaticalTweets | #FanaticalAboutFanatical

Follow The Stable on Instagram and Twitter: @StableMusicals

Other Ways You Can Help
Please follow us and share our campaign on Twitter:@FanaticalTweets | #FanaticalAboutFanatical
Follow The Stable on Instagram and Twitter: @StableMusicals

story:
VERSION FRANÇAISE: (Text in English below)

Goma Dance Festival est une initiative des jeunes danseurs de la ville de Goma en collaboration avec quelques jeunes opérateurs culturels de cette ville touristique de l’Est de la République Démocratique du Congo.

L'idée d'organiser le festival vient de F BAT, un jeune danseur congolais vivant à Goma et son groupe de danse Rinha Crew.

A travers ce festival, nous voulons célébrer la danse, révéler l’universalité de cette forme artistique, dépasser les barrières politiques, culturelles et ethniques et nous rassembler autour du langage commun de la danse.

La première édition 2017 ayant été un excellent succès grâce à votre soutien, nous avons eu le courage de continuer la belle aventure. Vous pouvez revivre l'ambiance dans cette vidéo Goma Dance Fest 2017

Pourquoi ?

A l’Est de la R.D.Congo plusieurs jeunes danseurs sont talentueux, mais manquent de formations ou stages professionnelles. Ils sont tous abandonné à leur propre sort et ne bénéficient d’aucune promotion ou soutien. En grandissant la majorité abandonne la danse suite au manque de promotion, d’espace d’expression ou d’un moyen de franchir les étapes vers une carrière professionnelle. C’est pour soutenir et promouvoir ces jeunes courageux et talentueux, que nous avons pensé à créer GOMA DANCE FESTIVAL afin de leur offrir des opportunités pour une carrière professionnelle et un espace d’expression.

Les objectifs :

• Créer un événement annuel pour montrer l’importance et la valeur de danse urbaine, contemporaine et traditionnelle à la jeunesse congolaise.

• Promouvoir et renforcer les capacités de jeunes danseurs, leur permettre de se prendre en charge dans leurs créations et le soutenir pour un développement professionnel.

• Promouvoir le respect, la liberté et solidarité pour consolider la paix et la cohabitation dans la région des grands-lacs Africain.

• Permettre aux danseurs d’échanger et de s’exprimer librement, afn qu’ils se sentent égaux et valorisés

• Cultiver dans la communauté un gout de soutien et de promotion de la danse urbaine et contemporaine comme une profession artistique et un élément important pour le développement de la jeunesse.

De quoi GDF a besoin ?

Grâce à l’implication et l’engagement des danseurs de la région, cette édition sera encore une réussite.

Nous travaillons en étroite collaboration avec l’Institut Français de Goma qui nous aide avec un espace pour l’hébergement des danseurs visiteurs et pour les ateliers de danse, l'association STREET OFF du célèbre danseur Ali « Lilou » Ramdani, l’un des danseurs les plus titrés au monde et parrain du festival qui nous appui dans les ateliers, le centre Kivu Youth Entertainment qui va s'occuper du multimédia et la documentation (photos +videos), le festival Batalo East qui accueille les gagnants de notre complétion de danse GDF Championship et bien d’autres personnes de bonne volonté nous tendent la mains.

Cependant nous avons besoin d'un soutien supplémentaire pour mieux réaliser cette édition. Cette collecte de fonds vise à rassembler le montant pour couvrir :

-          les couts de transport

-          la location de la salle de spectacles pour la compétition

-          les couts de la restauration des danseurs invités et des bénévoles.

Ce que vous obtenez :

Un réel sentiment de satisfaction et de joie à aider un groupe de jeunes passionnés et motivés.

Mais si cela ne vous attire pas assez, qu'en est-il de :

- pour $10 : une lettre de remerciement

- pour $20 ; une Carte de vœux

- pour $30 : une photo GDF personnalisée

- pour $50 : une Carte de vœux et une photo GDF personnalisée

- pour $200 : un Joli portrait (dessin) de toi

- pour $500 : Parrain officiel, une lettre de remerciement, une carte de vœux, une photo GDF personnalisée, Joli portrait (dessin) de toi

L’impact :

• Les jeunes sont réunis pour promouvoir le respect, la liberté et solidarité pour consolider la paix et la cohabitation dans la région des grands-lacs Africain

• Les capacités de jeunes danseurs sont renforcées pour une future carrière professionnelle

• Les gagnants à GDF Championship participent à d’autre festival au niveau international

• La communauté de la région développe le gout de soutien et de promotion de la danse urbaine et contemporaine comme une profession artistique et un élément important pour le développement de la jeunesse.

Pour nous aider à faire en sorte que cet évènement se réalise, vous pouvez :

- Faire une donation

- Partager sans modération cette page avec vos proches

- Nous suivre sur : Facebook, Instagram, Twitter

Et vous êtes bien sûr les bienvenus au Goma, au festival, et venez visiter ce magnifique endroit! Grand Merci!

Contacts:

Tél: +243 852 525 098, +243 991 238 230

Mail: gomadancefest@gmail.com

Web : http://rinhadanceprojects.org

ENGLISH VERSION:

Goma Dance Festival is an initiative of young dancers in the town of Goma, in collaboration with some young cultural operators of that turistic town in Eastern Democratic Republic of Congo.

The idea of organising the festival comes from F BAT, a young congolese dancer living in Goma, and from his dance group Rinha Crew.

Through this festival, we want to celebrate dance, reveal the universality of this art, overcome political, cultural and ethnic barriers, and all get together around the communal language of danse.

The first edition of Goma Dance Festival in 2017 has been a great success thanks to your support, and this gave us the courage to continue this beautiful adventure. You can see the athmosphere and energy of the last edition here:  Goma Dance Fest 2017

for this edition, the activities of the festival will last for a week, from the 23rd to 29th of April/

Why the Festival?

In Eastern DRC, a large number of young dancers are talented, but they lack training opportunities or professional courses, they are all abandoned to their fate, and they do not benefit from any promotion or support. When growing up, the majority quits dancing as they do not have the promotion, space of expression or means to pass to a professional career. We decided to create the GOMA DANCE FESTIVAL indeed to support and promote these brave and talented young dancers, in order to offer them opportunities for a professional career, and to offer them a space for expression.

The objectives:

·         Create an annual event to show the importance and value of the urban and traditional African dance to the Congolese youth.

·         Promote and streghten the capacities of the young dancers, to allow them to support themselves in their creations and to support their professional development.

·         Allow dancers to share and to express themselves freely, in order to make them feel equal and valued.

·         Cultivate within the community a feeling of support and promotion of urban and contemporary dance as an artistic profession and as an important element for youth development.

·         Promote respect, freedom and solidarity to consolidate peace and cohabitation in the Great Lakes Region of Africa.

What does the GDF need?

Thanks to the engagement of dancers from the region, this edition will again be a great success. We work in collaboration with the Institut Français de Goma, which helps us with a place of accommodation for the visiting dancers and for the dance workshops, with the association STREET OFF, of the famous dancer Ali « Lilou » Ramdani, which supports us for the dance workshops. The centre Kivu Youth Entertainment will take care of multimedia and of documenting the Festival. The festival Batalo East will welcome the winners from our dance competitions  GDF Championship. And many other people of great will are fundamental in making this Festival a great success.

Thus, we need your support to make this edition great. This fundraising wishes to collect funds to cover :

·         the transportation costs

·         the rental of a room for the competition

·         costs of food for the invited dancers and the volunteers

What you will get:

A real feeling of satisfation and the joy to support of passionate and motivated group of young people!!! And also :

For a $10 donation: a thank-you letter

For a $20 donation: a greetings card

For a $30 donation: a personalized GDF photo

For a $50 donation: a greetings card and a a personalized GDF photo

For a $200 donation: a nice portrait (drawing) of you

For a $500 donation: official sponsor, a thank-you letter, a greetings card, a personalized GDF photo, a nice portrait (drawing) of you

The impact:

- the youth are reunited to promote respect, freedom and solidarity, to consolidate peace and cohabitation in the Great Lakes Region of Africa

- the skills of the young dancers are strengthened for a future professional carreer

- the winners of the GDF Championship participate to other festivals at international level

- the community of the region develops a feeling of support and promotion for urban and contemporary dance as an artistic profession and as an important element for yuth development

To help us make this event happen and make it great, you can:

·         make a donation

·         share without moderation in your social media pages

·         follow us on: Facebook, Instagram, Twitter

And of course you are very welcome in Goma, at the Festival! Come visit this magnificent place!

A huge thank you!

Contacts:

Tél: +243 852 525 098, +243 991 238 230

Mail: gomadancefest@gmail.com

Web: http://rinhadanceprojects.org
