story:
"Show Off!" is about making new musicals that rock

  • We are a group of writers, musicians, and performers creating new musicals in San Francisco
  • We are on a mission to make musicals that will move you, that will make you think and want to talk about it immediately, but will also let you out of the theater after just 75 minutes and leave you wanting more
  • When you support "Show Off!" you are helping to make the next Hamilton

Be part of the magic and form a connection with artists 

What We Need & What You Get

Here's what we need:

  • We need enough money to cover the cost of renting performance and rehearsal spaces ($10k), paying our artists a stipend for their work (another $10k), paying for housing out of state artists ($5k), costumes, props and renting sound equipment ($5k)
  • We are asking for one third of the total cost (which is $30k) to get us off the ground, and we are hoping the ticket sales will cover the rest
  • Real art comes at real cost, but it's real worth it!

Here's what you'll get:

  • Get a part in the show!
  • Get premium front-row seats for you and friends at discount prices
  • Get access to performance and rehearsal videos and behind-the-scenes footage
  • Get exclusive access to the writers and artists to ask questions and get involved in the creative process

The Impact

  • The world needs more relevant musical theater now more than ever
  • Action needs a voice, it needs a battlecry, it needs an anthem.
  • We need more memorable songs with melodies that make people want to pay attention, with lyrics that make people think and talk and act
  • We are a team that has produced over 20 musicals from "Les Miserables" to "Last Five Years", with sold-out runs; we know what it takes to produce a hit
  • With your help this will be a hit, and you can be part of it

Other Ways You Can Help

If you can't give, then spread the word!

  • Get the word out, tell your friends about "Show Off!"
  • Share on Facebook, Instagram, thru Messenger, whatever just share!

story:
The No Bull$#!% History of Invention

Appearing at the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival 2016.  Once again Kyle Allatt and Tupper shed light onto the dusty annals of history, and show us the crude sketches of dicks drawn into the margins. A story chock full of facts about the real drug addicts, thieves and mad folk who help give us the modern world. From drinking mercury to electrocuting elephants for a crowd, Kyle Allatt brings his NO Bull$#!% approach to the story of human invention.

We’ve got 8 shows in Montreal in the St. Ambroise Montreal Fringe Festival this year, and more in the Toronto Fringe Festival as well.  Kyle's previous hit show “The NO Bull$#!% History of Canada” has delighted audiences from Montreal to the Maritimes, and had a Sold out a run at the Edmonton Fringe Festival 2015.

We’re looking for funding to grow and spread this show. The more successful we are funding the show here, the more we can advertise and spread this show. After the initial run of The No Bull$#!% History of Canada, Kyle was able to tour to Charlottetown, St.John, Halfiax and then on to Edmonton in 2015. If we hit our goal here we can try to mirror and exceed that success.  This ups the likelihood we’ll be able to come to your town, or do a show you can get to experience fist hand.

NO BS: this is what we need & what we can get you

Ok so no bull$#!%, we need money to offset the cost of 2 fringes, and venue fees, printing flyers and posters.

Montreal OFF Fringe fees: 620.00

Toronto Fringe fees: 750.00

Theater St.Catherine's fees: 500.00

Printing flyers posters, promo video, Sandwich board: 250.00

Whoa Jay, (Kyle's producer and friend) your math doesn’t add up. If you need 2120.00 why are you only asking for 1500.00?  Well here’s the deal 1. We need to hit our goals here to Maximize funding. Feel free to give more, we can and will accept if we meet and exceed our goal. All of these funds go into making the show, and pushing the show out with the highest quality to most people, so we’re no-profit. Your money will be well spent. 2.  We are looking to offset the costs we’ve already incurred, if we don’t make our goal the show will go on, its further show and improving the media coverage and quality of the props that are dependent on funding form folks like you.  The more we get the more we will do.

So this is our proposal in a nutshell. We’ll be adding more in the weeks to come. Also if you’re in Montreal from the 8th to the 19th  Here is the show location and times. Come see what all the work we’ve put in is for, you’ll learn something about history, invention and what really went on 100% without bull$#!% guaranteed.

The No Bull$#!% History of Invention

Théâtre Sainte-Catherine

264 Rue Sainte-Catherine E, Montréal, QC H2X 1L4, Canada

Tickets call : 514.849.FEST (3378)

Show times:

June 8th  7:45PM

June 9th 9:00PM

June 11th  1:00PM

June 12th  3:30PM

June 15th  5:30PM

June 17th 5:30PM

June 18th 7:00PM

June 19th  12:00PM

story:
What WDMC and Queens Shakespeare Are Up To Now

After another amazing season, with amazing work onstage, with amazing audiences, who were in turn….amazed in 2015, What Dreams May Co in partnership with Queens Shakespeare Inc. again turns the microscope onto two of literature’s most famous characters, who on the surface appear to be complete opposites. One a certain boy who will never grow up, the other one of Shakespeare’s kings who has grown quite old. Yet they both seem to suffer a clear case of “Peter Pan Syndrome”; flying about from place to place, and oblivious to the destruction they leave in their wake. Following up our successful run of The Terrible Tragedy of Peter Pan, What Dreams May Co is pleased to present William Shakespeare’s King Lear.

Director Emily C.A. Snyder brings audiences to the last days of Imperial Russia, a world of encroaching cold and darkness, of blowing winds, and crashing thunder. A place where class distinctions are brutally enforced, in the ever shifting battle to keep from being…left out in the cold. Exploring this timeless work through this high stakes lens, with a female Lear played by Kitty Mortland, audiences will be left to discover their own reason in madness, find the wisdom in folly, and perhaps…see a bit of their own nature in the shadow of Lear’s looking glass.

Why Do We Need Your Help?

We are performing right in the heart of Times Square!  We are so excited to be producing at John DeSotelle Studio this winter!  Now that our rent is going up, any help you can give will be felt even more deeply.  Here's a breakdown of what you can do:

If you donate $90 you will be covering the price of a week of rehearsals.

If you donate $150 you will be covering the price of our programs.

If you donate $200 you will be covering the price of our photographer.

If you donate $500 you will be covering the rights to perform the play.

If you donate $1000 you will cover half a weekend of performances.

If you donate $2000 you will cover a full weekend of performances.

A contribution of any size will help us to make things happen, and makes you a part of the artistic process! So choose your favorite perk and join the team!

Who Is WDMC?

Founded in 2011, What Dreams May Co. is dedicated to making the classics accessible to all. We believe that the beauty of the language and the deeply human themes that Shakespeare used are still entirely relevant today. We remain true to these important foundations and use them to create a world audiences can recognize as their own, populated with characters that reflect the diverse community we live in. By holding the mirror up to the nature of our world as it is now, we can gain a deeper understanding of the words that have been handed down to us from centuries past.

Who Is Queens Shakespeare?

Founded in 2005 by Nanette Asher, Queens Shakespeare, Inc. is a not-for-profit professional theatrical company, which serves Queens County and the greater New York City area. Its aim is to act as a laboratory for actors of all ages and experience levels to explore classical works and to perform in fully produced, accessible, and innovative productions. Each season one production is developed as an educational tour which is then presented at different venues throughout the state. Producing and touring in this fashion allows the company to actively contribute to the growth and vibrancy of the developing Queens arts scene, while at the same time exposing classical works to modern audiences through the educational tour.


Your friends at WDMC and Queens Shakespeare,

Chrissy and Jonathan

What WDMC and Queens Shakespeare Are Up To Now

After another
amazing season, with amazing work onstage, with amazing audiences, who were in
turn….amazed in 2015, What Dreams May Co in partnership with Queens Shakespeare
Inc. again turns the microscope onto two of literature’s most famous
characters, who on the surface appear to be complete opposites. One a certain boy
who will never grow up, the other one of Shakespeare’s kings who has grown
quite old. Yet they both seem to suffer a clear case of “Peter Pan Syndrome”;
flying about from place to place, and oblivious to the destruction they leave
in their wake. Following up our successful run
of The Terrible Tragedy of Peter Pan,
What Dreams May Co is pleased to present William Shakespeare’s King Lear.
Director Emily C.A. Snyder brings audiences to the last days of
Imperial Russia, a world of encroaching cold and darkness, of blowing winds,
and crashing thunder. A place where class distinctions are brutally enforced,
in the ever shifting battle to keep from being…left out in the cold. Exploring
this timeless work through this high stakes lens, with a female Lear played by
Kitty Mortland, audiences will be left to discover their own reason in madness,
find the wisdom in folly, and perhaps…see a bit of their own nature in the
shadow of Lear’s looking glass. 

Why Do We Need Your Help?We are performing right in the heart of Times Square!  We are so excited to be
 producing at John DeSotelle Studio this winter!  Now that our rent is 
going up, any help you can give will be felt even more deeply.  Here's a
 breakdown of what you can do:If you donate $90 you will be covering the price of a week of rehearsals.If you donate $150 you will be covering the price of our programs.If you donate $200 you will be covering the price of our photographer.If you donate $500 you will be covering the rights to perform the play.If you donate $1000 you will cover half a weekend of performances.If you donate $2000 you will cover a full weekend of performances.A
 contribution of any size will help us to make things happen, and makes 
you a part of the artistic process! So choose your favorite perk and 
join the team!Who Is WDMC?Founded in 2011, What Dreams May Co. is dedicated to making the classics accessible to all. We believe that 
the beauty of the language and the deeply human themes that Shakespeare 
used are still entirely relevant today. We remain true to these 
important foundations and use them to create a world audiences can 
recognize as their own, populated with characters that reflect the 
diverse community we live in. By holding the mirror up to the nature of 
our world as it is now, we can gain a deeper understanding of the words 
that have been handed down to us from centuries past.Who Is Queens Shakespeare?Founded in 2005 by Nanette Asher, Queens Shakespeare, Inc. is a 
not-for-profit professional theatrical company, which serves Queens 
County and the greater New York City area. Its aim is to act as a 
laboratory for actors of all ages and experience levels to explore 
classical works and to perform in fully produced, accessible, and 
innovative productions. Each season one production is developed as an 
educational tour which is then presented at different venues throughout 
the state. Producing and touring in this fashion allows the company to 
actively contribute to the growth and vibrancy of the developing Queens 
arts scene, while at the same time exposing classical works to modern 
audiences through the educational tour.Your friends at WDMC and Queens Shakespeare,Chrissy and Jonathan

story:
Who We Are 

My name is Jordan Klomp, a young LA-Based actor and teaching artist. Together with co-producer Bo Powell, director Frank Weidner, and a team of friends and fellow artists who are among LA's best, I am independently producing an intimate and compelling iteration of Shakespeare's Cymbeline. Our show premieres this November at the Whitmore-Lindley Theatre in North Hollywood, and runs weekends from November 4-20th.

Cymbeline has always held a special place in my heart for its rich characters, complexity of language, and compelling storyline. The fact that several of its themes have such modern-day relevance makes now as poignant a time as any for Cymbeline's retelling. What really makes this production special, though, is the collective of incredibly talented artists who have banded together to work on it. Your contributions will guarantee that every member of this fantastic team receives compensation for the  hours of time and huge amounts of creative energy they have poured into this project. 

What We Need & What You Get

  • To help amply stipend the artists and cover our production costs, we need $5000.
  • Signed Posters, a glass of wine, free tickets, a personalized sonnet...even an Elizabethan Feast held in your name! Visit our "Perks" page for more details!
  • While we would love to reach our goal, every little bit goes a long way to paying the cast and crew! The more you donate, the more likely it is that this will be able to afford to reunite for more great theatre!

The Impact

Helping our team afford some money for gas, or helping to recompense them for the hours of work they have taken off to be a part of this is important. Just as important is the support your donation will give towards this unforgettable project, the likes of which is rarely seen in the intimate LA Theatre Scene. 

  • We are an ensemble hailing from some of the best Theatres in Los Angeles, Including Theatricum Botanicum, A Noise Within, Antaeus, Rogue Machine, Sacred Fools, and Center Theatre Group.
  • Our goal with this project is to bring some big theatre talent to a wider audience. Tickets are only $10-$20, meaning more people can afford to see our production than those of larger theaters. 
  • We are also using this affordability of pricing to have our show reach schools and students. Many of our ensemble members are teachers, and educating/inspiring the next generation of students and artists is something we are extremely passionate about!

Risks & Challenges

As a self-produced show with a newly formed core, we don't yet possess the audience of an established company, and aren't eligible for grants or funding from commercial sources. This is why we need YOU! 

  • Part of our choice in self-producing is in allowing for the inclusion of Equity Actors in our ensemble on a completely volunteer basis. This means a higher quality ensemble and performance!
  • In addition, we are not constricted in what we can stipend our actors and crew like a Theatre company would be. The more you donate, the more our team will earn for their efforts, and the more we can give back artistically to our community!

Other Ways You Can Help

As an artist, I understand that sometimes, there is just no extra money available to donate to a project. There are many other ways you can help support us though, including: 

  • Purchasing a ticket to our show! Tickets are available on http://cymbelinela.brownpapertickets.com . You can even type in "Mountaineer" for a $10 ticket!
  • Like and follow us on Social Networking! Be sure to like our pages on Facebook (https://www.facebook.com/cymbelinela) and on Instagram (@cymbelinela). See a friend in our cast, or a really cool rehearsal picture? Like or share the photo! Hashtag us at #cymbelinela. We're grateful for your support!

Sincerely,

The Cymbeline Team

story:
Overview:

My name is Nova Grayson Casillo, and producing Dracula will be my thesis for my degree in Design and Technical Theatre.  I will be designing the props, scenery, lighting, and costumes for the production. This production will be a culminating point for me - allowing me to explore the areas of technical theatre for which I have the most passion.

Dracula interests me for a number of reasons, the first being the subject matter. I am drawn to plays which are dark and contain elements of horror. 

The challenges in this specific adaptation of Dracula include sudden scene changes and stunning technical surprises. Balancing the intimacy of the story with the spectacle is key. There are also a few props which are of particular interest: a live rat is eaten on stage and a blood transfusion takes place.

The technical aspects of this story are also showcased more than those in a typical production. Unlike previous productions I have designed, where the tech is successful when it goes unnoticed, the special effects and production elements are crucial to the plot moving forward.

Meet the Director:

Rebekah Reimer graduated from Belmont University in Nashville, TN in 2013. She has directed several shows, but is uniquely qualified for this production through her additional technical experience as a designer, technician, and technical director.  She is drawn to shows which require technical prowess, and Dracula has been on her list to direct for quite some time. To learn more about Rebekah, you can visit her website. 

Risks & Challenges:

Producing this show will be challenging and incredibly risky. That is why we have chosen it. Although implementing the show will be no easy feat, our largest obstacle is in funding.  If we are unable to reach our goal in funding, we will still be able to do the production - but the challenges in creating the spectacle we hope for will be magnified. 

What We Need:

Our budget breakdown is as follows:

Rights   $400.00

Director/TD   $500.00

Paid Actors*   $300.00

Stage Manager*   $200.00

Lighting   $100.00

Scenery   $400.00

Costumes   $300.00

Props   $300.00

Makeup   $50.00

Promotional   $50.00

Total:   $2,500.00

*In addition to the numbers listed above, the actors and stage manager will also receive a portion of ticket sales as payment for their work. 

What You Get:

A donation to our campaign could get you discounted tickets, full or half page ad space in the program, signed posters, promotional pins/stickers, curtain speech acknowledgements, themed cocktails and desserts at a meet and greet downtown, and the warm fuzzy feeling of contributing to the arts (not to mention our undying devotion). Donations and ad space submissions will be accepted after the 60 days of the main campaign, however the perks will no longer be available, so get your perks now! Any communications in regards to perk redemptions, donations, ad space submissions, questions, etc will be handled through CravatProductions@gmail.com.

View our perks to see more details.  ---------------------------------->

Other Ways You Can Help:

Donating to our campaign isn't the only way to help.  Share the link. Spread the word.  Contact us regarding opportunities to volunteer.  Any little thing you do will be a tremendous help.  

Show Dates:

Friday December 15, 2017 at 7:30pm

Saturday December 16, 2017 at 2pm

Saturday December 16, 2017 at 7:30pm

Sunday December 17, 2017 at 2pm

And remember:

"There are dark imaginings in the world. And though a foe, when vanquished, is gone from sight - A fear, once rooted in your mind, is yours forever."

story:
Hello Friend!

WE ARE TAKING LENA OFF-BROADWAY!!!
But, in order to accomplish this, we must produce a presentation ( It's more like a fancy audition) for theatrical investors and theatrical houses. If these folks like what they see, the next steps involve them producing our little skit (fingers crossed) in their theater.The presentation will be held in NYC at the decadent Duane Park, NYC. We have invited renowned theaters in New York City, to potentially become our new home. 

How Much?


The total cost of the presentation is $7,500
 

HOW IS THE MONEY SPENT?
With a bit of magic and miracles, we are going to WOW these folks. But, putting on a show can be costly. Why? Because unfortunately, we can't ask world class musicians, management, dramaturg, director, stage managers, cast and stage crew to be paid in hugs and high-fives. Your contributions go to them!

Cast Rehearsals 

The Team will work A LOT in a little amount of time. 

We will have production meetings from now until showtime. 

WHY Do This Now?
Who Runs The World? Women! - Our world is finally beginning to recognize women as the most influential beings on the earth. Lena Horne was there as a woman, specifically a woman of color. She broke down racial barriers, kicked down doors, and forged a path for many Black female artists to follow.  It's time to tell her story.

We at #TeamLena are excited to share this journey with you. We are grateful for your love and support in making this presentation a reality. I'm a believer in the strength of community, and together we can do it! And when we go to Broadway,YOU can say, you helped us get there!

ABOUT

LENA: A Moment With A Lady

As we approach the centennial of her birth, Lena Horne’s legacy lives on as we are transported back in time to remember, relate and relish with the one and only. Set in 1981, Lena, played by Syndee Winters (Lion King, Pippin, Hamilton) constructs a narrative through words and music of some of her most pivotal personal and professional moments, which made her the multifarious women we all have come to love. On a mission to share the truth and overcome adversity, she unexpectedly opens crevices that she has eluded for many years.

She’s recognized as of the most influential African-American pioneers in entertainment. Ms. Horne collaborated with some of greatest musical artists of the 20th century, shattered the color barrier in Hollywood, and she was heavily involved with the civil rights movement. Lena Horne is not only recognized as a timeless beauty, inside and out, but she is cherished as an American Icon.

story:
Short Summary

Voyeur Theatre Collective is committed to exploring the evolution of theatre for the millennial generation by changing the makeup of the social art form to reflect the changing demographics and interests of its audience. A VTC show is part party, part performance—celebratory, immersive, digital, completely original and unflinchingly intimate.

 

Our tight-knit collective consists of a diverse array of artists, allowing our performances to utilize everything from live DJs and video projection to choreographed movement and audience interaction. Culture evolves, and we do too.


Voyeur Theatre Collective’s spring show is Next Level. It follows five players as they navigate a party depicted as a video game, with accomplishments to unlock and other “non-playable characters” (NPCs) to battle. The show explores existentialist concepts by assigning enhanced meaning to social events and interpersonal interactions, raising the stakes of everyday life. Just as millennials are able to choose to interact with the world or stay at home on Netflix, audience members can choose to observe or actively participate in the show. The show will feature live musical performances, video projections, dance and choreographed movement and an original score.

What We Need

Voyeur Theatre Collective is only three years old, and does not receive funding from Northwestern University. While we have held fundraisers throughout the year, we are ultimately financially dependent on this Indiegogo page. Our shows are rooted in core tenants of the millennial existence like technology and live music, and thus require a substantial budget.

The three primary costs for this show are renting a performance space, constructing a set with several high-powered projectors and renting a full sound system. We also plan on attracting a non-traditional theatre audience with low ticket prices, and thus need to subsidize that cost.

The Impact

When you generously donate to Voyeur Theatre Collective’s spring performance, you allow us to change the way our generation uses art to understand ourselves and the world. VTC’s core ethos of uniting creative people from a diverse array of disciplines and backgrounds demonstrates our commitment to unifying through theatre. Help us create immersive, intimate, urgently relevant theatre.
